content.question: Which of the following statements is true about "plug type" aircraft doors?

options.A: They are always used in unpressurised aircraft.
options.B: Each door can move inside and outside the aircraft.
options.C: They must have a pressure relief valve.
options.D: They can only be hydraulically or electrically operated.

key_points: On pressurised aircraft, the pressure hull has to be made very strong to withstand the constant "bulging" force of the high pressure air inside
There are many potential weak points in this, including windows, hatches, and doors
Therefore, the doors in a pressurised aeroplane have to be specifically designed to seal to the frame and not break or buckle under the forces of pressurisation
learning.explanation: On pressurised aircraft, the pressure hull has to be made very strong to withstand the constant "bulging" force of the high pressure air inside. There are many potential weak points in this, including windows, hatches, and doors. Therefore, the doors in a pressurised aeroplane have to be specifically designed to seal to the frame and not break or buckle under the forces of pressurisation. This is why pressurised aircraft often use "plug type" doors, where the door is larger than the frame, and is mounted inside of the frame, so the door is being pushed into the door frame by the force of air pressure, acting like a "plug" for the hole. These doors have to be opened inwards into the aircraft, and then are usually hinged in such a way that they can go back through the door frame sideways and remain outside the aircraft whilst open. This is done primarily to reduce the space taken up inside the aircraft by the door, which also helps during an evacuation. Therefore, the most correct answer is that the door can move inside and outside the aircraft. As for the other options; They are not always used in unpressurised aircraft, in fact I imagine that is quite rare. They do not need a pressure relief valve, they are supposed to hold quite high pressure loads, and there will be an over-pressure relief valve somewhere on the aircraft fuselage. They can be manually operated, and often are.

content.question: The heating facility for the windshield of an aircraft is…

options.A: Used on a continual basis as it reduces the thermal gradients which adversely affect the useful life of the components.
options.B: Harmful to the integrity of the windows in the event of a bird strike.
options.C: Used only at low altitudes where there is a risk of ice formation.
options.D: Only used when hot air demisting is insufficient.

learning.explanation: 021.02.04.01.10: Explain the function of window heating for structural purposes. The flight deck windshield is made of many different layers of materials, mostly plastics such as acrylic and vinyl, as well as some layers of toughened glass, to give it favourable properties such as high strength, good flexibility (for impact resistance) and a hard wearing outer coating, with good rain resistance. They also contain heating elements which have a couple of different jobs, their main job being to keep the plastics in a slightly softer state, where they are flexible enough to absorb and deflect impacts from objects like birds at very high speeds (it is therefore used on a continuous basis during the entire flight). If the heating was not present, then the windshield would become very brittle in the extreme cold of the upper airways and could break more easily upon impact. The secondary jobs of the heated windshield are de-fogging and de-icing, which are important in their own right, but are certainly a secondary consideration to the impact resistance. Another rationale for the constant operation of the window heating system is the mitigation of thermal gradients. When the window heating system is activated, it ensures that the window pane remains at a consistent temperature throughout the entirety of the flight.

content.question: Which of the following sources of hydraulic pressure is commonly used for operation of cargo doors when the electric hydraulic pumps are not working?

options.A: Hydraulic accumulator.
options.B: Hand pump.
options.C: Engine-driven pumps.
options.D: Ram air turbine.

key_points: On some large aircraft (such as the Airbus A320 family), the cargo doors are very heavy and are therefore lifted by hydraulics
They are only opened and closed on the ground, of course, so primarily this will be done with the electric hydraulic pumps providing the pressure to the system

However, if the electric hydraulic pumps are not operating (electric supply issues or pumps INOP), then the cargo doors can be opened and closed using a hand pump to provide the necessary pressure to the hydraulics
learning.explanation: On some large aircraft (such as the Airbus A320 family), the cargo doors are very heavy and are therefore lifted by hydraulics. They are only opened and closed on the ground, of course, so primarily this will be done with the electric hydraulic pumps providing the pressure to the system. However, if the electric hydraulic pumps are not operating (electric supply issues or pumps INOP), then the cargo doors can be opened and closed using a hand pump to provide the necessary pressure to the hydraulics. As for the other options: Engine driven pumps require the engines to be on, and that would be very hazardous for ground crew trying to open the cargo doors, so is not feasible. A ram air turbine is a small wind turbine that drops from the underside of an aircraft to provide power/hydraulic pressure to important controls in flight. It is not used on the ground, nor would it be useful without any airflow through it. A hydraulic accumulator would likely still have some pressure in it during most ground operations, but it is not what you would use to operate the cargo doors, as it would quickly run out of pressure and is needed for the parking brakes in some aircraft, etc.

content.question: A hydraulic accumulator serves to…

options.A: Dampen fluctuations in hydraulic pressure, and act as a backup reservoir.
options.B: Dampen fluctuations in hydraulic pressure, and act as a primary reservoir.
options.C: Cool the hydraulic fluid, and act as a primary reservoir.
options.D: Cool the hydraulic fluid, and act as a backup reservoir.

key_points: An accumulator is fitted to store hydraulic fluid under pressure, dampen pressure fluctuations, allow for thermal expansion and provide an emergency supply of fluid to the system in the event of a pump failure
The gas side of the accumulator is charged to a predetermined pressure with air or nitrogen
As the accumulator is fitted and the hydraulic pressure in the system builds up, the gas in the accumulator will be compressed until fluid and gas pressures equalise at normal system pressure
learning.explanation: An accumulator is fitted to store hydraulic fluid under pressure, dampen pressure fluctuations, allow for thermal expansion and provide an emergency supply of fluid to the system in the event of a pump failure. The gas side of the accumulator is charged to a predetermined pressure with air or nitrogen. As the accumulator is fitted and the hydraulic pressure in the system builds up, the gas in the accumulator will be compressed until fluid and gas pressures equalise at normal system pressure. That is why the accumulator gauge will read the same as the hydraulic system is pressurised to.

Which of the following options are the purposes of an accumulator in a hydraulic system?
1) to damp pressure fluctuations
2) to cool the hydraulic fluid
3) to serve as a limited alternate source of pressure
4) to serve as a main pressure source for normal operation
5) to allow for thermal expansion

options.A: 1, 3 and 5
options.B: 2, 3 and 5
options.D: 1, 2 and 4

key_points: Hydraulic Accumulators are usually installed in hydraulic systems to store energy, in the form of hydraulic fluid under pressure (which will allow limited operation of hydraulic services when the pump is not operating or in case of an emergency) and to dampen out pressure fluctuations within the system
They are often used after a pump in a hydraulic system to do both these jobs, and by doing so increase efficiency and reduce the stresses on the hydraulic system

They can use a diaphragm (annex above) or a movable piston, with one side connected to the hydraulic lines and containing hydraulic fluid, but with the other side filled with gas (usually nitrogen), which can compress to the same pressure as the system
learning.explanation: Hydraulic Accumulators are usually installed in hydraulic systems to store energy, in the form of hydraulic fluid under pressure (which will allow limited operation of hydraulic services when the pump is not operating or in case of an emergency) and to dampen out pressure fluctuations within the system. They are often used after a pump in a hydraulic system to do both these jobs, and by doing so increase efficiency and reduce the stresses on the hydraulic system. They can use a diaphragm (annex above) or a movable piston, with one side connected to the hydraulic lines and containing hydraulic fluid, but with the other side filled with gas (usually nitrogen), which can compress to the same pressure as the system. They can also help with absorbing the pressure of thermal expansion within closed hydraulic systems, when the fluid expands or contract due to temperature changes, but cannot flow back to the resevoir. When the system is open, any excess fluid will flow into the reservoir. The are not used for aiding cooling.

key_points: A Ram Air Turbine (RAT) is a small wind turbine that is installed in an aircraft to be used as a source of power during emergencies
In these cases, the RAT will power vital systems such as flight controls or flight-critical instrumentation, navigation and communication equipment
The RAT generates power from the airstream based on the speed of the aircraft and is connected to an electrical generator or to a hydraulic pump
learning.explanation: A Ram Air Turbine (RAT) is a small wind turbine that is installed in an aircraft to be used as a source of power during emergencies. In these cases, the RAT will power vital systems such as flight controls or flight-critical instrumentation, navigation and communication equipment. The RAT generates power from the airstream based on the speed of the aircraft and is connected to an electrical generator or to a hydraulic pump. Consequently, more power is generated when the aircraft is operating at a higher speed and less is generated when operating at lower speeds.

content.question: During a normal aircraft service, an engineer notices an oily mist leaving the pressure release valve whilst draining the nitrogen from a horizontally mounted hydraulic accumulator. What does this indicate?

key_points: Note: Please let us know if you see this in your exam, as we have reason to believe that it may be changed or removed due to appeals, thank you
Whilst this is an awful question, which pilots would usually have no business dealing with, it can still be worked out with the normal knowledge from the syllabus

A hydraulic accumulator is a device used to store hydraulic pressure, for the purposes of smoothing out hydraulic pressure changes, and storing the pressure in case there is a loss of hydraulic pump, so a finite amount of pressure remains for further uses
learning.explanation: Note: Please let us know if you see this in your exam, as we have reason to believe that it may be changed or removed due to appeals, thank you. Whilst this is an awful question, which pilots would usually have no business dealing with, it can still be worked out with the normal knowledge from the syllabus. A hydraulic accumulator is a device used to store hydraulic pressure, for the purposes of smoothing out hydraulic pressure changes, and storing the pressure in case there is a loss of hydraulic pump, so a finite amount of pressure remains for further uses. It works by compressing nitrogen inside the accumulator with the force of the hydraulic fluid, and then the high pressure nitrogen is where the energy is stored. There are a few different ways to do this, via diaphragm, with a moving piston between the fluid and the nitrogen, and with no separation at all, just gravity. These are the types of gas charged accumulators, but there are also spring accumulators and even weighted accumulators that can be used. We do not normally look into these though. If an accumulator was mounted horizontally, the gravity option would not keep the fluid in the lines, so would not work. Therefore only a diaphragm or (more likely) a moving piston would be used in this orientation. This should mean that there is no cross-contamination of nitrogen and hydraulic fluid. The hydraulic fluid stays on one side of the piston/diaphragm, the nitrogen stays on the other side. If, as in this scenario, there is an amount of hydraulic fluid leaving the nitrogen release valve, then there must have been some sort of leak between the two, for hydraulic fluid to enter the nitrogen section.

content.question: The pressure in a hydraulic system is measured relative to which of the following?

options.A: A vacuum
options.B: A pressure differential
options.C: Atmospheric pressure
options.D: Oil pressure

key_points: There are different ways of measuring and stating pressure

These include; Absolute pressure, which is referenced against a vacuum, Gauge pressure, which is referenced against ambient (usually atmospheric) pressure, and Differential pressure, which measures the difference between the pressures of two different locations
In this case, hydraulic pressure is a gauge pressure, and is therefore measured against atmospheric pressure
learning.explanation: There are different ways of measuring and stating pressure. These include; Absolute pressure, which is referenced against a vacuum, Gauge pressure, which is referenced against ambient (usually atmospheric) pressure, and Differential pressure, which measures the difference between the pressures of two different locations. In this case, hydraulic pressure is a gauge pressure, and is therefore measured against atmospheric pressure. We can also work this out by thinking about what happens when you de-pressurise a hydraulic system completely. The hydraulic pressure will read 0 PSI, as the fluid is exerting the same amount of pressure on its surroundings as the atmosphere does. Atmospheric pressure is around 14.7 PSI greater than a vacuum (i.e. its absolute pressure is 14.7 PSI, or 1013 hPa). For instance, manifold pressure gauges read out MAP (Manifold Absolute Pressure), so show the absolute ambient pressure when the engine is off. Other systems rarely read out absolute pressure.

learning.explanation: A "swash plate pump" is actually an axial piston "constant pressure" hydraulic pump, also called a "demand pump". This is the only pump that has a variable swash plate. This is the best type of hydraulic pump for aircraft hydraulic systems. It modulates its volumetric output to provide constant pressure to the system, and therefore needs no automatic cut-out valve like a constant delivery pump would. It works the same way as a constant delivery pump for the part. The inlet flow from the reservoir enters the pistons when they are furthest away, then the drive shaft spins the swash plate round so the pistons push against the fluid and this provides pressure to the hydraulic system through the outlet tube. The control piston senses the pressure in the system and adjusts the angle of the swash plate to either increase or decrease the amount of "pushing" the pistons do, thereby keeping the system pressure constant. This will become more clear if you have a look at the attached pictures. The first picture will give an overview of how this constant pressure pump looks. The pressure applied by the driver/pilot onto the brake pedal does work on the incompressible brake fluid (hydraulic fluid), which acts on a piston to push the brake pads into the brake discs, thereby applying the brakes. learning.explanation: A constant delivery hydraulic pump can also be called a fixed volume or fixed displacement pump. It is less complex than a constant pressure pump, and simply produces a constant volume of hydraulic fluid per turn of the pump, with no ability to change this dependent on the pressure in the system. On its own it is not useful as it has varying pressure output, which could perhaps overpressure a system or burn out the pump motor, etc., so it has to be combined with an automatic cut-out valve (ACOV) which turns this constant voulme output into a constant pressure supply into a system. Hydraulic Accumulators are usually installed in hydraulic systems to store energy, in the form of hydraulic fluid under pressure (which will allow limited operation of hydraulic services when the pump is not operating or in case of an emergency) and to dampen out pressure fluctuations within the system. key_points: A hydraulic filter is a component used by hydraulic systems, which is installed in the pressure and return lines, to continuously remove contaminants in the hydraulic oil
This process will purify the hydraulic fluid and protect the system from damages created by the particle contents
Some filters are equipped with a contamination indicator
learning.explanation: A hydraulic filter is a component used by hydraulic systems, which is installed in the pressure and return lines, to continuously remove contaminants in the hydraulic oil. This process will purify the hydraulic fluid and protect the system from damages created by the particle contents. Some filters are equipped with a contamination indicator. As contaminating particles collect on the filter element, the differential pressure across the element increases. For pop-up indicators, when the increase in pressure reaches a specific value, an indicator (usually in the filter head) pops out, signifying an impending filter by-pass - the filter must be cleaned or replaced. At this point, the filter is still able to filter the fluid, however it is likely to become fully blocked/clogged soon.

key_points: ALTERNATE BRAKES Power brake actuating systems use the aircraft hydraulic system as the source of power to apply the brakes

learning.explanation: ALTERNATE BRAKES Power brake actuating systems use the aircraft hydraulic system as the source of power to apply the brakes. Early aircraft had a single braking system with no backup or redundancy, meaning that any failure could result in total loss of braking capability. Nowadays, most large passenger aircraft have braking redundancy which is achieved by multiple, independent hydraulic systems backed up by accumulators. These systems allow for several layers of failure without resulting in total loss of braking capability. In most cases, the right hydraulic system supplies the normal brakes. If this is lost, there is an automatic switchover to Alternate Brakes powered by the center system. In addition to supply system redundancy, the brake accumulator is also an emergency source of power for the brakes in many power brake systems. The accumulator is pre-charged with air or nitrogen on one side of its internal diaphragm. Enough hydraulic fluid is contained on the other side of the diaphragm to operate the brakes in case of an emergency.

key_points: A "demand pump" is actually an axial piston "constant pressure" hydraulic pump
This is the only pump that has a variable swash plate
This is the best type of hydraulic pump for most aircraft hydraulic systems
learning.explanation: A "demand pump" is actually an axial piston "constant pressure" hydraulic pump. This is the only pump that has a variable swash plate. This is the best type of hydraulic pump for most aircraft hydraulic systems. It runs at a constant RPM and modulates its volumetric flow output to provide constant pressure to the system, and therefore needs no automatic cut-out valve like a constant delivery pump would. This is why it is called a "demand pump", it regulates its output based on the demand. It works the same way as a constant delivery pump for the most part. The inlet flow from the reservoir enters the pistons when they are furthest away, then the drive shaft spins the swash plate round so the pistons push against the fluid and this provides pressure to the hydraulic system through the outlet tube. The control piston senses the pressure in the system and adjusts the angle of the swash plate to either increase or decrease the amount of "pushing" the pistons do, thereby keeping the system pressure constant. This will become more clear if you have a look at the attached pictures. The first picture will give an overview of how this constant pressure pump looks. Figure 1 shows the pump at maximum stroke and figure 2 shows the pump at minimum stroke, when the system is already at the correct pressure. In terms of hydraulic pressures, most large transport aircraft have hydraulic pressures in the range of 3000 - 5000 psi as this is a good amount to power heavy control surfaces and landing gear systems, etc. Larger aircraft tend to have higher pressures in general, and the Airbus A380 runs hydraulic pressures of 5000 psi, whereas Boeing 737s run at 3000 psi.

key_points: A "demand pump" is actually an axial piston "constant pressure" hydraulic pump

learning.explanation: A "demand pump" is actually an axial piston "constant pressure" hydraulic pump. This is the only pump that has a variable swash plate. This is the best type of hydraulic pump for most aircraft hydraulic systems. It modulates its volumetric output to provide constant pressure to the system, and therefore needs no automatic cut-out valve like a constant delivery pump would. This is why it is called a "demand pump", it regulates its output based on the demand. It works the same way as a constant delivery pump for the most part. The inlet flow from the reservoir enters the pistons when they are furthest away, then the drive shaft spins the swash plate round so the pistons push against the fluid and this provides pressure to the hydraulic system through the outlet tube. The control piston senses the pressure in the system and adjusts the angle of the swash plate to either increase or decrease the amount of "pushing" the pistons do, thereby keeping the system pressure constant. This will become more clear if you have a look at the attached pictures. The first picture will give an overview of how this constant pressure pump looks. key_points: Axial piston pumps are constant pressure pump (variable volume)
This pump supplies fluid at a variable volume and can control the pressure
The cylinder and the drive-shaft are coaxial and rotate taking the pistons which can move up and down in the cylinder
learning.explanation: Axial piston pumps are constant pressure pump (variable volume). This pump supplies fluid at a variable volume and can control the pressure. The cylinder and the drive-shaft are coaxial and rotate taking the pistons which can move up and down in the cylinder. The pistons are a connected to shoes to the non-rotating yoke or swash plate. The angle of the swash-plate and thus the piston stroke is varied by the position of the control piston. This piston is controlled by the outlet pressure on one side of it and a spring on the other. If the pump is stationary there will be no hydraulic pressure and so the spring will push the control piston to the right and the swash-plate angle will be maximum. As the pump begins to rotate the pistons will start moving up and down because of the angle of the swash-plate. If the required operating pressure is reached, the control piston will be pushed back to the left causing the swash-plate to be almost vertical and therefore the pistons’ stroke will be minimal. learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.04.02.01.06: Explain the purpose of main-wheel (body) steering. Larger aircraft with multiple main gear wheels often mount the main landing gear on bogie beams, which are excellent for absorbing direct impacts during landing, but can suffer from very high sideways loads during tight turns whilst taxiing. These sideways loads also put a lot of sideways stress on the tyres, which can only rotate forwards and backwards, of course, so will get unnecessarily "scrubbed" during tight turns. This effect can be reduced somewhat by giving the main gear bogie beams a small amount of available steering angle, which is only used in slow speed tight turns, turning the opposite direction of the nose wheel to turn sideways forces into longitudinal forces on the main gear assemblies, thereby reducing stress on the torsional links and reducing tyre abrasion. INCORRECT: braking distance will almost always be longer in any case, regardless of runway condition. Manual braking will never ensure the required stopping distance – take-off has to be avoided. INCORRECT, while manual braking significantly increases the braking distance (50%) this doesn’t mean the stopping distance available isn’t long enough. The auto-brake system can be used for automated braking during landing or during a rejected take-off (RTO). There are several modes the auto-brakes can be in: Off Armed the auto-brake system is ready to be used but there are conditions which have to be met before the auto-brakes start operating. Activated When the system was armed and the necessary conditions have been met the system can be activated in different ways depending on the type of aircraft. The auto-brake system is not useable when the alternate braking system is in use. Depending on the type of aircraft, 3 to 5 modes of deceleration can be selected. Anti-skid protection is provided during autobrake operation, with inoperative anti-skid the auto-brake system will not operate. The autobrakes will be armed once a deceleration mode has been selected. When the aircraft touches down and the main wheels spin up or by the means of weight on wheels the auto-land system will be activated. The auto-land system continues to brake until a complete stop or until the auto-brakes are disarmed. The selected deceleration mode will give a standard deceleration rate independent on the weight of the aircraft for a dry runway. Disarming of the autobrakes will occur by any of the following crew actions: Manual braking Advancing any thrust lever after landing Moving the speed brake lever to down after speed brakes have been deployed on the ground. Moving the autobrake selector to Disarm or Off. When RTO is selected, the maximum brake pressure will be applied when all thrust levers a closed above a ground speed of 85 knots. So below this 85 knots the autobrakes are not activated. Manual braking When the anti-skid is inoperative the braking distance will almost always be longer in any case, regardless of runway condition. Manual braking will never be as consistent and efficient as the auto-brake with anti-skid would.

content.question: The nose wheel extension of an aircraft is 2 inches less than normal when the aircraft is correctly loaded, the most likely cause is…

key_points: OLEO STRUT Large aircraft have Oleo-Struts as shock absorbers

An oleo strut consists of an inner metal tube or piston, which is attached to the wheel axle, and which moves up and down in an outer (or upper) metal tube, or cylinder, that is attached to the airframe

learning.explanation: OLEO STRUT Large aircraft have Oleo-Struts as shock absorbers. An oleo strut consists of an inner metal tube or piston, which is attached to the wheel axle, and which moves up and down in an outer (or upper) metal tube, or cylinder, that is attached to the airframe. The cavity within the strut and piston is filled with gas (usually nitrogen, sometimes air, especially on light aircraft) and oil (usually hydraulic fluid), and is divided into two chambers that communicate through a small orifice. When the aircraft is stationary on the ground, its weight is supported by the compressed gas in the cylinder. During landing, or when the aircraft taxis over bumps, the piston slides up and down. The cavity within the strut and piston is filled with gas (usually nitrogen, sometimes air, especially on light aircraft) and oil (usually hydraulic fluid), and is divided into two chambers that communicate through a small orifice. content.question: How does the emergency landing gear extension usually occur in a modern jet transport aircraft?

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.04.01.02.09: Describe some methods for emergency gear extension including: gravity/free fall; air or nitrogen pressure; manually/mechanically. The emergency extension system lowers the landing gear if the main power system fails. There are numerous ways in which this can be done depending on the size and complexity of the aircraft. A very common way of extending the landing gear in case of emergency is by gravity free fall. Such system allows the landing gear to just drop naturally under the influence of gravity from their retracted and up-locked position to an extended and down-locked position. This is usually a one-time non-reversible operation. In order to activate this system, the aircraft will have an emergency release handle in the cockpit which connects to the gear up locks through a mechanical linkage. When operating the handles, the up-locks will be released, either by mechanical, electrical or pneumatic means. This allows each landing gear to free-fall under its own weight. The weight of the gear will also push the doors open. The gears will remain in the down and locked position because of the mechanical downlocks that come into place automatically. The doors will not retract after this, as there is no available system to do so, so they remain in the down position. There are other systems available for emergency gear extension, such as electrical or pneumatic, but gravity free-fall is so much more common due to its simplicity and lack of potential failure points. It is often aided by pneumatic pressure or a similar system to release the uplocks though.

key_points: Large aircraft have Oleo-Struts as shock absorbers, an example in the picture attached

An oleo strut consists of an inner metal tube or piston, which is attached to the wheel axle, and which moves up and down in an outer (or upper) metal tube, or cylinder, that is attached to the airframe

The cavity within the strut and piston is filled with gas (usually nitrogen, sometimes air, especially on light aircraft) and oil (usually hydraulic fluid), and is divided into two chambers that communicate through a small orifice
learning.explanation: Large aircraft have Oleo-Struts as shock absorbers, an example in the picture attached. An oleo strut consists of an inner metal tube or piston, which is attached to the wheel axle, and which moves up and down in an outer (or upper) metal tube, or cylinder, that is attached to the airframe. The cavity within the strut and piston is filled with gas (usually nitrogen, sometimes air, especially on light aircraft) and oil (usually hydraulic fluid), and is divided into two chambers that communicate through a small orifice. When the aircraft is stationary on the ground, its weight is supported by the compressed gas in the cylinder. During landing, or when the aircraft taxis over bumps, the piston slides up and down. This movement compresses the gas, which acts as a spring, and forces oil through the orifice, which acts as a damper. A tapered rod is used on some designs to change the size of the orifice as the piston moves, providing greater resistance as compression of the strut increases. Additionally, a check valve is sometimes used to uncover additional orifices so that damping during compression is less than during rebound. Oleo struts absorb and dissipate forces by converting and emitting a portion of the accumulated kinetic energy into thermal energy.

Autobrakes have quite a simple logic system, depending on their mode of operation, they use the wheel brakes to slow down the aircraft at a pre-determined, constant rate of deceleration (you can think of it as a constant G-force, or a constant amount of knots lost per second)
This is independent on the weight of the aircraft, and the only thing that can usually hamper this is any lack of traction on the runway (wet, ice, etc
learning.explanation: The auto-brake system can be used for automated braking during landing or during a rejected take-off (RTO). Autobrakes have quite a simple logic system, depending on their mode of operation, they use the wheel brakes to slow down the aircraft at a pre-determined, constant rate of deceleration (you can think of it as a constant G-force, or a constant amount of knots lost per second). This is independent on the weight of the aircraft, and the only thing that can usually hamper this is any lack of traction on the runway (wet, ice, etc.). This standard deceleration rate means that the use of any other deceleration methods will simply take some of the energy away from the brakes, making their job easier. The autobrake system does not care how easy the braking is though, it is very set on gaining a constant rate of deceleration, so applying reverse thrust would not change the rate of deceleration, it would just make the brakes cooler at the end of the landing, as they have worked less hard. The way the autobrake system controls this is by modulating the brake pressure, this is the hydraulic pressure which pushes the brake stators into the rotors. To make the brakes work less hard, the autobrake system reduces the brake pressure.

content.question: How do aircraft parking brakes work?

options.A: They trap hydraulic fluid using a shut-off valve to continuously apply the wheel brakes whilst set.
options.B: They reduce the hydraulic pressure applied to the brakes to that required for parking, which is much less than during landing.
options.C: They operate without hydraulic pressure by mechanically locking the brake pads to the brake disks, therefore providing plenty of braking action whilst the aircraft is parked and hydraulic power is not available.
options.D: They are independent wheel-braking systems which provides hydraulic power for braking action when the aircraft is shut down and parked.

key_points: BRAKES Most vehicle brakes work using hydraulics

On the majority of cars, this means the force you apply to the brake pedal pressurises the brake fluid (hydraulic fluid), and this pressure is used to push a piston (actuator) to force brake pads (stators) into brake discs (rotors) connected to each wheel
The harder you push the pedal, the harder the brake pads contact the discs, the more friction is caused, and the harder you decelerate
learning.explanation: BRAKES Most vehicle brakes work using hydraulics. On the majority of cars, this means the force you apply to the brake pedal pressurises the brake fluid (hydraulic fluid), and this pressure is used to push a piston (actuator) to force brake pads (stators) into brake discs (rotors) connected to each wheel. The harder you push the pedal, the harder the brake pads contact the discs, the more friction is caused, and the harder you decelerate. This is a manual braking system. In light aircraft, the same system is present, but in large aircraft, many thousands of times more braking force is needed, requiring large multi-disk brakes on many more wheels, and your feet are just not able to provide enough force to apply these brakes, no matter how much you go to the gym. This means that the brakes run off the normal hydraulic system, and your feet (or the autobrake - if fitted) are now simply moving a valve to provide more or less hydraulic pressure to the brake actuators. This means that, given large aircraft hydraulic systems can run from 3000 to 5000 psi, these can provide much more braking force, and the power comes from hydraulic pumps, not your feet. PARKING BRAKES Parking brakes operate the same in almost all aircraft, no matter whether you are using manual brakes or a hydraulically assisted system. They use a simple shut-off valve upstream of the brake actuators, and whilst the brakes are being applied, with the pads pushed into the disks, the valve is closed to trap that hydraulic pressure inside the braking system and keep those wheels stopped. The only difference is how much pressure is trapped within the brakes when you set it on. In a light aircraft, you need to push the brakes hard enough when setting the parking brake, or they might not be fully set on. Most large aircraft will not let you make this mistake. If you do leave parking brakes set on for a long time, small leaks within the system may slowly allow the pressure to drop and the brakes might slowly release, or the brakes could go the other way and seize in place, so aircraft should not have them set for too long, and instead chocks and tie-downs should be used to secure aircraft for long periods.

learning.explanation: The auto-brake system can be used for automated braking during landing or during a rejected take-off (RTO). There are several modes the auto-brakes can be in: Off Armed the auto-brake system is ready to be used but there are conditions which have to be met before the auto-brakes start operating. Activated When the system was armed and the necessary conditions have been met the system can be activated in different ways depending on the type of aircraft. Depending on the type of aircraft, 3 to 5 modes of deceleration can be selected. Anti-skid protection is provided during autobrake operation, with inoperative anti-skid the auto-brake system will not operate. The autobrakes will be armed once a deceleration mode has been selected. When the aircraft touches down and the main wheels spin up or by the means of weight on wheels the auto-land system will be activated. The use of reverse thrust is beneficial for stopping distance, but in RTO mode the autobrake will continue to apply maximum braking until disarmed or stopped, irrespective of the deceleration rate. Disarming of the autobrakes will occur by any of the following crew actions: Manual braking Advancing any thrust lever after landing Moving the speed brake lever to down after speed brakes have been deployed on the ground. key_points: EMERGENCY GEAR EXTENSION When you establish that the gear has failed to extend, you should be ready to use whatever type of emergency landing gear system is available in the aeroplane

learning.explanation: EMERGENCY GEAR EXTENSION When you establish that the gear has failed to extend, you should be ready to use whatever type of emergency landing gear system is available in the aeroplane. The most common kinds you will see are the hand crank, hand pump hydraulic, free fall and pressurized nitrogen bottle systems. These systems are designed for emergency gear extension - not retraction. Failure of gear to retract is not an emergency unless it retracts partially and cannot be extended again A hand crank system is often found on aeroplanes with electric gear systems. The crank is employed to turn the gears that operate the actuators manually instead of through the electric motor. If you fly an aeroplane with a hydraulic system, you might use a hydraulic hand pump system to extend the gear when the primary pump fails. You do so by supplying the necessary hydraulic fluid pressure to the actuator cylinders by pumping a hand pump. A freefall system is another method of gear extension used on aeroplanes that have hydraulic gear systems. A control lever is used to open a valve that releases the system pressure. Hydraulic pressure equalizes on both sides of the gear actuators and allow the landing gear to fall into position through the force of gravity and aerodynamic loads. In the pressurized nitrogen bottle system, the nitrogen is not directly used to actuate the landing gear actuators or brake units but, instead, it applies the pressurized nitrogen to move hydraulic fluid to the actuator.

key_points: Anti-skid systems have several functions, but most importantly, they help braking by maintaining an optimum wheel-slip value
Anti-skid system operations are based on tachometers called wheel speed sensors that measure the rotation speed of each wheel
The tachometers are connected to a computer called anti-skid unit (ASU)
learning.explanation: Anti-skid systems have several functions, but most importantly, they help braking by maintaining an optimum wheel-slip value. Anti-skid system operations are based on tachometers called wheel speed sensors that measure the rotation speed of each wheel. The tachometers are connected to a computer called anti-skid unit (ASU). The ASU, by comparing the aircraft ground speed as a reference with precise wheel RPM measurements from tachometers, determines the slip ratio required for optimum braking. When a wheel begins to turn too slowly, brake pressure to this wheel is reduced. Operative anti-skid results in shorter landing distances, but also enhances take-off performance by reducing the accelerate-stop distance. In addition to the main optimised braking function, anti-skid systems offer other functions including: The ASU prevents brake application before touchdown on landing. It will prevent any brake pressure even if brake pedals are pressed before touchdown to allow the stationary wheels to spin-up to speed on contact. Only after spin-up does the ASU allow brake preassure application. The ASU protects against the locking of any wheel during the braking process by avoiding excessive wheel-slip values. The ASU protects against the effects of hydroplanning.

content.question: Consider an aircraft with hydraulically operated brakes and a pneumatically operated emergency braking system, which uses the normal hydraulic brake lines. The aircraft also has an anti-skid system to avoid loss of control and locked wheels during braking. Which of the following statements is correct?

options.A: The anti-skid system will allow for a lower brake temperature when braking hard.
options.B: After using the emergency braking system, the brake pedals will feel softer underfoot.
options.C: Normal braking is available after using the emergency braking system, provided it is operational.
options.D: The emergency braking system will be able to stop in a shorter distance, compared to normal braking.

key_points: Brakes on a car are operated by the driver pushing on the brake pedal, which uses a piston to squeeze hydraulic fluid into the brake lines, which then applies a force on the brake pads, pressing the pads onto the spinning disks to create friction, which gives braking action
This is, of course, a hydraulic system
Hydraulic systems are an excellent way to transfer forces around a vehicle like a car or an aircraft
learning.explanation: Brakes on a car are operated by the driver pushing on the brake pedal, which uses a piston to squeeze hydraulic fluid into the brake lines, which then applies a force on the brake pads, pressing the pads onto the spinning disks to create friction, which gives braking action. This is, of course, a hydraulic system. Hydraulic systems are an excellent way to transfer forces around a vehicle like a car or an aircraft. The main benefit of hydraulics is that the fluid is not compressible, so the force from the brake pedal piston is immediately (and completely) transferred onto the brake pads. This applies to an aircraft as well, as the only difference is that large aircraft brakes use multiple brake pads (stators) and brake disks (rotors), and the braking systems are usually supplemented by the high pressure hydraulic systems that run the rest of the aircraft's systems to gain higher forces than just the pilot's feet can produce. The emergency braking system that is mentioned in this question is to be used in the case of a loss of hydraulic pressure, and extra pressure can be gained by firing a single burst of high pressure gas into the brake lines, which then allow the brakes to be used (not nicely, but better than nothing). Because of the gas (most likely Nitrogen to reduce fire risk) now inside the hydraulic brake lines, the force applied to the pedals is not going to be completely applied to the brakes, as some of the pressure is absorbed by the compression of the gas in the lines. This makes the brakes feel "soft" or "spongy" underfoot, and not nearly as reactive or sensitive. After this is used, the brake lines will have to be bled again to remove the remaining air in the system, and replace it completely with hydraulic fluid. The gas canister will be replaced for emergency brake system use in the future. Mention of the anti-skid system is there to throw you off. Anti-skid improves braking by stopping the wheels from locking up, so actually increases brake temperature (or does not affect it, depending on the conditions).

Learning Objective 021.04.01.02.08: Describe the sequence for emergency gear extension: unlocking; operating; down-locking. All aircraft are different in their emergency gear extension, but on the whole, the concept is the same. The emergency extension system lowers the landing gear if the main power system fails. Many system allows the landing gear to essentially "free fall" under the influence of gravity from their retracted and up-locked position to an extended and down-locked position. This is usually a one-time non-reversable operation. We are assuming that "activating the uplocks" in this sense refers to the mechanical unlocking process of the gear uplocks. This is usually a cable that is pulled from the flight deck by some means, which overcomes the spring tension on the uplock, releasing the gear (and/or gear doors) to extend by gravity. Another consideration is that of the hydraulic system, as usually landing gear is held up during flight by a combination of the mechanical up-locks and the hydraulic pressure being sealed off within the actuators. To release the gear for free fall, the correct sequence of actions would usually be: Release the hydraulic cut-off valve holding the hydraulic pressure (not the selector valves, they are different) Release the locks holding the undercarriage doors (if fitted). Release the mechanical uplocks holding the gear up. One or all of these items may have to be performed manually, using mechanical pulley systems. Compressed gas can also be fired for the purposes of releasing mechanical up-locks.

content.question: After landing, with the autobrake system set to a constant deceleration rate, the use of thrust reversers will...

options.A: decrease the brake pressure.
options.B: change the configuration of the ground spoilers.
options.C: increase the landing distance.
options.D: increase the brake pressure.

key_points: Note: This is quite similar to Q215119, but has a couple of small changes to the question and options, so we have added it separately
The correct answer is the same
The auto-brake system can be used for automated braking during landing or during a rejected take-off (RTO)
learning.explanation: Note: This is quite similar to Q215119, but has a couple of small changes to the question and options, so we have added it separately. The correct answer is the same. The auto-brake system can be used for automated braking during landing or during a rejected take-off (RTO). Autobrakes have quite a simple logic system, depending on their mode of operation, they use the wheel brakes to slow down the aircraft at a pre-determined, constant rate of deceleration (you can think of it as a constant G-force, or a constant amount of knots lost per second). This is independent on the weight of the aircraft, and the only thing that can usually hamper this is any lack of traction on the runway (wet, ice, etc.). This standard deceleration rate means that the use of any other deceleration methods will simply take some of the energy away from the brakes, making their job easier. The autobrake system does not care how easy the braking is though, it is very set on gaining a constant rate of deceleration, so applying reverse thrust would not change the rate of deceleration, it would just make the brakes cooler at the end of the landing, as they have worked less hard. The way the autobrake system controls this is by modulating the brake pressure, this is the hydraulic pressure which pushes the brake stators into the rotors. To make the brakes work less hard, the autobrake system reduces the brake pressure.

Such system allows the landing gear to essentially "free fall" under the influence of gravity from their retracted and up-locked position to an extended and down-locked position. This is usually a one-time non-reversable operation. In order to activate this system, the aircraft will have an emergency release handle in the cockpit which connects to the gear up locks and hydraulic locks through a mechanical linkage. These can be used to allow the gears to free-fall under their own weight. The weight of the gears will push the doors open. The gears will remain in the down and locked position by mechanical means, these down-locks work automatically and mechanically once the gear reaches the down position. Another consideration is that of the hydraulic system, as usually landing gear is held up during flight by a combination of the mechanical up-locks and the hydraulic pressure being sealed off within the actuators. To release the gear for free fall, the correct sequence of actions would usually be: Release the hydraulic cut-off valve holding the hydraulic pressure. Release the locks holding the undercarriage doors (if fitted). Release the mechanical uplocks holding the gear up. One or all of these items may have to be performed manually, using mechanical pulley systems. Compressed gas can also be fired for the purposes of releasing mechanical up-locks.

Automatic Braking (Autobrake) systems offer two modes of operation: Landing Mode Rejected Take-Off (RTO) Mode In Landing Mode (1, 2, 3, MAX), calibrated pressure is automatically applied to the brakes upon touchdown, regardless of pilot input. This system adjusts brake pressure to counteract aircraft drag, thrust reversers, and spoilers, maintaining the chosen deceleration level for modes 1, 2 and 3 and maximum braking for MAX. The Rejected Take-Off (RTO) setting instructs the autobrake system to apply full pressure to the wheel brakes, bringing the aircraft to a stop. Activation of RTO mode occurs when a rejected takeoff is initiated by the pilot at a groundspeed exceeding 88 knots. content.question: On landing gear, most stress is carried by a torsion link...

options.A: on the inner cylinder of the main oleo leg during a small radius turn.
options.B: on the outer cylinder of the main oleo leg during a small radius turn.
options.C: on the inner cylinder of the main oleo leg during a large radius turn.
options.D: between the inner and outer cylinder of the main oleo leg during a small radius turn.

key_points: The torsion link on landing gear is the component shown in the annex above which stops the gear twisting round under load
Without the torsion link, there would be no directional control over the landing gear, and it would be free to spin around
With the wheel connected to the inner cylinder of the oleo, and the aircraft connected to the outer cylinder, there would be no mechanical connection between the two, only a little friction
learning.explanation: The torsion link on landing gear is the component shown in the annex above which stops the gear twisting round under load. Without the torsion link, there would be no directional control over the landing gear, and it would be free to spin around. With the wheel connected to the inner cylinder of the oleo, and the aircraft connected to the outer cylinder, there would be no mechanical connection between the two, only a little friction. The torsion link provides that mechanical connection between the inner and the outer cylinder (the wheel and the aircraft) in only one direction, preventing sideways movement, whilst still allowing shock absorption by the oleo in the up and down direction, as it moves in and out due to its "scissor link" design. The torsion link does carry lots of stress, therefore, when the aircraft wants to turn and the wheel does not. For example, a main wheel (without steering capability) going round a tight corner where the aircraft wants to twist sideways but the wheel does not. Even more than this, a bogie beam with multiple attached landing gear going round a similarly small corner, would have huge amounts of stress through the torsion link.

learning.explanation: Anti-skid is the system that stops our wheels "locking up" in wet or slippery runway conditions, as that would only damage our tyres, remove our controllability and provide a reduced braking performance. Instead, we want our tyres to be going just slightly slower than our groundspeed, to provide the greatest braking efficiency, especially in low traction conditions, and this is what anti-skid does. The defects which may make the cover unserviceable are: Cuts. Cuts in the tyre cover penetrating to the cords render the tyre unserviceable and must be repaired. content.question: Which of these statements about an auto-brake system is correct?

options.A: When a low auto-brake setting is used during landing use of reverse will not influence the brake temperature
options.B: On most aeroplanes the auto-brake system provides the capability to select a fixed landing distance
options.C: The achievable deceleration levels of full manual braking and the auto-brake RTO mode are the same
options.D: When using manual braking during taxiing, the auto-brake system will disarm

key_points: “When a low auto-brake setting is used during landing use of reverse will not influence the brake temperature
” INCORRECT

It obviously will, the autobrake varies the brake pressure to achieve a constant deceleration, so therefore, if you’re using thrust reversers, some of that energy (to dissipate speed to achieve a certain deceleration rate) is being supplied by the use of thrust reversers – therefore, they reduce the amount of brake pressure which has to be applied on the brakes => brake temperature will reduce as a result of using reversers
learning.explanation: “When a low auto-brake setting is used during landing use of reverse will not influence the brake temperature.” INCORRECT. It obviously will, the autobrake varies the brake pressure to achieve a constant deceleration, so therefore, if you’re using thrust reversers, some of that energy (to dissipate speed to achieve a certain deceleration rate) is being supplied by the use of thrust reversers – therefore, they reduce the amount of brake pressure which has to be applied on the brakes => brake temperature will reduce as a result of using reversers. “When using manual braking during taxiing, the auto-brake system will disarm” INCORRECT. During taxi we only ever use manual braking, therefore, the reference to the use of autobrake during taxi does not make sense. “On most aeroplanes the auto-brake system provides the capability to select a fixed landing distance” INCORRECT. Only a few aircraft do that, I believe the A350 and A380 – where you can actually go into the computer and say “this is the runway we are landing on, and I actually want to vacate at this specific exit” because it has the runway in the database and all the different taxiways off the runway and, therefore, you can use the autobrake and select to vacate at a certain exit and it will make sure you have the right speed to vacate => but that is not the majority of the aeroplanes. Ultimately, it is not very practical because there are a lot of different factors. On most aircrafts, it just provides a fixed deceleration rate but not a fixed landing distance (seen it is subjected to wind as well). You can never say it will precisely take this xxx amount of distance. Hopefully, this makes sense. “The achievable deceleration levels of full manual braking and the auto-brake RTO mode are the same” CORRECT. So if you press on the pedals as hard as you possibly can, it’s going to give you a maximum deceleration rate and it will also ensure that the wheels don’t lock up – which is exactly the same as autobrake max/RTO. If you look at the pushbutton, it says MAX - maximum amount of braking so it is the same as if you push on the pedals as hard as you can. (Don’t forget that you’ve got antiskid which works in conjunction with autobrake as well) => Fundamentally, if autobrake is in rejected take off RTO mode and you reject the take off => then the braking will be maximum possible braking, which is exactly the same as if you press on the pedals maximum. But the thing with the autobrake is that, as soon as the pilot decides to reject the take off and closes the thrust levers, then the maximum braking pressure gets applied immediately. Whereas, if you were to take off without autobrake, and then decided to abort the take-off, you’d first think about “right, I have got to close the thrust levers” and then you’ve got to think to press on the brake pedals => so, there’s obviously an element of delay in that. And that is why the stopping distance in the event of a manual rejected take off would be greater, even though the brake pressure on the brakes, would be exactly the same under both circumstances. content.question: What happens if the grooves or tread of an aircraft tyre are worn?

options.A: The tyre can be used on the nose wheel only.
options.B: The tyre can never be repaired or retreaded.
options.C: The tyre can be retreaded several times.
options.D: The tyre can be retreaded once.

key_points: The tread of an airplane tire will wear out long before its casing (everything other than the tread)
This means that the tire casing remains entirely capable of safely holding the inflation pressure to support the load of the airplane long after the tread has worn away
All the tire needs is a new tread
learning.explanation: The tread of an airplane tire will wear out long before its casing (everything other than the tread). This means that the tire casing remains entirely capable of safely holding the inflation pressure to support the load of the airplane long after the tread has worn away. All the tire needs is a new tread. Airplane tires can be expensive: there is no logical reason to scrap a tire for an aircraft when it can be safely and economically reconditioned with a new tread. This is why retreading has been standard practice in the aviation industry for decades. The maximum retread level for the part number is set only after extensive testing and analysis. Some airplane tyres can be safely retreaded up to seven or more times, but there is always a limit and the limit is always set with an abundance of caution. The retread process is easy to understand. A worn tyre is removed from an aircraft. It is sent back to a retreading firm, often a manufacturer of airplane tires. When the firm receives a tire for retreading it is carefully inspected to ensure that it is safe and economical to retread. The tyre is scrapped if technicians consider there to be doubt about its airworthiness.

All modern aircraft now use disc brakes as their means of slowing down or stopping. Steel and carbon emerge as the principal constituents used in the fabrication of these brake components, each offering unique benefits. Conventional brake discs are typically fashioned from steel, boasting durability, cost-efficiency, and consistent braking performance. Carbon is also harnessed in brake assembly due to its superior heat absorption and dissipation characteristics. Carbon brakes exhibit notably lighter weight compared to their steel counterparts. There are numerous ways in which this is done depending on the size and complexity of the aircraft
A means of extending the landing gear and locking it in the down position in case of emergency is by gravity free fall
learning.explanation: The emergency extension system lowers the landing gear if the main power system fails. There are numerous ways in which this is done depending on the size and complexity of the aircraft. A means of extending the landing gear and locking it in the down position in case of emergency is by gravity free fall. Such system allows the landing gear to essentially "free fall" under the influence of gravity from their retracted and up-locked position to an extended and down-locked position. This is usually a one-time non-revisable operation. In order to activate this system, the aircraft will have an emergency release handle in the cockpit which connects to the gear up locks through a mechanical linkage. When operating the handles, the up-locks will be released (unlocked), either either by mechanic or electronic means. This allows the gears to free-fall under their own weight. The weight of the gears will push the doors open. The gears will remain in the down and locked position by mechanical means.

key_points: EMERGENCY GEAR EXTENSION When you establish that the gear has failed to extend, you should be ready to use whatever type of emergency landing gear system is available in the aeroplane
The most common kinds you will see are the hand crank, hand pump hydraulic, free fall and pressurized nitrogen bottle systems
These systems are designed for emergency gear extension - not retraction
learning.explanation: EMERGENCY GEAR EXTENSION When you establish that the gear has failed to extend, you should be ready to use whatever type of emergency landing gear system is available in the aeroplane. The most common kinds you will see are the hand crank, hand pump hydraulic, free fall and pressurized nitrogen bottle systems. These systems are designed for emergency gear extension - not retraction. Failure of gear to retract is not an emergency unless it retracts partially and cannot be extended again In the pressurized nitrogen bottle system, the emergency gear extension system is activated by pulling the red EMER GEAR CONTROL handle, allowing a one shot extension of the landing gear. Once activated, nitrogen pressure from the emergency air bottle is released through a shuttle valve to the extend side of the landing gear actuators, extending the gear towards the down and locked position. Once the gear has fully extended, the down locks inside the actuators will engage and the down and locked micro switches will be energised causing the three green down and locked lights to illuminate. Once the emergency gear extension procedure has been used, subsequent retraction of the landing gear cannot be achieved. Ground servicing of the system is required prior to normal use of the system.

content.question:
Which of the following statements about an anti-skid system are correct/incorrect?
(1) The anti-skid computer compares wheel speed to aeroplane reference speed to provide a slip ratio for maximum braking performance
(2) If a pilot is careful when braking manually, he/she will be able to achieve the same braking efficiency as if braking with anti-skid

options.A: (1) is incorrect; (2) is incorrect.
options.B: (1) is correct; (2) is incorrect.
options.C: (1) is correct; (2) is correct.
options.D: (1) is incorrect; (2) is correct.

key_points: ANTI-SKID SYSTEM Large aircraft with power brakes require anti-skid systems
It is not possible to immediately ascertain in the flight deck when a wheel stops rotating and begins to skid, especially in aircrafts with multiple-wheel main landing gear assemblies
A skid not corrected can quickly lead to a tire blowout, possible damage to the aircraft, and control of the aircraft may be lost
learning.explanation: ANTI-SKID SYSTEM Large aircraft with power brakes require anti-skid systems. It is not possible to immediately ascertain in the flight deck when a wheel stops rotating and begins to skid, especially in aircrafts with multiple-wheel main landing gear assemblies. A skid not corrected can quickly lead to a tire blowout, possible damage to the aircraft, and control of the aircraft may be lost. One of the important issues to realize is that the anti-skid system greatly increases the effectiveness of braking. In very simplified terms, the anti-skid system provides the greatest possible brake pressure while not allowing the wheels to lock due to an excessive brake pressure being applied. Without the anti-skid system (manual braking) the braking effectiveness is reduced. "The anti-skid computer compares wheel speed to aeroplane reference speed to provide a slip ratio for maximum braking performance." Correct. These systems use a computer that, during ground movement when braking, which constantly compares the measured values of individual wheels (actual rotational speed) with the desired optimum parameters, providing a slip ratio for maximum braking performance. "If a pilot is careful when braking manually, he/she will be able to achieve the same braking efficiency as if braking with anti-skid." Incorrect. A pilot will never reach the same performance as a properly functioning anti-skid system. The anti-skid system senses when a brake starts to skid and will reduce braking pressure to avoid the wheels from skidding, a pilot won’t come close to the same performance.

So, when you select “low” autobrake mode in flight, on the landing roll out – it varies the brake pressure to achieve that deceleration rate always. If it is a contaminated runway and it can’t achieve that rate, fundamentally, it will just achieve what it can achieve. “When a low auto-brake setting is used during landing use of reverse will not influence the brake temperature.” INCORRECT. It obviously will, the autobrake varies the brake pressure to achieve a constant deceleration, so therefore, if you’re using thrust reversers, some of that energy (to dissipate speed to achieve a certain deceleration rate) is being supplied by the use of thrust reversers – therefore, they reduce the amount of brake pressure which has to be applied on the brakes => brake temperature will reduce as a result of using reversers. “When the auto-brake system is inoperative, in general take-off is not allowed, because maximum manual braking does not achieve the same deceleration as the auto-brake system in the RTO mode.” INCORRECT. I would say that this is a bit type specific. However, saying that the maximum manual braking does not achieve the same deceleration as the auto-brake system in RTO IS NOT CORRECT. => Fundamentally, if autobrake is in rejected take off RTO mode and you reject the take off => then the braking will be maximum possible braking, which is exactly the same as if you press on the pedals maximum. content.question: Landing gear torsion links are used to…

options.A: control the rate of oleo strut recoil.
options.B: prevent rotation of the landing gear piston in the oleo strut.
options.C: absorb the lateral stresses to which the gear is subjected.
options.D: prevent extension of the oleo strut when the gear is retracted.

key_points: The function of a torsion link, or torque link, is to avoid movement of the inner cylinder within the outer cylinder
So when the aircraft is moving forward without turning there will not be much force on the torsion link
When the aircraft touches down with a strong cross-wind there might be some forces on the torque link, but most of the movement will be forward in line with the direction of the aircraft
learning.explanation: The function of a torsion link, or torque link, is to avoid movement of the inner cylinder within the outer cylinder. So when the aircraft is moving forward without turning there will not be much force on the torsion link. When the aircraft touches down with a strong cross-wind there might be some forces on the torque link, but most of the movement will be forward in line with the direction of the aircraft. When the aircraft is turning on the ground and especially turns with a small radius, the wheels will want to move forward whilst the aircraft is turning, this will cause a lot of load on the torsion link.

content.question: Light aircraft and helicopters may equipped with a “blowdown” emergency gear extension system for use in case of hydraulic failure. Which gasses are used for this purpose, and how are the gasses sent to the actuators?

options.A: Nitrogen or compressed air, which is routed through a manually operated shuttle valve.
options.B: Helium or nitrogen, which is routed to parallel actuators on the landing gear.
options.C: Nitrogen or compressed air, which is routed to parallel actuators on the landing gear.
options.D: Helium or carbon dioxide, which is routed through a manually operated shuttle valve.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.04.01.02.09: Describe some methods for emergency gear extension including: gravity/free fall; air or nitrogen pressure; manually/mechanically. The emergency extension system lowers the landing gear if the main hydraulic system fails. There are numerous ways in which this can be done depending on the size and complexity of the aircraft. A very common way of extending the landing gear in case of emergency is by gravity free fall. This is common for large aircraft as their gear are very heavy. Unfortunately, in light aircraft, the gear components are not as heavy, so can get jammed in place with not very much force. This includes the "blowdown" system using compressed gasses. The action of emergency gear extension is often a one-way movement, and cannot be reversed. In order to activate the system, the aircraft will have an emergency release handle in the cockpit which connects to the gear up locks through one of the following systems. When operating the handles, the up-locks will be released, either by mechanical, electrical or pneumatic means. This allows each landing gear to free-fall under its own weight. Some emergency extension systems (as mentioned above) use bottles of compressed air or compressed nitrogen to extend the gear, thereby overcoming any small jams that would otherwise keep the gear in the up position. Nitrogen is better as it is non-flammable, and air contains oxygen, which will feed a potential fire. Compressed air is easier (and cheaper) to bottle though. The gear will remain in the down and locked position because of the mechanical down locks that come into place automatically. The doors will not retract after this, as there is no available system to do so, so they remain in the down position. The shuttle valve mentioned in this question is a way to feed one actuator with two different pressure sources. When one pressure source loses pressure, the piston can slide across from blocking the emergency source to blocking the usual source, allowing out the emergency pressure to feed the actuator. This can be automatic or manually controlled. A diagram of the shuttle valve is shown in the annex above.

options.B: Increased on the slower turning wheels.
options.C: Decreased on the slower turning wheels.
options.D: Decreased on the faster turning wheels.

key_points: Anti-skid systems have several functions, but most importantly, they help braking by maintaining an optimum wheel-slip value
Anti-skid system operations are based on tachometers called wheel speed sensors that measure the rotation speed of each wheel
The tachometers are connected to a computer called anti-skid unit (ASU)
learning.explanation: Anti-skid systems have several functions, but most importantly, they help braking by maintaining an optimum wheel-slip value. Anti-skid system operations are based on tachometers called wheel speed sensors that measure the rotation speed of each wheel. The tachometers are connected to a computer called anti-skid unit (ASU). The ASU, by comparing the aircraft ground speed as a reference with precise wheel RPM measurements from tachometers, determines the slip ratio required for optimum braking. When a wheel begins to turn too slowly, brake pressure to this wheel is reduced. Operative anti-skid results in shorter landing distances, but also enhances take-off performance by reducing the accelerate-stop distance.

content.question: The retraction mechanism of the landing gear is...

options.A: an active system and operated with the engine pump.
options.B: an active system and operated with the pressure pump.
options.C: a passive system and operated with the engine pump.
options.D: a passive system and operated with the pressure pump.

key_points: In all aircraft, the landing gear is an active system, in that it requires a power source to function, in this case, it is hydraulic pressure that powers it
The landing gear in some aircraft can be lowered passively (gravity extension), but cannot be raised passively
The power for the hydraulic system in all large aircraft comes from engine driven pumps
learning.explanation: In all aircraft, the landing gear is an active system, in that it requires a power source to function, in this case, it is hydraulic pressure that powers it. The landing gear in some aircraft can be lowered passively (gravity extension), but cannot be raised passively. The power for the hydraulic system in all large aircraft comes from engine driven pumps. These pumps are driven by the auxiliary gearbox connected to one of the engine shafts. Electric hydraulic pumps are also present, and provide the same amount of pressure, but have a much lower displacement as they are much smaller, weaker pumps. Therefore, when landing gear is raised, the vast majority of the load is placed on the engine driven pumps, and is therefore fed by power from the auxiliary gearbox.

However, if the runway is contaminated and has slippery spots, brakes might be released in order to prevent skidding. Brake release will consequently reduce deceleration rate. The autobrake cannot control the aircraft laterally, so it would be really bad if the wheels locked up (on a wet runway without anti-skid), and therefore it cannot be used at all if anti-skid is not available. The sidewall is the bit on the side of the tyre that connects the tread to the "bead", which is fitted to the wheel rim, it is a very vulnerable section of the tyre, with less protection. Objects embedded in the tyre cause obvious damage to the structural integrity, which could lead to blow outs or slow punctures, both of which are very bad for any ground movements, take off and landing. key_points: Anti-skid systems have several functions, but most importantly, they help braking by maintaining an optimum wheel-slip value

The ASU, by comparing the aircraft ground speed as a reference with precise wheel RPM measurements from tachometers, determines the slip ratio required for optimum braking. Operative anti-skid results in shorter landing distances, but also enhances take-off performance by reducing the accelerate-stop distance.

content.question:
Which of the following is correct about multi-disc steel brakes as opposed to single disc carbon brakes?
1. Multiple small applications is best
2. Small numbers of strong applications is best
3. They operate best at a higher brake temperature
4. They operate best at a lower brake temperature
5. They have higher braking strength
6. They have lower braking strength

options.A: 1, 3 and 4
options.B: 2, 4 and 6
options.C: 1, 4 and 5
options.D: 1, 3 and 5

key_points: Important Note: This question is slightly modified from the original feedback received

The original feedback did not compare the multi-disk steel brakes to anything, so was very difficult to answer as the options require comparison to other brakes, however, it was clear from the options that sometimes the examiner was asking about the multi-disk vs single disk element, and sometimes about steel brakes vs carbon brakes
Therefore, We chose to compare them to single disc carbon brakes
learning.explanation: Important Note: This question is slightly modified from the original feedback received. The original feedback did not compare the multi-disk steel brakes to anything, so was very difficult to answer as the options require comparison to other brakes, however, it was clear from the options that sometimes the examiner was asking about the multi-disk vs single disk element, and sometimes about steel brakes vs carbon brakes. Therefore, We chose to compare them to single disc carbon brakes. The only difference in answer can occur if they compare multi-disc steel brakes to multi-disc carbon brakes directly, in which case the carbon brakes have higher braking strength usually. Please let us know what was actually on the exam if you do see this, and we can adjust it as necessary, thanks! The two usual materials for aircraft brakes are steel and carbon. They vary somewhat in characteristics, and in cost. Steel brakes are usually much cheaper than carbon brakes. Steel brakes perform better at lower temperatures, and when they get hot, suffer from brake fade, where the rotors do not apply as much traction onto the stators due to the intense heat. Carbon brakes, however, have a much hotter operating window. In fact, carbon brakes are not very effective at low temperatures, so need to have some heat in them already, to be able to produce the peak braking force. This is why the two types should be treated differently. Steel brakes should be kept cool, by using them many times, but softly with gaps to allow them to cool. Carbon brakes, on the other hand, should be applied firmly all at once when possible, to allow them to work in their operating window as much as possible, and because their wear is more linked to amount of applications, rather than total heat input. In most transport aircraft, the brakes need to absorb vast amounts of heat during landings, rejected take-offs and taxiing, much more than could be absorbed by a single disk and pair of brake pads. Therefore, their brakes are usually made up of multiple (spinning) brake discs separated by multiple (static) rings of brake pads. These multiple rings of stators and rotors can provide much stronger braking and absorb far more heat than a single disc and pair of pads alone, steel or carbon.
