key_points: Pre-flight inspections must confirm whether the condition of the tyre is suitable for operation
Tyre covers must be examined for cuts, bulges, embedded stones, metal or glass, signs of wear, creep, local sponginess, etc
Operation with damaged tyres may result in tyre burst that can cause further damage to the airframe or lead to a ground collision/runway excursion
learning.explanation: Pre-flight inspections must confirm whether the condition of the tyre is suitable for operation. Tyre covers must be examined for cuts, bulges, embedded stones, metal or glass, signs of wear, creep, local sponginess, etc. Operation with damaged tyres may result in tyre burst that can cause further damage to the airframe or lead to a ground collision/runway excursion. The defects which may make the cover unserviceable are: Cuts. Cuts in the tyre cover penetrating to the cords render the tyre unserviceable and must be repaired. Bulges. These may indicate partial failure of the casing, if the casing has failed. Foreign Bodies. Embedded stones, metal, glass etc. These must NOT be removed but reported to maintenance staff. Wear. Pattern tread covers worn to the base of the marker grooves or marker tie bars for 25% of the tyre circumference, or plain tread covers worn to the casing fabric, must not be used. Creep. Movement of the tyre round the wheel must not exceed 1 in for tyres of up to 24 in outside diameter and 1 1⁄2 in for tyres over 24 in outside diameter. If these limits are exceeded, the tyre must be removed from the wheel and the tube examined for signs of tearing at the valve. A check of the ply/speed rating, tread depth measurement, and tyre pressure measurement is usually the job of an engineer, and is not required before every single flight, however checking tyre creep and embedded objects are quick enough, and important enough tasks to require a check of every tyre before flight.

content.question:
The autobrake system is deactivated:
1) below a preset minimum speed
2) when reverse thrust is activated

options.B: 1) is correct, 2) is incorrect
options.C: 1) is correct, 2) is correct

key_points: The autobrake system is deactivated: Statement 1: below a preset minimum speed
Incorrect, the autobrake will not deactivate below a certain speed
Statement 2: when reverse thrust is activated
learning.explanation: The autobrake system is deactivated: Statement 1: below a preset minimum speed. Incorrect, the autobrake will not deactivate below a certain speed. Statement 2: when reverse thrust is activated. Incorrect, the autobrake remains active also when reverse thrust is activated. The auto-brake system can be used for automated braking during landing or during a rejected take-off (RTO). There are several modes the auto-brakes can be in: Off Armed the auto-brake system is ready to be used but there are conditions which have to be met before the auto-brakes start operating. Activated When the system was armed and the necessary conditions have been met the system can be activated in different ways depending on the type of aircraft. The auto-brake system is not useable when the alternate braking system is in use. Depending on the type of aircraft, 3 to 5 modes of deceleration can be selected. Anti-skid protection is provided during autobrake operation, with inoperative anti-skid the auto-brake system will not operate. The autobrakes will be armed once a deceleration mode has been selected. When the aircraft touches down and the main wheels spin up or by the means of weight on wheels the auto-land system will be activated. The auto-land system continues to brake until a complete stop or until the auto-brakes are disarmed. The selected deceleration mode will give a standard deceleration rate independent on the weight of the aircraft for a dry runway. Disarming of the autobrakes will occur by any of the following crew actions: Manual braking Advancing any thrust lever after landing Moving the speed brake lever to down after speed brakes have been deployed on the ground. Moving the autobrake selector to Disarm or Off. When RTO is selected, the maximum brake pressure will be applied when all thrust levers a closed above a ground speed of 85 knots. So below this 85 knots the autobrakes are not activated.

key_points: Note: This is very similar to Q218296, but we have had a couple of reports from UK exams of slight differences in wording
The answer is quite similar

Please let us know if you see either in the exam, and whatever you can remember about them, thank you! FLY-BY-WIRE In a Fly-By-Wire aircraft, the pilot inputs commands via a sidestick or yoke to a computer
learning.explanation: Note: This is very similar to Q218296, but we have had a couple of reports from UK exams of slight differences in wording. The answer is quite similar. Please let us know if you see either in the exam, and whatever you can remember about them, thank you! FLY-BY-WIRE In a Fly-By-Wire aircraft, the pilot inputs commands via a sidestick or yoke to a computer. The computer then processes these inputs and sends corresponding electrical signals to the servo valve which in turn controls the movement of a hydraulic actuator, moving the flight control surface. There are numerous advantages to fly by wire systems, including weight savings and safety features that can be incorporated into the computer software. FBW enables highly reliable flight envelope protection systems which significantly enhances safety. For instance, on the Airbus, the flight mode of Normal Law provides five types of protection: pitch attitude, load factor limitations, high speed, high-AoA and bank angle. In addition, Low Speed Protection is available in certain phases of flight. The bank angle protection system on a FBW aircraft can change the effect of control inputs to make it harder to maintain a bank angle that is outside of limits. For instance, in the Airbus A320, above 33°, force is needed to maintain the bank angle. The aircraft will not allow bank angles past 67° in normal law. In this question the bank angle protections have activated improperly at 30° AoB, so more force will be required to maintain or increase the angle of bank.

content.question: In a fully manual flight control system, the pilot must exert sufficient force to...

options.A: separate each pilot`s yaw control in the case of a jam.
options.B: overcome the aerodynamic loads felt at the control surface.
options.C: activate the artificial feel system.
options.D: allow pressure to build up in the flight control actuators.

key_points: As a fully manual flight control system is reversible the pilot feels all forces acting on the control surfaces in the controls
So the pilot must be able to exert sufficient force to overcome the aerodynamic loads on the control surfaces
Primary flight controls Are controls which movement causes a rotation about one of the three axes of the aircraft, causing a change in the aircraft’s flightpath or attitude
learning.explanation: As a fully manual flight control system is reversible the pilot feels all forces acting on the control surfaces in the controls. So the pilot must be able to exert sufficient force to overcome the aerodynamic loads on the control surfaces. Primary flight controls Are controls which movement causes a rotation about one of the three axes of the aircraft, causing a change in the aircraft’s flightpath or attitude. The elevator, rudder and ailerons are considered to be the primary flight controls. The primary flight controls in a manually controlled system are reversible. This means that a force applied to the controls is a force which moves the control surface, and also a force which moves the control surface will move the pilot’s controls. This means that the air pressure on the control surface can be felt in the pilot’s controls. When the flight controls are fully power operated this is not the case and is called irreversible. This means that if there is a force moving the control surface this will not move the control columns, and there will be no natural feel on the controls. Because of this there will need to be an artificial feel unit installed in a fully powered or irreversible control system. This artificial feel unit should apply force to the cockpit controls in proportion to the control deflection and in proportion to the aircraft’s speed. This artificial feel system will also work with a trim system, but this works different than a normal trim surface does. A movement of the trimwheel will result in a movement of the electric trim actuator, and so the control surface, but not in the movement of the control column (this is for elevator control). It is different for aileron and rudder trim. Elevator trim: zero force position of the control column does not change (control column/horn/stick does not move) Aileron trim: zero force position changes (control wheel turns in the direction of the trim) Rudder trim: zero force position changes (pedals move in the direction of the trim)

learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.05.02.01.02: List the following secondary flight control surfaces: lift-augmentation devices (flaps and slats); speed brakes; flight and ground spoilers; trimming devices such as trim tabs, trimmable horizontal stabiliser. Secondary flight controls are surfaces which aid the characteristics of the aircraft and the pilots, but are not the primary control surfaces. content.question: What happens to the flight envelope protection if your aircraft system turns to the Alternate mode?

options.A: degraded.
options.B: fully maintained.
options.C: lost.
options.D: upgraded.

key_points: EASA examinations use the Airbus A320 family as an example of Fly-By-Wire controlled aircraft
Normal law is the system mode which is active throughout the flight and is terminated when system failures occur that prevent its use
The highest reduced mode of operation in Airbus FBW systems is the Alternate Law, which provides most features of normal law
learning.explanation: EASA examinations use the Airbus A320 family as an example of Fly-By-Wire controlled aircraft. Normal law is the system mode which is active throughout the flight and is terminated when system failures occur that prevent its use. The highest reduced mode of operation in Airbus FBW systems is the Alternate Law, which provides most features of normal law. Some features such as automatic stall protection are lost and replaced by conventional warnings for the pilots to manually correct the condition. This means that flight envelope protection is degraded as avionics no longer limit the pilot input to avoid stall. Should failure conditions prevent operation in Alternate Law, an even more basic Direct Law is available. Autopilot functions are lost, along with flight envelope protection. As a last emergency means of operation, Mechanical Backup is provided to maintain level flight only for the limited period of flight control computer reset following a complete loss of power. As we have stated above, a system degradation results in a loss of protection features, so the required alertness of the crew increases and leads to a higher workload.

The use of more than 1 actuator per control surface

There can be two systems powering the same surface, where one is a back-up for the other and can be used with the use of clutches on the same control run. The use of more than 1 actuator per control surface. The use of multiple control surfaces per axis, for example, spoilers can also be used for lateral control when the ailerons would fail.

key_points: Flaps There are numerous types of flap designs which increase lift and drag in varying amounts

learning.explanation: Flaps There are numerous types of flap designs which increase lift and drag in varying amounts. For light aircraft the most popular type is the plain or camber flap. For large transport aircraft the most used is the slotted Fowler flaps. (see different types in the image in the annex) In the cockpit there will be a selector where the pilot selects the desired flap setting, the input from this selector will be the input for the slat/flap control computers which control, test and monitor the operation of the flaps and slats. This computer’s output will be the input for an electrically controlled hydro-mechanical unit, a hydraulic motor, which drive the transmission which moves the flaps. The position of the flaps is measured with sensors and is indicated in the cockpit. The flaps are protected against asymmetric operation, runaway and over speed. The flap load relief system, or load limiter will retract the flaps to an intermediate position when the airspeed exceeds a predetermined speed. Once the speed has decreased below this speed, the flaps will be automatically returned to the selected flap setting. If the main hydraulic system fails, the emergency operation might be via an alternate hydraulic system or an electric motor which operates the same gear train as the normal operating system.

Thankfully, this topic is not particularly complicated so the more questions about this, the better
In a fly-by-wire system such as the Airbus A320, amongst others, both pilots have a sidestick which is a major input into the fly-by-wire control system
learning.explanation: Note: There are lots of questions on the bank about this, and some very similar looking ones to this, but different feedback has indicated different options, so we will continue to add as many new questions as we think are in the real exams. Thankfully, this topic is not particularly complicated so the more questions about this, the better. In a fly-by-wire system such as the Airbus A320, amongst others, both pilots have a sidestick which is a major input into the fly-by-wire control system. As these sidesticks are not mechanically linked like other, there needs to be a way for both pilots to make inputs at once. The standard system for this is for both inputs to be "algebraically summed" together, which is a complex way of saying that both sticks get an input into the control system. This is called dual input. In case that it occurs, an aural warning “DUAL INPUT” and a flashing warning light in sight of each pilot is provided. To allow one pilot to take over controls from the other, which might be necessary in case of incapacitation, etc., a red take-over button is installed on each sidestick that disables the stick on the other side when held. This button works as an autopilot disconnect when pushed once, but when it is pushed and held, it removes the other pilot's inputs from the system, and after 40 seconds of holding (A320 specific) the other pilot is "locked out" from inputs until they push their own priority button. When this condition occurs, an aural warning is provided “PRIORITY LEFT/RIGHT”, indicating the active sidestick.

content.question: On an aircraft equipped with a Fly-By-Wire control system, the pilot…

options.A: never override soft and hard protections.
options.B: can override hard protections only.
options.C: can override soft protections only.
options.D: can override soft and hard protections.

key_points: FLY-BY-WIRE (FBW) Fly-By-Wire aeroplanes function differently to conventional aeroplanes in that the pilot or autopilot input is via a flight control computer
The computer translates this input into an aircraft attitude using all three axes, which it will then maintain until another input is made
CONTROL LAWS - NORMAL LAW The Fly-By-Wire system was designed and certified to render the new generation of aircraft even more safe, cost effective, and pleasant to fly
learning.explanation: FLY-BY-WIRE (FBW) Fly-By-Wire aeroplanes function differently to conventional aeroplanes in that the pilot or autopilot input is via a flight control computer. The computer translates this input into an aircraft attitude using all three axes, which it will then maintain until another input is made. CONTROL LAWS - NORMAL LAW The Fly-By-Wire system was designed and certified to render the new generation of aircraft even more safe, cost effective, and pleasant to fly. Flight control surfaces are all : ‐ Electrically-controlled ‐ Hydraulically-actuated. Computers interpret pilot input and move the flight control surfaces, as necessary, to follow their orders. However, when in normal law, regardless of the pilot’s input, the computers will prevent excessive manoeuvres and exceedance of the safe envelope in pitch and roll axis. One of the PF's primary tasks is to maintain the aircraft within the limits of the normal flight envelope. Some circumstances, due to extreme situations or aircraft mishandling, may provoke the violation of these limits. Protections are intended to: - Provide maximum authority to the PF to consistently achieve the best possible aircraft performance in extreme conditions - Reduce the risks of over-controlling, or over-stressing the aircraft - Provide PF with an instinctive and immediate procedure to ensure that the PF achieves the best possible result. The normal law protects the aircraft throughout the flight envelope, as follows: ‐ load factor limitation ‐ pitch attitude protection ‐ high-speed protection. - bank angle protection ‐ high-angle-of-attack (AoA) protection One of the hard protections on the Airbus system, in normal law, is the stall protection. Without flight crew input, the F/CTL computers maintain the AoA equal to a defined value. The AoA can be further increased by flight crew input, up to a maximum value. The AoA will not exceed that maximum value, even if the flight crew gently pulls the sidestick all the way back. CONTROL LAWS - RECONFIGURATION LAWS Depending on the failures occurring to the flight control system, or on its peripherals, there are 3 levels of reconfiguration : ‐ Alternate law (There are two levels of alternate law : with and without reduced protections.) ‐ Direct law ‐ Mechanical ALTERNATE LAW - REDUCED PROTECTIONS - Load Factor Limitation - Pitch Attitude Protection - Low Speed Stability (Soft protection) An artificial low speed stability replaces the normal angle-of-attack protection. A gentle progressive nose down signal is introduced, that tends to keep the speed from falling below these values. The flight crew can override this demand. In addition, stall warnings are activated at an appropriate margin from the stall condition. - High Speed Stability (Soft protection) Above VMO or MMO, a nose up demand is introduced to avoid an excessive increase in speed. The flight crew can override this demand. In addition, the aural overspeed warning remains available.

“They decrease the control force generated by the cables or pushrods” Is incorrect because a valve is nothing more than a “switch” and it has nothing to do with decreasing control forces
“They act on the actuator of the control surface” Is correct, as these valves will open or close the actuators are supplied with hydraulic fluid under pressure which will move the control surface
learning.explanation: A hydraulic valve acts as a switch in an electrical system, it can open or close the flow to a service. “They decrease the control force generated by the cables or pushrods” Is incorrect because a valve is nothing more than a “switch” and it has nothing to do with decreasing control forces. “They act on the actuator of the control surface” Is correct, as these valves will open or close the actuators are supplied with hydraulic fluid under pressure which will move the control surface. “They directly cause a movement of the control surface” Is incorrect, this is the description of an actuator. “They only provide the pilot with an “artificial feel” feedback” Is incorrect, 1 because of the word “only” and 2 because valve do not provide artificial feel, this would be the work of an actuator operated by a valve.

content.question: You are flying an aircraft with Fly-By-Wire flight controls, operating in normal law with flight envelope protections. On short final approach, ATC instruct you to immediately go around due to a runway incursion. What should you do with the sidestick?

options.A: Gently pull back on the sidestick with caution so as not to stall.
options.B: Pull back on the sidestick to decelerate below VFE, then reduce the back pressure and extend flaps.
options.C: Firmly pull back on the sidestick but be careful to not exceed the limit load factor.
options.D: Firmly pull back on the sidestick with no hesitation and do not worry about stalling.

key_points: Fly-By-Wire systems A Fly-By-Wire control system is a powered system (irreversible) that uses electronic inputs to a solenoid servo valve instead of mechanical inputs from conventional powered controls
The pilot operates the controls, these can be a sidestick and rudder pedals or a conventional yoke with rudder pedals
These controls are fitted with transducers which convert the mechanical movement into an electrical output which is then amplified and processed by several computers
learning.explanation: Fly-By-Wire systems A Fly-By-Wire control system is a powered system (irreversible) that uses electronic inputs to a solenoid servo valve instead of mechanical inputs from conventional powered controls. The pilot operates the controls, these can be a sidestick and rudder pedals or a conventional yoke with rudder pedals. These controls are fitted with transducers which convert the mechanical movement into an electrical output which is then amplified and processed by several computers. These computers provide the input for the servo valves which controls the movement of the hydraulic actuators attached to the flight control surfaces. One of the largest benefits of fly by wire is the flight envelope protection system. It has many abilities, including preventing excessive bank angles, preventing the stall, overspeed protection, overload protection, etc. In the event of a late go-around like this one, the recommended way to go around remains the same amongst all aircraft, apply TOGA thrust (or sometimes less if full TOGA thrust is not required), pitch up to a suitable go-around attitude (somewhere around 15° initially), retract flaps if necessary, and begin climbing, then "clean up" the rest of the aircraft (gain speed, gear up, retract flaps further, etc.). For that initial reaction though, Fly-By-Wire flight envelope protections could perhaps be useful. Because of the stall protection of a fly-by-wire flight control system, in theory, the pilot can just apply TO/GA thrust and pull back on the sidestick all the way, and just hold it there. The aircraft will likely go into stall protection mode, which in an Airbus A320 (as EASA usually refer to) changes the control logic slightly above αprot then applies TO/GA thrust above αfloor (the pilot should already have applied TO/GA at this point of course), so the aircraft will climb, but the system will not let the aircraft fully stall, no matter how hard the pilot pulls back. Note: This would be a very aggressive manoeuvre, and similar to terrain or windshear escape manoeuvres, which would cause the pilots far more issues later on than if they just performed a normal go-around, so this is not the way a pilot should actually fly a go-around in a fly-by-wire aircraft, it is simply a theoretical method of doing so. However, the examiner likes to find interesting ways of testing Fly-By-Wire knowledge, and that includes asking you about the very limits of the systems. Whilst pulling back on the stick with caution is quite advisable (as per one of the other options), it does not need to be gentle, particularly for a late go-around, and it is not to stop the aircraft stalling really, as the Fly-By-Wire stops that.

content.question: In a Fly-By-Wire controlled aircraft, what happens if both pilots move their sidesticks at the same time?

options.A: The pilot-in-command has priority (left stick).
options.B: Both inputs are mixed.
options.C: Nothing happens.
options.D: The stick where the last input was made has priority.

key_points: In a Fly-By-Wire system such as the Airbus A320, amongst others, both pilots have a sidestick which is a major input into the fly-by-wire control system
As these sidesticks are not mechanically linked like other, there needs to be a way for both pilots to make inputs at once
The standard system for this is for both inputs to be "algebraically summed" together, which is a complex way of saying that both sticks get an input into the control system
learning.explanation: In a Fly-By-Wire system such as the Airbus A320, amongst others, both pilots have a sidestick which is a major input into the fly-by-wire control system. As these sidesticks are not mechanically linked like other, there needs to be a way for both pilots to make inputs at once. The standard system for this is for both inputs to be "algebraically summed" together, which is a complex way of saying that both sticks get an input into the control system. This is called dual input. In case that it occurs, an aural warning “DUAL INPUT” and a flashing warning light in sight of each pilot is provided. To allow one pilot to take over controls from the other, which might be necessary in case of incapacitation, etc., a red take-over button is installed on each sidestick that disables the stick on the other side when held. When this condition occurs, an aural warning is provided “PRIORITY LEFT/RIGHT”, indicating the active sidestick.

content.question: The pilot`s control input in a Fly-By-Wire system is…

options.A: linked by mechanical cables directly to the flight control surface.
options.B: converted into an electrical signal and linked via a computer to the flight control surface.
options.C: linked mechanically to a computer and then to the flight control surface.
options.D: linked by electrical wires directly to the flight control surface.

key_points: Fly by wire systems A fly by wire control system is a powered system (irreversible) that uses electronic inputs to a solenoid servo valve instead of mechanical inputs from conventional powered controls
The pilot operates the controls, these can be a sidestick and rudder pedals or a conventional yoke with rudder pedals
These controls are fitted with transducers which convert the mechanical movement into an electrical output which is then amplified and processed by several computers
learning.explanation: Fly by wire systems A fly by wire control system is a powered system (irreversible) that uses electronic inputs to a solenoid servo valve instead of mechanical inputs from conventional powered controls. The pilot operates the controls, these can be a sidestick and rudder pedals or a conventional yoke with rudder pedals. These controls are fitted with transducers which convert the mechanical movement into an electrical output which is then amplified and processed by several computers. These computers provide the input for the servo valves which controls the movement of the hydraulic actuators attached to the flight control surfaces. Advantages of fly by wire Weight reduction, as there is no need for the long and heavy control cables this is a big reduction in the weight of the aircraft. Pilot work load is reduced because the pilot is supported by the computers with automated features like auto trim and turn coordination. Flight envelope protection, which can prevent the pilot from pitching up too much beyond the stalling angle of attack. It can limit the controls in such a way that the airframe will not endure Gforces out of the limits. Disadvantages Reliability, as conventional systems might give some indication of an upcoming failure, a fly by wire system can lose a computer would could result in loss of control. This means there is need for redundancy in the form of additional computers and hydraulic systems.

content.question:
Which of these statements about rudder limiting are correct or incorrect?
I. A rudder ratio changer system limits both rudder and rudder pedal deflection as the IAS increases
II. A variable stop system reduces the rudder deflection for a given rudder pedal deflection as the IAS increases

options.A: I is correct, II is correct.
options.B: I is incorrect, II is incorrect.
options.C: I is correct, II is incorrect.
options.D: I is incorrect, II is correct.

key_points: "I
A rudder ratio changer system limits both rudder and rudder pedal deflection as the IAS increases
" Incorrect
learning.explanation: "I. A rudder ratio changer system limits both rudder and rudder pedal deflection as the IAS increases." Incorrect. Rudder Ratio Changer: The control commands from the rudder pedals and trim control are modified by a rudder ratio changer. As the aircraft speed inscreases, the rudder deflection must be reduced proportionately within the range of the rudder pedal depression by the pilot => the rudder peddals move through their full range at all speeds, however, rudder deflection is reduced with increasing airspeed. If this automatic reduction is not applied and rudder is fully deflected when the aircraft is in high speed flight, it will may cause the plane to sharply and violently yaw. "II. A variable stop system reduces the rudder deflection for a given rudder pedal deflection as the IAS increases." Incorrect. Variable Stop System: The movement of the rudder and pedal travel are proportional. However, as the airspeed increases, the movement of the rudder pedals and the rudder are physically reduced. When the rudder is limited in movement at high speed, the pedal travel is also restricted.

content.question: Which modes of operation exist in Fly-By-Wire systems?

options.A: The normal mode, the direct mode and mechanical backup.
options.B: The alternate (or secondary) mode, the direct mode and mechanical backup.
options.C: The normal mode, the alternate (or secondary) mode and the direct mode.
options.D: The normal mode, the alternate (or secondary) mode, the direct mode and mechanical backup.

key_points: The Fly-By-Wire system has multiple redundancies that offer layered protection: Normal Law offers all the protections (like stall, load factor etc)
This is the system in operation during normal flights
Normal Law operates in different modes depending on the stage of flight
learning.explanation: The Fly-By-Wire system has multiple redundancies that offer layered protection: Normal Law offers all the protections (like stall, load factor etc). This is the system in operation during normal flights. Normal Law operates in different modes depending on the stage of flight. These modes include: Ground Mode Flight Mode Flare Mode Alternate Law offers limited protection including stability, load factor and stall protections. Basically, it is the reduced mode of operation which provides most features of normal law. Direct Law is the lowest level of fly-by-wire system and directly transmits the pilot inputs to control surfaces, while still giving stall and load factor warnings Mechanical back up. In case all of the above fail, the system reverts to mechanical backup, where pitch control is achieved through the horizontal stabilizer and lateral control is accomplished using the rudder pedals. The purpose of the backup system is to allow control of the aircraft following a total loss of electrics, flight control computers, elevators, or ailerons and spoilers In case of mechanical backup, the system will operate as long as hydraulic power is available. In case of electrical failure, as long as hydraulics are OK, the pilot should be able to control the aircraft.

Which of these statements is correct as regards trimming in an irreversible flight control system of a conventional aeroplane equipped with a trimmable horizontal stabiliser?

key_points: Elevator (pitch) trim: zero force position of the control column does not change (control column/horn/stick does not move) Aileron trim: zero force position changes (control wheel turns in the direction of the trim) Rudder trim: zero force position changes (pedals move in the direction of the trim) Primary flight controls Are controls which movement causes a rotation about one of the three axes of the aircraft, causing a change in the aircraft’s flightpath or attitude
The elevator, rudder and ailerons are considered to be the primary flight controls
The primary flight controls in a manually controlled system are reversible
learning.explanation: Elevator (pitch) trim: zero force position of the control column does not change (control column/horn/stick does not move) Aileron trim: zero force position changes (control wheel turns in the direction of the trim) Rudder trim: zero force position changes (pedals move in the direction of the trim) Primary flight controls Are controls which movement causes a rotation about one of the three axes of the aircraft, causing a change in the aircraft’s flightpath or attitude. The elevator, rudder and ailerons are considered to be the primary flight controls. The primary flight controls in a manually controlled system are reversible. This means that a force applied to the controls is a force which moves the control surface, and also a force which moves the control surface will move the pilot’s controls. This means that the air pressure on the control surface can be felt in the pilot’s controls. When the flight controls are fully power operated this is not the case and is called irreversible. This means that if there is a force moving the control surface this will not move the control columns, and there will be no natural feel on the controls. Because of this there will need to be an artificial feel unit installed in a fully powered or irreversible control system. This artificial feel unit should apply force to the cockpit controls in proportion to the control deflection and in proportion to the aircraft’s speed. This artificial feel system will also work with a trim system, but this works different than a normal trim surface does. In the figure in the annex you can see how the trim of the artificial feel unit works. A movement of the trimwheel will result in a movement of the electric trim actuator, and so the control surface, but not in the movement of the control column (this is for elevator control). It is different for aileron and rudder trim. Elevator trim: zero force position of the control column does not change (control column/horn/stick does not move) Aileron trim: zero force position changes (control wheel turns in the direction of the trim) Rudder trim: zero force position changes (pedals move in the direction of the trim)

2. The resulting control input of a dual control input from both sidesticks is electronically limited to the maximum deflection limit of one sidestick

options.A: 1 is incorrect, 2 is correct.
options.B: 1 is correct, 2 is incorrect.
options.C: Both 1 and 2 are incorrect.
options.D: Both 1 and 2 are correct.

key_points: In a Fly-By-Wire system such as the Airbus A320, amongst others, both pilots have a sidestick which is a major input into the fly-by-wire control system
As these sidesticks are not mechanically linked like other, there needs to be a way for both pilots to make inputs at once

learning.explanation: In a Fly-By-Wire system such as the Airbus A320, amongst others, both pilots have a sidestick which is a major input into the fly-by-wire control system. As these sidesticks are not mechanically linked like other, there needs to be a way for both pilots to make inputs at once. The standard system for this is for both inputs to be "algebraically summed" together, which is a complex way of saying that both sticks get an input into the control system. This is called dual input. In case that it occurs, an aural warning “DUAL INPUT” and a flashing warning light in sight of each pilot is provided. To allow one pilot to take over controls from the other, which might be necessary in case of incapacitation, etc., a red take-over button is installed on each sidestick that disables the stick on the other side when held. This button works as an autopilot disconnect when pushed once, but when it is pushed and held, it removes the other pilot's inputs from the system, and after 40 seconds of holding (A320 specific) the other pilot is "locked out" from inputs until they push their own prioirty button. When this condition occurs, an aural warning is provided “PRIORITY LEFT/RIGHT”, indicating the active sidestick. Fly-by-wire systems often include safeguards to prevent excessive control inputs that could potentially overstress the aircraft or exceed its performance limits. In the case of dual control inputs, the resulting control input is indeed electronically limited to prevent exceeding the maximum deflection limit of one sidestick.

content.question:
Which of these statements about a gust lock system are correct or incorrect?
I. A gust lock can be used in flight to reduce the effects of turbulence
II. Reversible flight controls should have a gust lock

options.A: I is incorrect, II is correct.
options.B: I is correct, II is correct.
options.C: I is correct, II is incorrect.
options.D: I is incorrect, II is incorrect.

key_points: "I
A gust lock can be used in flight to reduce the effects of turbulence
" Incorrect
learning.explanation: "I. A gust lock can be used in flight to reduce the effects of turbulence." Incorrect. A gust lock is essentially a device which limits the movement of a control surface while the aeroplane is parked, preventing damage when it is unattended. It stops aicraft's surfaces from being slammed back and forth in a strong wind/gusts. Typically it is the ailerons, the elevator and the rudder that are of concern. In many aircraft, the control column that supports the yoke can be immobilized in the cockpit with a heavy pin that slides through aligned holes in the column itself, thereby restarting the elevator and ailerons from moving at all. There is also a style of gust lock that attaches directly to the base of the rudder and holds it immobile. It is clearly essential that all flight control locks are removed/disengaged before flight. "II. Reversible flight controls should have a gust lock." Correct. A reversible control system is a power assisted system in which the pilot is connected directly to the controls, feeling part of the load. It is called "reversible" because if someone moves the external surfaces, the stick (or control column) and the peddals move inside the cockpit. Control surfaces move freely and in case of strong wind, for example, they may be slammed back and forth, which may cause aircraft damage. For that reason, a gust lock system should be used, inside the aircraft and/or outside.

content.question: An aeroplane extends its flaps asymmetrically. The aircraft will roll...

options.A: towards the side with fewer flaps and have a yawing moment to the same side.
options.B: towards the side with more flaps and have a yawing moment to the same side.
options.C: towards the side with more flaps and have a yawing moment to the opposite side.
options.D: towards the side with fewer flaps and have a yawing moment to the opposite side.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.05.02.01.07: Explain how a flap/slat asymmetry protection device functions, and describe the implications of a flap/slat asymmetry situation. A flap asymmetry situation can be disastrous. This is because flaps change the coefficient of lift of the wing massively, in order to provide more lift, and therefore allow flight at slower speeds. Flaps can easily double the coefficient of lift from a wing, whilst also increasing the drag, possibly by a lot. This means that flap asymmetry will roll the aircraft towards the cleaner wing (fewer flaps), as the wing with flaps down is producing much more lift than it. It also means that the aircraft will have asymmetric drag, and will want to yaw towards the wing with flaps down, as the flaps are causing extra drag that the clean wing is not producing. This means that the yaw is in the opposite direction from the roll.

It uses computers to translate the pilot's inputs into electrical signals, which is transfered into the movement of hydraulic servo valves via solenoids. It has many positives, such as flight envelope protection and reduced weight and complexity. There do still have to be ways to combat failures, so that a single point of failure is not capable of making the aircraft uncontrollable. In an A320, for instance, each aileron has 2 actuators, an active and a "damping". Fly-By-Wire is the control system that connects the pilots inputs to the aircraft control surfaces via computers, giving no direct physical connection, but providing benefits such as flight envelope protection and reduced weight of control systems. Flight envelope protection is what is being discussed in this question. An aircraft with fly-by-wire operating in normal law will have a full suite of stall protections. These mean that the system will not let the pilot stall the aircraft by pulling back too hard or too far with the sidestick. It also protects the aircraft from pulling more than the limit load factor. This means that during a terrain escape manoeuvre, when the aim is to gain as much altitude as possible in the shortest distance, the pilot can just pull back on the sidestick to full deflection, and the fly-by-wire system will ensure a controlled pitch up to a high (but safe) pitch angle, allowing the speed to reduce to the point where the aircraft reaches "max alpha", and then the aircraft will pitch down to maintain that angle of attack. Whether this is an approved way of performing a terrain escape manoeuvre is irrelevant to the question, which is simply testing your technical knowledge of fly-by-wire systems.

content.question:
Which of the following are used to limit rudder deflection?
1. Gust lock
2. Variable stops
3. Ratio changer
4. Control locks
5. Blow-back

options.A: 1, 2 and 4
options.B: 2, 3 and 5
options.C: 2, 4 and 5
options.D: 3, 4 and 5

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.05.01.05.05: Explain the concept of a rudder deflection limitation (rudder limiter) system and the various means of implementation (rudder ratio changer, variable stops, blow-back). As stated in the Learning Objective above, there are 3 ways to limit rudder deflection, which we want to do at higher airspeeds to limit the forces on the aircraft: Rudder Ratio Changer: The control commands from the rudder pedals and trim control are modified by a rudder ratio changer. As the aircraft speed increases, the rudder deflection must be reduced proportionately within the range of the rudder pedal depression by the pilot => the rudder pedals move through their full range at all speeds, however, rudder deflection is reduced with increasing airspeed. If this automatic reduction is not applied and rudder is fully deflected when the aircraft is in high speed flight, the huge forces could damage the aircraft, or at least cause violent yaw/roll. Variable Stops: The movement of the rudder and the pedal travel are directly proportional to each other. However, as the airspeed increases, the movement of the rudder pedals and the rudder are physically reduced. When the rudder is limited in movement at high speed, the pedal travel is also restricted. This does have the consequence of making the rudder very sensitive at high airspeeds, just not with a very long pedal travel. Blow-Back: This is a system that applies a constant movement force to the rudder, the force being dictated by the pedal deflection, which then deflects the rudder depending on the speed of the airflow. slower airspeed means that the constant force will deflect the rudder more, whereas fast airspeed would mean the consequent higher dynamic pressure naturally limits the rudder deflection, acting like a more modern rudder ratio changer.

content.question: Extension of the wing spoilers is often limited to a maximum airspeed. What is the reason for this?

options.A: To prevent roll control problems at high speed.
options.B: To prevent longitudinal instability at high speed.
options.C: To prevent structural damage to the spoilers at excessive dynamic pressures.
options.D: To ensure maximum fuel efficiency by braking at the highest possible speed.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.05.02.01.05: Describe the requirement for limiting flight speeds for the various secondary flight control surfaces. Secondary flight controls such as flaps, slats, and spoilers often contain maximum speed limits for their use, due to the fact that they stick into the airflow, which will exert significant force on them due to dynamic pressure. The dynamic pressure exerted is proportional to the square of the air velocity, so for a doubling of speed, the dynamic pressure increases by x4. If the secondary flight controls were extended past their maximum speed, the devices and the mechanisms keeping them in place could be overpowered or may be permanently damaged. For spoilers, they are subject to huge amounts of dynamic pressure as part of their job "spoiling" the airflow over the wing, so are particularly susceptible to this. learning.explanation: TRIM RUNAWAY While the use of an electrical trim system can provide important safety and convenience benefits, it can also introduce the potential for a malfunction called “Trim Runaway.” Trim Runaway occurs when the Trimmable Horizontal Stabilizer (THS) or other trim device on the aircraft tail fails to stop at the desired position and continues to deflect up or down. A full stabilizer deflection could prevent the aircraft from returning to a safe landing. A Runaway Pitch Trim can be fatal in flight because it would run the horizontal stabilizer either up or down to its mechanical stops, and the use of the elevators would not be sufficient to overcome this force. In most Electrical Trim systems, two toggle switches are required for a stabilizer trim system, where one of them releases the trim brake and the other one drives the motor. You must use both to activate the stabilizer trim - they are designed in such a way on the control column that if you trim, you will always push them together. The reason you need double trim switches is primarily to prevent Trim Runaway on the stabilizer, if one switch runs away then the other can be used to stop it.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.05.01.05.02: Explain how redundancy is obtained in primary flight control systems of large transport aeroplanes. Modern transport aircraft must be equipped with safeguards to prevent loss of control in the event of hydraulic or electrical failure. This is typically achieved by incorporating redundancy into the control system. One common method of redundancy is splitting control surfaces into two or three sections, each powered by separate actuators and hydraulic systems. In addition, computer system redundancy is also provided in some modern transport aircraft, such as Airbus aircraft. In a large transport aircraft with fully powered primary flight controls, redundancy can be achieved by having multiple flight control computers linked to multiple actuators supplied by different power sources. This configuration ensures that, in the event of a single-point failure, the aircraft's control surfaces remain operable and the pilots can continue to control the aircraft safely.

CORRECT: The zero force position will not change when using pitch (elevator) trim Statement 2: The zero force position of the control wheel does not change when using the aileron trim

CORRECT: The zero force position will not change when using pitch (elevator) trim Statement 2: The zero force position of the control wheel does not change when using the aileron trim. INCORRECT: The zero force position will change when using the aileron trim. Primary flight controls Are controls which movement causes a rotation about one of the three axes of the aircraft, causing a change in the aircraft’s flightpath or attitude. The elevator, rudder and ailerons are considered to be the primary flight controls. The primary flight controls in a manually controlled system are reversible. This means that a force applied to the controls is a force which moves the control surface, and also a force which moves the control surface will move the pilot’s controls. This means that the air pressure on the control surface can be felt in the pilot’s controls. When the flight controls are fully power operated this is not the case and is called irreversible. This means that if there is a force moving the control surface this will not move the control columns, and there will be no natural feel on the controls. Because of this there will need to be an artificial feel unit installed in a fully powered or irreversible control system. This artificial feel unit should apply force to the cockpit controls in proportion to the control deflection and in proportion to the aircraft’s speed. This artificial feel system will also work with a trim system, but this works different than a normal trim surface does. In the figure in the annex you can see how the trim of the artificial feel unit works. A movement of the trimwheel will result in a movement of the electric trim actuator, and so the control surface, but not in the movement of the control column (this is for elevator control). It is different for aileron and rudder trim. Elevator trim: zero force position of the control column does not change (control column/horn/stick does not move) Aileron trim: zero force position changes (control wheel turns in the direction of the trim) Rudder trim: zero force position changes (pedals move in the direction of the trim)

content.question: A Fly-By-Wire (FBW) system has different modes of operation. Of the modes listed below, which one is the most basic?

options.A: Direct mode
options.B: Direct computer mode
options.C: Alternate mode

key_points: Boeing and Airbus call these a bit different but the principle stays the same
Airbus has the following laws: Normal law Flight control Normal Law provides three axis control, flight envelope protection and manoeuver load alleviation
Normal Law operates in different modes depending on the stage of flight
learning.explanation: Boeing and Airbus call these a bit different but the principle stays the same. Airbus has the following laws: Normal law Flight control Normal Law provides three axis control, flight envelope protection and manoeuver load alleviation. Normal Law operates in different modes depending on the stage of flight. These modes include: Ground Mode, Flight Mode, Flare Mode Alternate law Alternate Law 1 (ALT1) combines Normal Law lateral mode with Alternate Law pitch modes. Low Energy Protection is replaced by Low Speed Stability meaning that the aircraft no longer has automatic stall protection. At low speed, a nose down demand is introduced based on IAS (instead of AOA) and Alternate Law changes to Direct Law. In addition, an audio "STALL" warning is introduced. α-Floor protection is not available so conventional pilot stall recovery action is required. Load Factor and Bank Angle Protections are retained. High Speed and High Angle of Attack Protections enter Alternate Law mode. Pitch Attitude Protection is lost. ALT1 control law degradation will result from some faults in the horizontal stabilizer, a single elevator fault, loss of a yaw-damper actuator, loss of slat or flap position sensors or a single air data reference fault. Dependent upon the failure, autopilot may not be available. In Alternate Law 2 (ALT2), Normal Law lateral mode is lost and is replaced by roll Direct Law and yaw Alternate Law. Pitch mode is in Alternate Law. Load factor protection is retained. In addition to those protections lost in ALT1 (Pitch Attitude and Low Energy Protection), Bank Angle Protection is also lost. In some failure cases, High Angle of Attack and High Speed Protections will also be lost. As is the case with ALT1, some failure cases that result in ALT2 will also cause the autopilot to disconnect. ALT2 is entered when both engines flame out, with faults in two inertial or two air-data reference units, with faults to all spoilers, certain aileron faults or with a pedal transducers fault Direct law In Direct Law (DIR), lateral modes are the same as ALT2; that is roll Direct Law and yaw Alternate Law. Pitch control degrades to Direct Law and automatic trim is inoperative requiring stab trim to be adjusted manually by the pilot. Control surface motion is directly related to the sidestick motion. ALL protections are lost. In Direct Law, autopilot function is always lost. DIR is entered if there is failure of all three inertial reference units or all three primary flight computers, faults in both elevators or flame out of both engines concurrent with loss of PRIM 1. Boeing uses: Normal mode In Normal mode during manual flight, the ACEs receive pilot control inputs and send these signals to the three PFCs. The PFCs verify these signals and utilise information from other airplane systems in order to compute control surface commands. These commands are then sent back to the ACEs which then send the enhanced signals to the flight control surface actuators which convert them into analog servo commands. Full functionality is provided including all enhanced performance, envelope protection and ride quality features. When the autopilot is engaged, the autopilot system sends commands to the PFCs. The PFCs generate control surface commands which are sent to the ACEs in the same manner as pilot control inputs. The autopilot commands move the flight deck controls to provide autopilot feedback to the pilots. If a pilot overrides the autopilot with control inputs, the PFCs will disengage the autopilot and utilise the pilot control inputs. Note that the autopilot is not available should reversion to Secondary or Direct mode occur. Secondary mode Boeing Secondary mode is somewhat similar to the Airbus Alternate Law. When the PFCs cannot support Normal mode operation due to internal faults or to loss of information from other aircraft systems, they automatically revert to Secondary mode. Reversion to Secondary mode results in the loss of the autopilot and the pilots must control the aircraft manually. The ACEs still receive pilot control inputs and send the appropriate signals to the PFCs. However, due to the degraded mode of operation, the PFCs use "simplified" computations to generate the flight control surface commands. These commands are sent back to the ACEs from where they are sent to the flight control surfaces in the same manner as during Normal mode operations. Aircraft handling qualities are affected by the simplified computations or PFC control laws that are utilised in Secondary mode. While all flight control surfaces remain operative, the elevator and rudder are more sensitive at some airspeeds. The following functions are inoperative or degraded during Secondary mode operations: autopilot auto speedbrakes envelope protection gust suppression tail strike protection thrust asymmetry compensation yaw damping Direct mode The ACEs automatically revert to Direct mode when they detect the failure of all three PFCs or when they are unable to communicate with the PFCs. Direct mode can also be manually selected by selecting the DISC position on the Primary Flight Computers Disconnect switch. In Direct mode, the PFCs no longer generate control surface commands. Pilot inputs are received by the ACEs and sent directly to the flight control surface actuators. Direct mode allows for full aircraft control while in flight and during the landing phase. Aircraft handling characteristics are very similar to those encountered while in Secondary mode. In addition to those functions lost during Secondary mode operations (as listed previously) the manual rudder trim cancel switch is inoperative.

content.question: A Fly-By-Wire system is always irreversible because…

options.A: there is a mechanical linkage between the flight control surfaces and the pilot controls. The pilot inputs move the control surfaces directly.
options.B: linked mechanically to a computer and then to the flight control surface.
options.C: the link between the pilot inputs and control surfaces is via a computer, so the control surfaces are moved indirectly by the pilot inputs.
options.D: the pilot can reverse the inputs of the autopilot system as he/she also has a direct link to the hydraulic commands of the control surfaces.

key_points: In a Fly-By-Wire system, the pilot inputs are transmitted to the flight control surfaces through a computer, which then actuates the hydraulic or electrical systems that move the control surfaces
This means that the pilot inputs do not directly move the control surfaces, and any corrective action must be taken through the computer system
This means that FBW is irreversible as there will be no direct feedback from aerodynamic forces on the control surfaces without an artificial feel system
learning.explanation: In a Fly-By-Wire system, the pilot inputs are transmitted to the flight control surfaces through a computer, which then actuates the hydraulic or electrical systems that move the control surfaces. This means that the pilot inputs do not directly move the control surfaces, and any corrective action must be taken through the computer system. This means that FBW is irreversible as there will be no direct feedback from aerodynamic forces on the control surfaces without an artificial feel system. This design feature allows for the implementation of various flight control laws and protections that can enhance the safety and performance of the aircraft. However, it also means that the system is irreversible, as the pilot cannot directly override the computer's commands to the flight control surfaces. Therefore, in a Fly-By-Wire system, the control surfaces are moved indirectly by the pilot inputs via a computer, which makes the system irreversible. Option "the link between the pilot inputs and control surfaces is via a computer, so the control surfaces are moved indirectly by the pilot inputs" correctly explains this concept.

learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.05.02.01.02: List the following secondary flight control surfaces: lift-augmentation devices (flaps and slats); speed brakes; flight and ground spoilers; trimming devices such as trim tabs, trimmable horizontal stabiliser. Secondary flight controls are surfaces which aid the characteristics of the aircraft and the pilots, but are not the primary control surfaces. That means that flaps, slats, speedbrakes, spoilers*, and even trim devices count as secondary flight controls. *Roll spoilers exist on many jets, which are spoilers that contribute to a down-going wing's lack of lift when rolling, similar to an up-going aileron. These do not count as secondary flight controls, as they are primary flight controls (effectively extra ailerons).

Which of these statements about rudder limiting are correct?
1. A rudder ratio changer system reduces the rudder deflection for a given rudder pedal deflection as the IAS decreases
2. A variable stop system limits both rudder and rudder pedal deflection as the IAS increases

options.B: Both 1 and 2 are incorrect.

key_points: A rudder ratio changer system reduces the rudder deflection for a given rudder pedal deflection as the IAS decreases
" Incorrect
learning.explanation: "1. A rudder ratio changer system reduces the rudder deflection for a given rudder pedal deflection as the IAS decreases." Incorrect. Rudder Ratio Changer: The control commands from the rudder pedals and trim control are modified by a rudder ratio changer. As the aircraft speed inscreases, the rudder deflection must be reduced proportionately within the range of the rudder pedal depression by the pilot => the rudder peddals move through their full range at all speeds, however, rudder deflection is reduced with increasing airspeed. If this automatic reduction is not applied and rudder is fully deflected when the aircraft is in high speed flight, it will may cause the plane to sharply and violently yaw. "2. A variable stop system limits both rudder and rudder pedal deflection as the IAS increases." Correct. Variable Stop System: The movement of the rudder and pedal travel are proportional. However, as the airspeed increases, the movement of the rudder pedals and the rudder are physically reduced. When the rudder is limited in movement at high speed, the pedal travel is also restricted.

content.question: During final approach in a jet aircraft with Fly-By-Wire flight controls, ATC instructs you to go around as there is still an aircraft on the runway. In the cockpit, the term "alpha floor" is mentioned. What will alpha floor protection do?

options.A: Prevent the aircraft from being able to stall when pulling back on the side stick or yoke.
options.B: Limit the aircraft’s capability to pitch up beyond a certain angle.
options.C: Use significant roll inputs to keep the aircraft from stalling.
options.D: Automatically increase thrust to prevent a stall when a high angle of attack is detected.

key_points: Fly-By-Wire flight controls offer many benefits to an aircraft, one of the largest being the addition of flight envelope protection
Provided the FBW system functions at its normal level, this significantly enhances safety
Feedback control of airspeed, Mach Number, attitude, and angle of attack can be used to ensure that the FBW aircraft stays within its certificated flight envelope
learning.explanation: Fly-By-Wire flight controls offer many benefits to an aircraft, one of the largest being the addition of flight envelope protection. Provided the FBW system functions at its normal level, this significantly enhances safety. Feedback control of airspeed, Mach Number, attitude, and angle of attack can be used to ensure that the FBW aircraft stays within its certificated flight envelope. For instance, on the Airbus A320 (the fly-by-wire aircraft most often referenced by EASA), the flight mode of Normal Law provides five types of protection: pitch attitude, load factor limitations, overspeed, high-AoA/low airspeed and bank angle. At high angles of attack/low airspeeds, sometimes called high alpha, Fly-By-Wire systems have certain protections to prevent the aircraft stalling. Take Airbus for instance, Their aircraft have alpha prot., alpha floor, and alpha max. Each level increases the amount of protections, Alpha prot. = the aircraft pitch is set so that speed remains at or above this speed, unless the stick is manually pulled back, hence it will automatically beginning a descent to remain at a safe speed if necessary Alpha floor = automatically applies TOGA (full) thrust Alpha max = In normal law, this cannot be exceeded even by maximum stick deflection aft, to avoid a full stall.

key_points: Fly-By-Wire systems A Fly-By-Wire control system is a fully powered flight control system (irreversible) that uses electronic inputs to a solenoid servo valve instead of mechanical inputs from conventional powered controls
The pilot operates the controls, these can be a sidestick and rudder pedals or a conventional yoke with rudder pedals
These controls are fitted with transducers which convert the mechanical movement into an electrical output which is then amplified and processed by several computers
learning.explanation: Fly-By-Wire systems A Fly-By-Wire control system is a fully powered flight control system (irreversible) that uses electronic inputs to a solenoid servo valve instead of mechanical inputs from conventional powered controls. The pilot operates the controls, these can be a sidestick and rudder pedals or a conventional yoke with rudder pedals. These controls are fitted with transducers which convert the mechanical movement into an electrical output which is then amplified and processed by several computers. These computers provide the input for the servo valves which controls the movement of the hydraulic actuators attached to the flight control surfaces. Advantages of Fly-By-Wire Weight reduction, as there is no need for the long and heavy control cables this is a big reduction in the weight of the aircraft. Pilot work load is reduced because the pilot is supported by the computers with automated features like auto trim and turn coordination. Flight envelope protection, which can prevent the pilot from pitching up too much beyond the stalling angle of attack. It can limit the controls in such a way that the airframe will not endure G forces out of the limits. Disadvantages Reliability, as conventional systems might give some indication of an upcoming failure, a fly by wire system can lose a computer, which could result in loss of control. This means there is need for redundancy in the form of additional sensors, computers and hydraulic systems. A flight control system must not be allowed to have a single point of failure, so there is a large amount of extra redundancy built-in, which allows multiple different failures before the FBW system becomes inoperative.

POWERED-ASSISTED SYSTEM A power-assisted system is designed so that a part of the control force is felt by the pilot (the rest is done by hydraulic power).

learning.explanation: As you can see at the bottom of this explanation, for the aileron and rudder the “zero force point” will be adjusted when trimming. This is not the case for elevator trim. Primary flight controls Are controls which movement causes a rotation about one of the three axes of the aircraft, causing a change in the aircraft’s flightpath or attitude. The elevator, rudder and ailerons are considered to be the primary flight controls. The primary flight controls in a manually controlled system are reversible. This means that a force applied to the controls is a force which moves the control surface, and also a force which moves the control surface will move the pilot’s controls. This means that the air pressure on the control surface can be felt in the pilot’s controls. When the flight controls are fully power operated this is not the case and is called irreversible. This means that if there is a force moving the control surface this will not move the control columns, and there will be no natural feel on the controls. Because of this there will need to be an artificial feel unit installed in a fully powered or irreversible control system. This artificial feel unit should apply force to the cockpit controls in proportion to the control deflection and in proportion to the aircraft’s speed. The artificial feel system is placed in parallel with the hydraulic actuator, so the movement of the flight controls in the cockpit will cause the hydraulic actuator to operate. During this same movement the artificial feel system will apply pressure on the controls appropriate to the airspeed of the aircraft. This artificial feel system will also work with a trim system, but this works different than a normal trim surface does. A movement of the trimwheel will result in a movement of the electric trim actuator, and so the control surface, but not in the movement of the control column (this is for elevator control). It is different for aileron and rudder trim. Elevator trim: zero force position of the control column does not change (control column/horn/stick does not move) Aileron trim: zero force position changes (control wheel turns in the direction of the trim) Rudder trim: zero force position changes (pedals move in the direction of the trim)

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.05.02.01.07: Explain how a flap/slat asymmetry protection device functions, and describe the implications of a flap/slat asymmetry situation. A flap asymmetry situation can be disastrous. This is because flaps change the coefficient of lift of the wing massively, in order to provide more lift, and therefore allow flight at slower speeds. Flaps can easily double the coefficient of lift from a wing, whilst also increasing the drag, possibly by a lot. An aircraft will fly terribly with even a medium sized flap asymmetry, with high drag and high lift on one wing but not the other. A way to avoid this situation is by having a flap/slat asymmetry protection system. This detects the actual flap/slat position in each wing with great accuracy, and as soon as an asymmetry is detected, the system will stop the flaps/slats from moving, and show up a warning or caution to the pilots.

key_points: FLY-BY-WIRE In a fly-by-wire aircraft, the pilot inputs commands via a sidestick or yoke to a computer

The computer then processes these inputs and sends corresponding electrical signals to the the servo valve which in turn controls the movement of a hydraulic actuator, which will hydraulically deflect a flight control surface

learning.explanation: FLY-BY-WIRE In a fly-by-wire aircraft, the pilot inputs commands via a sidestick or yoke to a computer. The computer then processes these inputs and sends corresponding electrical signals to the the servo valve which in turn controls the movement of a hydraulic actuator, which will hydraulically deflect a flight control surface. There are numerous advantages to FBW systems, including weight savings and safety features that can be incorporated into the computer software. FBW also enables highly reliable flight envelope protection systems which, provided the FBW system functions at its normal level, significantly enhances safety. Feedback control of airspeed, Mach Number, attitude, and angle of attack can be used to ensure that the FBW aircraft stays within its certificated flight envelope. For instance, on the Airbus, the flight mode of Normal Law provides five types of protection: pitch attitude, load factor limitations, high speed, high-AoA and bank angle. In addition, Low Speed Protection is available in certain phases of flight. The bank angle protection system on a FBW aircraft has the ability to change the control inputs to keep the aircraft within its safe flight envelope, and can therefore make it harder to maintain a bank angle that is outside of limits. The system would not override the pilot too much, and in dire situations the pilot may require high bank angles, which would still be possible in a FBW aircraft, as not to degrade safety.

learning.explanation: Fly-By-Wire aircraft have certain control modes, or "laws". Boeing and Airbus name these differently, but they are somewhat similar in concept. Airbus uses: Normal Law Alternate Law Direct Law Boeing uses: Normal Mode Secondary Mode Direct Mode A quick run-down of the control laws (primarily Airbus, but these small descriptions fit Boeing's modes well). Normal Law - All control augmentations and protections are in place. Alternate Law - Some protections are lost, some features act differently from normal, and the autopilot may be lost (depending on the fault). key_points: There are 4 main types of control system: Manual - cables and pulleys connect the flight controls to the control surfaces directly
The only power supplied is by the pilot

learning.explanation: There are 4 main types of control system: Manual - cables and pulleys connect the flight controls to the control surfaces directly. The only power supplied is by the pilot. Partially powered/Power assisted controls - The pilot is mechanically connected to the controls, but any force they exert will be assisted by extra force from the hydraulics. Similar to powered steering in a car. Fully powered controls - The flight controls physically move a servo valve which directs hydraulic pressure to the controls. No computers involved, but hydraulic pressure is absolutely required. Fly-By-Wire - A type of fully powered control system where the flight control movements are interpreted by a computer which electronically controls the hydraulic servo valves to move the control surfaces. The hydraulics still provide the power to move the control surfaces, but a computer sits between the pilot and the hydraulics, checking and modifying the requested movements. Fly-by-wire and fully powered controls are "irreversible", meaning that there is no feedback from the control surfaces to the pilot. This means that an artificial feel system has to be installed, so the pilot can feel the correct amount of resistance when moving the controls. This is not the case on manual or power assisted control systems, which are "reversible", and have natural feedback to the flight controls. Power assisted controls do not have as much feedback as manual controls of course, as the hydraulic system takes most of the force, but the pilot will feel a certain percentage of it, and the feel force does come from the actual aerodynamic forces acting on the control surface.

learning.explanation: When EASA mention a Fly-By-Wire aircraft with sidesticks, they usually mean the Airbus A320. When an aircraft is fitted with sidesticks for manual control, these sidesticks are connected digitally to the FBW (Fly-By-Wire) system to provide input for aileron and elevator control. The sidestick on each side of the flight deck feature a red button, used for autopilot disconnect, or as a "priority takeover" button. Priority takeover is added as the sidesticks are not mechanically linked so the pilots must be able to decide who is controlling the aircraft manually, as dual inputs can otherwise occur. to disconnect the autopilot when engaged in "command" (i.e. the aircraft is automatically flying), this red button can be pushed, the autopilot can be de-selected on the control panel (the flight-deck glareshield panel), or the pilot can simply make a large enough input on the sidestick, which will also disengage the autopilot and allow the pilot to control the aircraft manually. The pilot cannot and must not disconnect the FBW system entirely, as this would leave the aircraft with no elevator or aileron control, and very limited mechanical reversion control.

learning.explanation: EASA examinations use the Airbus A320 family as an example of fly-by-wire controlled aircraft. Normal law is the system mode which is active throughout the flight and is terminated when system failures occur that prevent its use. The highest reduced mode of operation in Airbus FBW systems is the Alternate Law, which provides most features of normal law. Some features such as automatic stall protection are lost and replaced by conventional warnings for the pilots to manually correct the condition. Should failure conditions prevent operation in Alternate Law, an even more basic Direct Law is available. Autopilot functions are lost, along with flight envelope protection. As a last emergency means of operation, Mechanical Backup is provided to maintain level flight only for the limited period of flight control computer reset following a complete loss of power. As we have stated above, a system degradation results in a loss of protection features, so the required alertness of the crew increases and leads to a higher workload.

key_points: Flight spoilers Flight spoilers are fitted on the upper side of the surface of the wing which can be raised

When a flight spoiler is raised it disturbs the flow over the wing causing a decrease in lift
learning.explanation: Flight spoilers Flight spoilers are fitted on the upper side of the surface of the wing which can be raised. They may be used to give directional control together, or instead of the ailerons. When a flight spoiler is raised it disturbs the flow over the wing causing a decrease in lift. When the flight spoilers are used for lateral control, on the wing that is meant to go down, the spoilers will extend while the spoilers on the up going wing remain retracted. Unlike ailerons, spoilers will not increase lift and so the use of spoilers instead of ailerons will cause a decrease in lift, this however will give some advantages over ailerons. As the raised spoiler will increase drag, the yaw directions will be in the same direction as the roll, therefore there will be no adverse yaw. When flying at transonic speeds there will be no shock induced, so the effectiveness stays the same. Because the spoilers are not located at the end of the wings there will be less wing twisting because the loss of lift will be distributed more even across the wingchord. The standard system for this is for both inputs to be "algebraically summed" together, which is a complex way of saying that both sticks get an input into the control system. key_points: There are two basic types of flight controls, reversible and irreversible
Reversible flight controls are those that have a two way force mechanism naturally as part of the system

This includes manual flight controls, which use levers and pulleys to transfer pilot force to the controls, and partially powered controls, which are aided by hydraulic force, but there is still a mechanical connection between the pilot and controls (think powered steering in a car)
learning.explanation: There are two basic types of flight controls, reversible and irreversible. Reversible flight controls are those that have a two way force mechanism naturally as part of the system. This includes manual flight controls, which use levers and pulleys to transfer pilot force to the controls, and partially powered controls, which are aided by hydraulic force, but there is still a mechanical connection between the pilot and controls (think powered steering in a car). The connecting factor means that if you went to the aileron and pushed it, the controls in the cockpit would move accordingly. The opposite are irreversible controls, which have no "backwards force", or "feel". These are only 1 way, so the pilot can move the control surfaces, but the control surfaces cannot move the pilot's controls. Fully powered hydraulic controls and Fly-By-Wire controls are irreversible. Irreversible controls have no natural feedback, so require artificial "feel", so the pilot has something to push against and the controls naturally centre, etc. If you pushed the aileron, the controls would not move. Therefore, in this scenario, there is no connection at all between the control surfaces and the cockpit controls (especially as the aircraft is powered down, so there is no automatic control centring, etc.). Therefore, if the rudder goes to full deflection by the wind or by someone pushing it, etc., there would be no corresponding movement of the rudder pedals. That would be the case for any irreversible control system, but the rudder pedals would also move if the system were reversible.

learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.05.02.01.07: Explain how a flap/slat asymmetry protection device functions, and describe the implications of a flap/slat asymmetry situation. A flap asymmetry situation can be disastrous. This is because flaps change the coefficient of lift of the wing massively, in order to provide more lift, and therefore allow flight at slower speeds. Flaps can easily double the coefficient of lift from a wing, whilst also increasing the drag, possibly by a lot. An aircraft will fly terribly with a large flap asymmetry, with high drag and high lift on one wing but not the other. A way to avoid this situation is by having a flap/slat asymmetry protection system. This detects the actual flap/slat position in each wing with great accuracy, and as soon as an asymmetry is detected, the system will stop the flaps from moving, and show up a warning or caution to the pilots.
