learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.05.01.05.05: Explain the concept of a rudder deflection limitation (rudder limiter) system and the various means of implementation (rudder ratio changer, variable stops, blow-back). As stated in the Learning Objective above, there are 3 ways to limit rudder deflection, which we want to do at higher airspeeds to limit the forces on the aircraft: Rudder Ratio Changer: The control commands from the rudder pedals and trim control are modified by a rudder ratio changer. As the aircraft speed increases, the rudder deflection must be reduced proportionately within the range of the rudder pedal depression by the pilot => the rudder pedals move through their full range at all speeds, however, rudder deflection is reduced with increasing airspeed. If this automatic reduction is not applied and rudder is fully deflected when the aircraft is in high speed flight, the huge forces could damage the aircraft, or at least cause violent yaw/roll. Variable Stops: The movement of the rudder and the pedal travel are directly proportional to each other. However, as the airspeed increases, the movement of the rudder pedals and the rudder are physically reduced. When the rudder is limited in movement at high speed, the pedal travel is also restricted. This does have the consequence of making the rudder very sensitive at high airspeeds, just not with a very long pedal travel. The figure above shows the allowed deflection of a particular aircraft. Blow-Back: This is a system that applies a constant movement force to the rudder, the force being dictated by the pedal deflection, which then deflects the rudder depending on the speed of the airflow. slower airspeed means that the constant force will deflect the rudder more, whereas fast airspeed would mean the consequent higher dynamic pressure naturally limits the rudder deflection, acting like a more modern rudder ratio changer. The reason that statement 2 is incorrect is that it says the limitations to rudder/rudder pedal deflection occur with decreasing airspeed, but actually it is with increasing airspeed.

The pilot operates the flight deck controls, which in turn operates transducers which convert the mechanical input into an electrical output which is amplified, processed by computers with the processed command signal providing the input to the servo valve which controls the movement of a hydraulic actuator

SYSTEM REDUNDANCY (figure 2) Safeguards to eliminate the possibility of loss of control in the event of hydraulic or electrical failure must be provided on modern transport aircraft. key_points: A Fly-By-Wire (FBW) system represents an advanced method of controlling aircraft flight, where electronic signals replace traditional mechanical inputs
Instead of direct manipulation of physical controls, such as conventional control columns and rudder pedals, pilots interface with flight deck controls like side sticks (as seen in Airbus aircraft)
These inputs are then translated into electrical signals by transducers, which are further enhanced and processed by onboard computers
learning.explanation: A Fly-By-Wire (FBW) system represents an advanced method of controlling aircraft flight, where electronic signals replace traditional mechanical inputs. Instead of direct manipulation of physical controls, such as conventional control columns and rudder pedals, pilots interface with flight deck controls like side sticks (as seen in Airbus aircraft). These inputs are then translated into electrical signals by transducers, which are further enhanced and processed by onboard computers. The processed commands are then transmitted to a servo valve, which, in turn, regulates the movement of a hydraulic actuator, ultimately controlling the aircraft's flight surfaces. FBW systems can be lighter than a conventional system as FBW does not require the heavy control cables. Including FBW provides a significant reduction in fuel consumption. The FBW systems also provide flight envelope protection by preventing the pilot pitching the aircraft beyond the stalling angle of attack. It will also allow the pilot to operate the controls positively up to the 2.5g limit without fear of overstressing the aircraft.

Basically, it is the reduced mode of operation which provides most features of normal law. Direct Law is the lowest level of fly-by-wire system and directly transmits the pilot inputs to control surfaces, while still giving stall and load factor warnings. In Direct Law, autopilot function is always lost. Mechanical back up. In case all of the above fail, the system reverts to mechanical backup, where pitch control is achieved through the horizontal stabilizer and lateral control is accomplished using the rudder pedals. The purpose of the backup system is to allow control of the aircraft following a total loss of electrics, flight control computers, elevators, or ailerons and spoilers In case of mechanical backup, the system will operate as long as hydraulic power is available. In case of electrical failure, as long as hydraulics are OK, the pilot should be able to control the aircraft.

options.A: Increased pilot workload due to decreased flight protection envelope.
options.B: Decreased pilot workload to allow pilots to carry out sufficient safety checks, etc.
options.C: Increased pilot workload due to increased stall protection.
options.D: No change to pilot workload, as the aircraft will still allow a stall to occur.

key_points: Note: This question is based on incomplete feedback
Please put any further exam feedback in the comments or email it to info@atplquestions
com, thank you
learning.explanation: Note: This question is based on incomplete feedback. Please put any further exam feedback in the comments or email it to info@atplquestions.com, thank you. Fly-By-Wire flight controls offer many benefits to an aircraft, one of the largest being the addition of flight envelope protection. Provided the FBW system functions at its normal level, this significantly enhances safety. Feedback control of airspeed, Mach Number, attitude, and angle of attack can be used to ensure that the FBW aircraft stays within its certificated flight envelope. For instance, on the Airbus, the flight mode of Normal Law provides five types of protection: pitch attitude, load factor limitations, overspeed, high-AoA/low airspeed and bank angle. At high angles of attack/low airspeeds, sometimes called high alpha, Fly-By-Wire systems have certain protections to prevent the aircraft stalling. Take Airbus for instance, their aircraft have alpha prot., alpha floor, and alpha max. Each level increases the amount of protections, from automatically beginning a descent to remain at a safe speed (alpha prot.) all the way up to alpha max, which the pilots cannot physically exceed (whilst in normal law). These protections reduce pilot workload, by allowing the pilots to think about things other than flying the aircraft near the stall. This could allow the pilots to complete checks or drills and secure the situation.

content.question: Consider a partially powered flight control system. Which of the following statements is true?

options.A: It automatically adjusts the flight controls without pilot input to maintain the flight path.
options.B: It allows the pilot to feel the aerodynamic load on the flight controls.
options.C: It completely isolates the pilot from feeling any feedback through the flight controls.
options.D: It uses electronic signals and computers to translate pilot inputs into control surface movement, with no mechanical connection.

key_points: There are 4 main types of control system: Manual - cables and pulleys connect the flight controls to the control surfaces directly
The only power supplied is by the pilot
Partially powered/Power assisted controls - The pilot is mechanically connected to the controls, but any force they exert will be assisted by extra force from the hydraulics
learning.explanation: There are 4 main types of control system: Manual - cables and pulleys connect the flight controls to the control surfaces directly. The only power supplied is by the pilot. Partially powered/Power assisted controls - The pilot is mechanically connected to the controls, but any force they exert will be assisted by extra force from the hydraulics. Similar to powered steering in a car. Fully powered controls - The flight controls physically move a servo valve which directs hydraulic pressure to the controls. No computers involved, but hydraulic pressure is absolutely required. Fly-by-wire - A type of fully powered control system where the flight control movements are interpreted by a computer which electronically controls the hydraulic servo valves to move the control surfaces. The hydraulics still provide the power to move the control surfaces, but a computer sits between the pilot and the hydraulics, checking and modifying the requested movements. Fly-by-wire and fully powered controls are "irreversible", meaning that there is no feedback from the control surfaces to the pilot. This means that an artificial feel system has to be installed, so the pilot can feel the correct amount of resistance when moving the controls. This is not the case on manual or power assisted (partially powered) control systems, which are "reversible", and have natural feedback to the flight controls. Power assisted controls do not have as much feedback as manual controls of course, as the hydraulic system takes most of the force, but the pilot will feel a certain percentage of it, and the feel force does come from the actual aerodynamic forces acting on the control surface.

content.question: What is the basic principle of a fully manual flight control system?

options.A: The flight control surfaces are connected to the flight deck controls by means of mechanical links only.
options.B: The deflection angle of the flight control surface will vary with airspeed, therefore, the flight control forces are constant.
options.C: A fully manual flight control system is an irreversible system because there is no flight deck flight control feedback when a flight control surface is in motion.
options.D: A fully manual flight control system is manually operated by the pilot by means of the flight control elements and is powered by a hydraulic system.

key_points: A fully manual flight control system would be a reversible control system, meaning the forces applied on the controls are the forces moving the control surfaces and vice versa
This are connected by mechanical links only and aren’t powered in any way
Primary flight controls Are controls which movement causes a rotation about one of the three axes of the aircraft, causing a change in the aircraft’s flightpath or attitude
learning.explanation: A fully manual flight control system would be a reversible control system, meaning the forces applied on the controls are the forces moving the control surfaces and vice versa. This are connected by mechanical links only and aren’t powered in any way. Primary flight controls Are controls which movement causes a rotation about one of the three axes of the aircraft, causing a change in the aircraft’s flightpath or attitude. The elevator, rudder and ailerons are considered to be the primary flight controls. The primary flight controls in a manually controlled system are reversible. This means that a force applied to the controls is a force which moves the control surface, and also a force which moves the control surface will move the pilot’s controls. This means that the air pressure on the control surface can be felt in the pilot’s controls. When the flight controls are fully power operated this is not the case and is called irreversible. This means that if there is a force moving the control surface this will not move the control columns, and there will be no natural feel on the controls. Because of this there will need to be an artificial feel unit installed in a fully powered or irreversible control system. This artificial feel unit should apply force to the cockpit controls in proportion to the control deflection and in proportion to the aircraft’s speed. This artificial feel system will also work with a trim system, but this works different than a normal trim surface does. In the figure in the annex you can see how the trim of the artificial feel unit works. A movement of the trimwheel will result in a movement of the electric trim actuator, and so the control surface, but not in the movement of the control column (this is for elevator control). It is different for aileron and rudder trim. Elevator trim: zero force position of the control column does not change (control column/horn/stick does not move) Aileron trim: zero force position changes (control wheel turns in the direction of the trim) Rudder trim: zero force position changes (pedals move in the direction of the trim)

content.question: A large transport aircraft is fitted with flight spoilers, speed brakes, trailing-edge flaps, and a moveable horizontal stabiliser. If this aircraft’s ailerons are jammed, roll control may be achieved by using the…

options.A: horizontal stabiliser.
options.B: speed brakes.
options.C: flight spoilers.
options.D: differential flaps.

key_points: Flight spoilers Flight spoilers are fitted on the upper side of the surface of the wing which can be raised
They may be used to give directional control together, or instead of the ailerons
When a flight spoiler is raised it disturbs the flow over the wing causing a decrease in lift
learning.explanation: Flight spoilers Flight spoilers are fitted on the upper side of the surface of the wing which can be raised. They may be used to give directional control together, or instead of the ailerons. When a flight spoiler is raised it disturbs the flow over the wing causing a decrease in lift. When the flight spoilers are used for lateral control, on the wing that is meant to go down, the spoilers will extend while the spoilers on the up going wing remain retracted. Unlike ailerons, spoilers will not increase lift and so the use of spoilers instead of ailerons will cause a decrease in lift, this however will give some advantages over ailerons. As the raised spoiler will increase drag, the yaw directions will be in the same direction as the roll, therefore there will be no adverse yaw. When flying at transonic speeds there will be no shock induced, so the effectiveness stays the same. Because the spoilers are not located at the end of the wings there will be less wing twisting because the loss of lift will be distributed more even across the wingchord. Flight spoilers can also be used as speedbrakes, these can be used either in the air or on the ground. When on the ground the spoilers will be extended further than when in the air. When spoilers are used as speedbrakes their deflection will be symmetrical other than for lateral control when the deflection will be asymmetrical.

content.question: Trailing edge flaps on large transport aircraft are normally powered…

options.A: hydraulically with electrical back-up.
options.B: manually with electrical back-up.
options.C: pneumatically with hydraulic back-up.
options.D: electrically with hydraulic back-up.

key_points: Flaps There are numerous types of flap designs which increase lift and drag in varying amounts
For light aircraft the most popular type is the plain or camber flap
For large transport aircraft the most used is the slotted Fowler flaps
learning.explanation: Flaps There are numerous types of flap designs which increase lift and drag in varying amounts. For light aircraft the most popular type is the plain or camber flap. For large transport aircraft the most used is the slotted Fowler flaps. (see different types in the image in the annex) In the cockpit there will be a selector where the pilot selects the desired flap setting, the input from this selector will be the input for the slat/flap control computers which control, test and monitor the operation of the flaps and slats. This computer’s output will be the input for an electrically controlled hydro-mechanical unit, a hydraulic motor, which drive the transmission which moves the flaps. The position of the flaps is measured with sensors and is indicated in the cockpit. The flaps are protected against asymmetric operation, runaway and over speed. The flap load relief system, or load limiter will retract the flaps to an intermediate position when the airspeed exceeds a predetermined speed. Once the speed has decreased below this speed, the flaps will be automatically returned to the selected flap setting. If the main hydraulic system fails, the emergency operation might be via an alternate hydraulic system or an electric motor which operates the same gear train as the normal operating system.

content.question: In a Fly-By-Wire (FBW) aircraft controlled by sidesticks, how can a pilot lock out the flight control inputs of the other pilot?

options.A: By pressing and holding the autopilot engage button.
options.B: By pressing and holding the radio push-to-talk (PTT) button.
options.C: By performing a long push on the sidestick priority button.
options.D: By performing a rapid double tap on the sidestick priority button.

key_points: In a Fly-By-Wire system such as the Airbus A320, amongst others, both pilots have a sidestick which is a major input into the fly-by-wire control system
As these sidesticks are not mechanically linked like other, there needs to be a way for both pilots to make inputs at once
The standard system for this is for both inputs to be "algebraically summed" together, which is a complex way of saying that both sticks get an input into the control system
learning.explanation: In a Fly-By-Wire system such as the Airbus A320, amongst others, both pilots have a sidestick which is a major input into the fly-by-wire control system. As these sidesticks are not mechanically linked like other, there needs to be a way for both pilots to make inputs at once. The standard system for this is for both inputs to be "algebraically summed" together, which is a complex way of saying that both sticks get an input into the control system. This is called dual input. In case that it occurs, an aural warning “DUAL INPUT” and a flashing warning light in sight of each pilot is provided. To allow one pilot to take over controls from the other, which might be necessary in case of incapacitation, etc., a red take-over button is installed on each sidestick that disables the stick on the other side when held. This button works as an autopilot disconnect when pushed once, but when it is pushed and held, it removes the other pilot's inputs from the system, and after 40 seconds of holding (A320 specific) the other pilot is "locked out" from inputs until they push their own prioirty button. When this condition occurs, an aural warning is provided “PRIORITY LEFT/RIGHT”, indicating the active sidestick.

content.question: What is the function of the hydraulic control valves in a fullypowered flight control system?

options.A: The control valves control the movement of the hydraulic actuators.
options.B: Fully powered flight control systems operate actuators without control valves.
options.C: The actuators operate the control valves, which in turn move the control surfaces.
options.D: Control valves convert hydraulic pressure into control column movement.

key_points: In a hydraulically powered flight control system the pilot operates the controls, these can be a sidestick and rudder pedals or a conventional yoke with rudder pedals
These controls are fitted with transducers which convert the mechanical movement into an electrical output which is then amplified and processed by several computers
These computers provide the input for the servo valves which controls the movement of the hydraulic actuators attached to the flight control surfaces

These controls are fitted with transducers which convert the mechanical movement into an electrical output which is then amplified and processed by several computers. These computers provide the input for the servo valves which controls the movement of the hydraulic actuators attached to the flight control surfaces.

content.question: What is correct regarding the Airbus fly-by-wire philosophy?

options.A: The level of safety required for commercial operations is easily achieved when FBW relies on a single computer controlling all the control surfaces
options.B: In Mechanical Law, the aircraft can be controlled manually using the pitch trim and the rudders, however a landing was never demonstrated using this mode
options.C: The Airbus system has a normal operating mode and five reversionary modes, described by Airbus as "laws"
options.D: In Alternate Law the system will still provide the basic control laws but angle of attack protection and other protections may be lost

key_points: The fly-by-wire system has multiple redundancies that offer layered protection: Normal Law offers all the protections (like stall, load factor etc)
This is the system in operation during normal flights
Normal Law operates in different modes depending on the stage of flight
learning.explanation: The fly-by-wire system has multiple redundancies that offer layered protection: Normal Law offers all the protections (like stall, load factor etc). This is the system in operation during normal flights. Normal Law operates in different modes depending on the stage of flight. These modes include: Ground Mode Flight Mode Flare Mode Alternate Law offers limited protection including stability, load factor and stall protections. Basically, it is the reduced mode of operation which provides most features of normal law. Direct Law is the lowest level of fly-by-wire system and directly transmits the pilot inputs to control surfaces, while still giving stall and load factor warnings Mechanical back up. In case all of the above fail, the system reverts to mechanical backup, where pitch control is achieved through the horizontal stabilizer and lateral control is accomplished using the rudder pedals. The purpose of the backup system is to allow control of the aircraft following a total loss of electrics, flight control computers, elevators, or ailerons and spoilers In case of mechanical backup, the system will operate as long as hydraulic power is available. In case of electrical failure, as long as hydraulics are OK, the pilot should be able to control the aircraft. Note: Type related questions are out of the scope of ATPL learning objectives. However, even though Boeing and Airbus call these a bit different, the principle stays the same.

content.question: A flight control surface actuator is said to be "reversible" when…

options.A: there is feedback to the pilot`s controls of the aerodynamic forces acting on the control surface.
options.B: there is a need to have an artificial feel system.
options.C: the flight control system has an alternate means of control in case of a control jam.
options.D: the pilot does not feel any force when moving that flight control surface in flight.

key_points: Primary flight controls Are controls which movement causes a rotation about one of the three axes of the aircraft, causing a change in the aircraft’s flightpath or attitude
The elevator, rudder and ailerons are considered to be the primary flight controls
The primary flight controls in a manually controlled system are reversible
learning.explanation: Primary flight controls Are controls which movement causes a rotation about one of the three axes of the aircraft, causing a change in the aircraft’s flightpath or attitude. The elevator, rudder and ailerons are considered to be the primary flight controls. The primary flight controls in a manually controlled system are reversible. This means that a force applied to the controls is a force which moves the control surface, and also a force which moves the control surface will move the pilot’s controls. This means that the air pressure on the control surface can be felt in the pilot’s controls. When the flight controls are fully power operated this is not the case and is called irreversible. This means that if there is a force moving the control surface this will not move the control columns, and there will be no natural feel on the controls. Because of this there will need to be an artificial feel unit installed in a fully powered or irreversible control system. This artificial feel unit should apply force to the cockpit controls in proportion to the control deflection and in proportion to the aircraft’s speed. The artificial feel system is placed in parallel with the hydraulic actuator, so the movement of the flight controls in the cockpit will cause the hydraulic actuator to operate. During this same movement the artificial feel system will apply pressure on the controls appropriate to the airspeed of the aircraft. This artificial feel system will also work with a trim system, but this works different than a normal trim surface does. A movement of the trimwheel will result in a movement of the electric trim actuator, and so the control surface, but not in the movement of the control column (this is for elevator control). It is different for aileron and rudder trim. Elevator trim: zero force position of the control column does not change (control column/horn/stick does not move) Aileron trim: zero force position changes (control wheel turns in the direction of the trim) Rudder trim: zero force position changes (pedals move in the direction of the trim)

content.question: On a large transport aeroplane, the auto-slat system…

options.A: ensures that the (part of) slats are always extended when the ground/flight system is in the “ground” position”.
options.B: provides for automatic slat retraction after take-off.
options.C: assist the ailerons.
options.D: extends (part of) the slats automatically when a certain value of angle of attack is exceeded.

key_points: Slats Slats are aerodynamic surfaces on the leading edge of the wings of fixed-wing aircraft which, when deployed, allow the wing to operate at a higher angle of attack
A higher coefficient of lift is produced as a result of angle of attack and speed, so by deploying slats an aircraft can fly at slower speeds, or take off and land in shorter distances
They are usually used while landing or performing manoeuvres which take the aircraft close to the stall, but are usually retracted in normal flight to minimize drag
learning.explanation: Slats Slats are aerodynamic surfaces on the leading edge of the wings of fixed-wing aircraft which, when deployed, allow the wing to operate at a higher angle of attack. A higher coefficient of lift is produced as a result of angle of attack and speed, so by deploying slats an aircraft can fly at slower speeds, or take off and land in shorter distances. They are usually used while landing or performing manoeuvres which take the aircraft close to the stall, but are usually retracted in normal flight to minimize drag. They decrease stall speed. Some aircraft have an autoslat function which will extend the slats automatically if the wing is about to stall. Usually this autoslat function has some conditions before it will function which can be airspeed, flaps and slats settings. When the stall condition ceases the autoslat system will retract the slats.

content.question: When large transport aeroplanes are flying at high speed, full rudder deflection would cause excessive loads on the structure. What system is fitted to the rudder to prevent this happening?

options.A: Rudder trim system.
options.B: Fully powered rudder control.
options.C: Rudder ratio or rudder travel changer.
options.D: Yaw damper system.

key_points: With a simple control system, full rudder pedal movement will provide full rudder deflection
With high speed aircraft, while it is necessary to have large rudder deflections available at low speed, when flying at high speed, full rudder deflection would cause excessive loads on the structure
To prevent this occurring, a gear change system can be incorporated into the rudder control system
learning.explanation: With a simple control system, full rudder pedal movement will provide full rudder deflection. With high speed aircraft, while it is necessary to have large rudder deflections available at low speed, when flying at high speed, full rudder deflection would cause excessive loads on the structure. To prevent this occurring, a gear change system can be incorporated into the rudder control system. This may be a single gear change which gives a smaller rudder deflection for full pedal movement above a certain speed (Variable Stop), or a progressive gear change which gives a decreasing rudder deflection with full pedal movement as speed increases (Rudder Ratio).

content.question: You are flying a Fly-By-Wire aircraft which is operating using direct law. What are the possible implications of this?

options.A: Roll and pitch augmentation are lost but you still have aural and visual alerts.
options.B: Roll augmentation is lost but you still have pitch augmentation.
options.C: Roll and pitch augmentation are lost.
options.D: Pitch augmentation is lost but you still have roll augmentation.

key_points: Fly-By-Wire aircraft have certain control modes, or "laws"
Boeing and Airbus name these differently, but they are somewhat similar in concept

Airbus uses: Normal Law Alternate Law Direct Law Boeing uses: Normal Mode Secondary Mode Direct Mode EASA tend to prefer questions relating to Airbus fly-by-wire systems, hence they have said "direct law" in the question
learning.explanation: Fly-By-Wire aircraft have certain control modes, or "laws". Boeing and Airbus name these differently, but they are somewhat similar in concept. Airbus uses: Normal Law Alternate Law Direct Law Boeing uses: Normal Mode Secondary Mode Direct Mode EASA tend to prefer questions relating to Airbus fly-by-wire systems, hence they have said "direct law" in the question. A quick run-down of the control laws (primarily Airbus, but these small descriptions fit Boeing's modes well). Normal Law - All control augmentations and protections are in place. Alternate Law - Some protections are lost, some features act differently to normal, and the autopilot may be lost (depending on the fault). Direct Law - In direct law, the pilot's controls are NOT augmented at all by the internal computers (for flight envelope protection, etc.), and the exact control movement is sent exactly as it is to the hydraulic servo valves. Autopilot is always lost. Stall and over speed warnings are still available.

content.question:
Which of these statements about rudder limiting are correct or incorrect?
I. A rudder ratio changer system reduces the rudder deflection for a given rudder pedal deflection as the IAS increases
II. A variable stop system limits both rudder and rudder pedal deflection as the IAS increases

options.A: I is incorrect, II is correct.
options.B: I is incorrect, II is incorrect.
options.C: I is correct, II is correct.
options.D: I is correct, II is incorrect.

key_points: "I
A rudder ratio changer system reduces the rudder deflection for a given rudder pedal deflection as the IAS increases
" Correct
learning.explanation: "I. A rudder ratio changer system reduces the rudder deflection for a given rudder pedal deflection as the IAS increases." Correct. Rudder Ratio Changer: The control commands from the rudder pedals and trim control are modified by a rudder ratio changer. As the aircraft speed inscreases, the rudder deflection must be reduced proportionately within the range of the rudder pedal depression by the pilot => the rudder peddals move through their full range at all speeds, however, rudder deflection is reduced with increasing airspeed. If this automatic reduction is not applied and rudder is fully deflected when the aircraft is in high speed flight, it will may cause the plane to sharply and violently yaw. "II. A variable stop system limits both rudder and rudder pedal deflection as the IAS increases." Correct. Variable Stop System: The movement of the rudder and pedal travel are proportional. However, as the airspeed increases, the movement of the rudder pedals and the rudder are physically reduced. When the rudder is limited in movement at high speed, the pedal travel is also restricted.

content.question: Given a conventional transport aeroplane with irreversible flight controls on the ground with engines running. Which of these statements is correct when rudder trim is used?

options.A: The rudder trim tab moves and the rudder pedals do not move.
options.B: The zero force point of the artificial feel system changes, the rudder does not move.
options.C: The rudder moves, the rudder pedals do not move.
options.D: The rudder moves, the rudder pedals move in the corresponding direction.

key_points: Flight controls Primary flight controls Are controls which movement causes a rotation about one of the three axes of the aircraft, causing a change in the aircraft’s flightpath or attitude
The elevator, rudder and ailerons are considered to be the primary flight controls
The primary flight controls in a manually controlled system are reversible
learning.explanation: Flight controls Primary flight controls Are controls which movement causes a rotation about one of the three axes of the aircraft, causing a change in the aircraft’s flightpath or attitude. The elevator, rudder and ailerons are considered to be the primary flight controls. The primary flight controls in a manually controlled system are reversible. This means that a force applied to the controls is a force which moves the control surface, and also a force which moves the control surface will move the pilot’s controls. This means that the air pressure on the control surface can be felt in the pilot’s controls. When the flight controls are fully power operated this is not the case and is called irreversible. This means that if there is a force moving the control surface this will not move the control columns, and there will be no natural feel on the controls. Because of this there will need to be an artificial feel unit installed in a fully powered or irreversible control system. This artificial feel unit should apply force to the cockpit controls in proportion to the control deflection and in proportion to the aircraft’s speed. This artificial feel system will also work with a trim system, but this works different than a normal trim surface does. In the figure in the annex you can see how the trim of the artificial feel unit works. A movement of the trimwheel will result in a movement of the electric trim actuator, and so the control surface, but not in the movement of the control column (this is for elevator control). It is different for aileron and rudder trim. Elevator trim: zero force position of the control column does not change (control column/horn/stick does not move) Aileron trim: zero force position changes (control wheel turns in the direction of the trim) Rudder trim: zero force position changes (pedals move in the direction of the trim)

content.question: A parked airplane has its rudder deflected fully right with the rudder pedals in neutral position, while it’s powered down. The flight control system is considered to be…

options.A: partially powered.
options.B: fully powered.
options.C: reversible.
options.D: fully manual.

key_points: There are two basic types of flight controls, reversible and irreversible
Reversible flight controls are those that have a two way force mechanism naturally as part of the system

This includes manual flight controls, which use levers and pulleys to transfer pilot force to the controls, and partially powered controls, which are aided by hydraulic force, but there is still a mechanical connection between the pilot and controls (the same as powered steering in a car)
learning.explanation: There are two basic types of flight controls, reversible and irreversible. Reversible flight controls are those that have a two way force mechanism naturally as part of the system. This includes manual flight controls, which use levers and pulleys to transfer pilot force to the controls, and partially powered controls, which are aided by hydraulic force, but there is still a mechanical connection between the pilot and controls (the same as powered steering in a car). The connecting factor means that if you went to the aileron and pushed it, the controls in the cockpit would move accordingly. The opposite are irreversible controls, which have no "backwards force", or "feel". These are only 1 way, so the pilot can move the control surfaces, but the control surfaces cannot move the pilot's controls. Fully powered hydraulic controls and fly-by-wire controls are irreversible. Irreversible controls have no natural feedback, so require artificial "feel", so the pilot has something to push against and the controls naturally centre, etc. If you pushed the aileron, the controls would not move. Therefore, in this scenario, there is no connection at all between the control surfaces and the cockpit controls (especially as the aircraft is powered down, so there is no automatic control centring, etc.). Therefore, if the rudder goes to full deflection by the wind or by someone pushing it, etc., there would be no corresponding movement of the rudder pedals. That would be the case for any irreversible control system, but the rudder pedals would also move if the system were reversible. Therefore, the flight controls on the aircraft described must be fully powered, out of that selection of options.

options.A: Secondary mode
options.B: Alternate law
options.C: Normal law
options.D: Direct law

key_points: The Fly-By-Wire system has multiple redundancies that offer layered protection: Normal Law offers all the protections (like stall, load factor etc)
This is the system in operation during normal flights
Normal Law operates in different modes depending on the stage of flight
learning.explanation: The Fly-By-Wire system has multiple redundancies that offer layered protection: Normal Law offers all the protections (like stall, load factor etc). This is the system in operation during normal flights. Normal Law operates in different modes depending on the stage of flight. These modes include: Ground Mode Flight Mode Flare Mode Alternate Law offers limited protection including stability, load factor and stall protections. Basically, it is the reduced mode of operation which provides most features of normal law. Direct Law is the lowest level of fly-by-wire system and directly transmits the pilot inputs to control surfaces, while still giving stall and load factor warnings Mechanical back up. In case all of the above fail, the system reverts to mechanical backup, where pitch control is achieved through the horizontal stabilizer and lateral control is accomplished using the rudder pedals. The purpose of the backup system is to allow control of the aircraft following a total loss of electrics, flight control computers, elevators, or ailerons and spoilers In case of mechanical backup, the system will operate as long as hydraulic power is available. In case of electrical failure, as long as hydraulics are OK, the pilot should be able to control the aircraft. Note: Type related questions are out of the scope of ATPL learning objectives. However, even though Boeing and Airbus call these a bit different, the principle stays the same.

The pilot operates the controls, these can be a sidestick and rudder pedals or a conventional yoke with rudder pedals
These controls are fitted with transducers which convert the mechanical movement into an electrical output which is then amplified and processed by several computers
learning.explanation: Fly-By-Wire systems A fly by wire control system is a fully powered flight control system (irreversible) that uses electronic inputs to a solenoid servo valve instead of mechanical inputs from conventional powered controls. The pilot operates the controls, these can be a sidestick and rudder pedals or a conventional yoke with rudder pedals. These controls are fitted with transducers which convert the mechanical movement into an electrical output which is then amplified and processed by several computers. These computers provide the input for the servo valves which controls the movement of the hydraulic actuators attached to the flight control surfaces. Advantages of Fly-By-Wire Weight reduction, as there is no need for the long and heavy control cables this is a big reduction in the weight of the aircraft. Pilot work load is reduced because the pilot is supported by the computers with automated features like auto trim and turn coordination. Auto-trim will continuously change the "zero point" of the flight control system, and therefore needs no input from the pilot usually, reducing workload. Flight envelope protection, which can prevent the pilot from pitching up too much beyond the stalling angle of attack. It can limit the controls in such a way that the airframe will not endure G forces out of the limits. Auto-trim will continuously change the "zero point" of the flight control system, and therefore needs no input from the pilot usually, reducing workload. It operates within the usual flight envelope as an integral part of the fly-by-wire system, and operates just fine with flaps/slats extended or retracted.

content.question: In the event of a flap overspeed, a flap load relief system will...

options.A: partially extend the flight spoilers to reduce the load factor, to prevent flap damage.
options.B: retract the trailing-edge flaps to an intermediate position, to protect the flaps.
options.C: lock movement of the flap lever towards the extended direction, to avoid a flap overload.
options.D: block trailing-edge flap movement if an asymmetry or misalignment is detected, to limit the flap loads.

key_points: Flaps take quite a lot of force in normal operation due to the heavy aerodynamic load they have to withstand
This increases with the square of the velocity, and can become really very large
Flaps are therefore made to be very strong, but as they are only useful in the lower speed range, they are not built to be used at high airspeeds
learning.explanation: Flaps take quite a lot of force in normal operation due to the heavy aerodynamic load they have to withstand. This increases with the square of the velocity, and can become really very large. Flaps are therefore made to be very strong, but as they are only useful in the lower speed range, they are not built to be used at high airspeeds. Each flap setting has a VFE speed, which is the maximum flaps extended speed. Above this speed, the flaps will take too much load, and could be damaged. Modern jet transport aircraft often have a flap load relief system, which detects flap overspeed, and can disengage the flap lock, allowing the airflow to push the flaps to a lower setting, or some intermediate value, so that the flaps do not get damaged. Some systems use hydraulic pressure and physically move the flaps using the standard system, whereas others use the "blowback" system mentioned above.

content.question: On Airbus aircraft, both sidesticks are not mechanically linked, so can operate independently of each other. How does a pilot take control over the other sidestick?

options.A: There is a switch button with positions left/neutral/right.
options.B: Both sidesticks add a signal to the system which calculates the input.
options.C: Only the left sidestick (captain) has a priority push-button to take control over the other sidestick.
options.D: A priority push-button is provided on each stick. By pressing this button, a pilot may cancel the inputs of the other pilot.

key_points: In a Fly-By-Wire system such as the Airbus A320, amongst others, both pilots have a sidestick which is a major input into the fly-by-wire control system
As these sidesticks are not mechanically linked like other, there needs to be a way for both pilots to make inputs at once
The standard system for this is for both inputs to be "algebraically summed" together, which is a complex way of saying that both sticks get an input into the control system
learning.explanation: In a Fly-By-Wire system such as the Airbus A320, amongst others, both pilots have a sidestick which is a major input into the fly-by-wire control system. As these sidesticks are not mechanically linked like other, there needs to be a way for both pilots to make inputs at once. The standard system for this is for both inputs to be "algebraically summed" together, which is a complex way of saying that both sticks get an input into the control system. This is called dual input. In case that it occurs, an aural warning “DUAL INPUT” and a flashing warning light in sight of each pilot is provided. To allow one pilot to take over controls from the other, which might be necessary in case of incapacitation, etc., a red take-over button is installed on each sidestick that disables the stick on the other side when held. When this condition occurs, an aural warning is provided “PRIORITY LEFT/RIGHT”, indicating the active sidestick.

content.question: Consider the following situation, the rudder ratio limiter of an aircraft gets stuck in high speed/high altitude mode when decelerating for the approach. Which of the following statements is correct?

options.A: Increased maximum operating speed.
options.B: Reduced crosswind limitation.
options.C: Greater rudder authority during approach.
options.D: A greater flap setting will be required.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.05.01.05.05: Explain the concept of a rudder deflection limitation (rudder limiter) system and the various means of implementation (rudder ratio changer, variable stops, blow-back). One of the problems with rudders is that they need to be very large and have a large maximum deflection for adequate directional control in the case of an engine failure during take-off or at low speeds, when there is very little airflow, but if this large rudder had a large deflection at the high cruise speeds of a jet aircraft, it could easily break the tail of the aircraft off with the extreme forces. There are a few methods to remove this problem, rudder ratio changers, variable stops, and blow-back. Rudder Ratio Changer: The control commands from the rudder pedals and trim control are modified by a rudder ratio changer. As the aircraft speed increases, the rudder deflection must be reduced proportionately within the range of the rudder pedal depression by the pilot => the rudder pedals move through their full range at all speeds, however, rudder deflection is reduced with increasing airspeed. This rudder ratio changer can be continuous, as described above, or can be a discreet change at a certain airspeed, like changing gears in a car. If this automatic reduction in rudder authority is not applied and rudder is fully deflected when the aircraft is in high speed flight, the huge forces could damage the aircraft, or at least cause violent yaw/roll. Conversely, if the rudder remains in the high-speed, low deflection mode, then there will be insufficient rudder authority to handle engine failures and crosswind landings at low speeds. This means that the approach will have added limitations, such as a higher minimum approach speed and a reduced crosswind limit. The annex above is an extract from the ATR 72 FCOM, an aircraft which does have a discreet rudder ratio changer (called a TLU - Travel Limiting Unit - in the manual) that changes rudder deflection at 180 kts, and the procedure for if a fault occurs. Notice that within the area of the red box, the procedure for if the fault is not resolved (or unsure if resolved) is to increase the VAPP (approach speed) by 10 kt (with associated increased landing distance) and land at an airport with the lowest crosswind, max demonstrated crosswind is 15 kt. To address the other options: The maximum operating speed will not increase, only the minimum. The rudder authority will be less than usual. The flap setting would not need to be greater, as the approach will be faster, so if anything, less flaps may be needed.

The sidesticks are connected digitally to the FBW system to provide input for aileron and elevator control

content.question:
How can you disengage autopilot?
1) disengage FBW
2) press and hold priority button
3) disengage on MCP
4) forcefully move the control column

key_points: This question is quite shocking to be honest
The examiner is mixing Boeing and Airbus philosophy
Definitely teaching the wrong thing
learning.explanation: This question is quite shocking to be honest. The examiner is mixing Boeing and Airbus philosophy. Definitely teaching the wrong thing. But here we go, statement 1 is definitely incorrect: "1) disengage FBW." INCORRECT. FBW describes those flight control systems which use computers to process the flight control inputs made by the pilot or autopilot, and send corresponding electrical signals to the flight control surface actuators. It is definitely not possible to disengage the FBW. "2) press and hold priority button." CORRECT. The sidestick priority logic is only valid when the autopilot is disconnected as it manages who has control when sidestick inputs are made on both sidesticks at the same time. If you press that button at any time it disconnects the autopilot. Press and hold it you have priority. Computers will disregard the other sidestick’s inputs. Press it continuously for 40 secs and it permanently locks the other sidestick out unless the other pilot presses his button. "3) disengage on MCP." CORRECT. I believe they might be referring to the A/P disengage bar which is found on the MCP of Boeing airplanes. If you press this bar down, the A/P disengages. "4) forcefully move the control column." CORRECT. This is known as column or wheel force override and is present in some aircraft, especially small aircraft.

learning.explanation: In a Fly-By-Wire system such as the Airbus A320, amongst others, both pilots have a sidestick which is a major input into the Fly-By-Wire control system. As these sidesticks are not mechanically linked like other, there needs to be a way for both pilots to make inputs at once. The standard system for this is for both inputs to be "algebraically summed" together, which is a complex way of saying that both sticks get an input into the control system. This is called dual input. In case that it occurs, an aural warning “DUAL INPUT” and a flashing warning light in sight of each pilot is provided. Even if both controls were deflected fully in the same direction, the sum of the two controls would be no more than the usual full deflection. Otherwise both pilots would have to make an input to get full control deflection, which would be silly. To allow one pilot to take over controls from the other, which might be necessary in case of incapacitation, etc., a red take-over button is installed on each sidestick that disables the stick on the other side. key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.05.04.01.07 For aircraft using sidestick for manual control, describe the implications of: dual control input made by the pilot; the control takeover facility available to the pilot. In a Fly-By-Wire system such as the Airbus A320, amongst others, both pilots have a sidestick which is a major input into the Fly-By-Wire control system. As these sidesticks are not mechanically linked like others, there needs to be a known output for if both pilots make inputs at once. The standard system for this is for both inputs to be "algebraically summed" together, which is a complex way of saying that both sticks get an input into the control system. This is called dual input. In case that it occurs, an aural warning “DUAL INPUT” and a flashing warning light in sight of each pilot is provided. To allow one pilot to take over controls from the other, which might be necessary in case of incapacitation, etc., a red take-over button is installed on each sidestick that disables the stick on the other side. When this condition occurs, an aural warning is provided “PRIORITY LEFT/RIGHT”, and a lasting visual indication of some kind (in this case, a red arrow on the sidestick priority light) indicating the active sidestick.

learning.explanation: 021.05.04.01.02: State the advantages of an FBW system in comparison with a conventional flight control system including: weight; pilot workload; flight-envelope protection. Fly-By-Wire (FBW) systems have several advantages over conventional mechanical flight control systems. Wires and electronic connections are significantly lighter than mechanical structural elements. The reduced weight allows for fitting redundant components, most sophisticated systems feature redundant flight control computers and separate computer systems for flight control without making control systems too heavy. Moreover, FBW system computers offer very sophisticated flight-envelope protections. The computers limit the orders to ensure the protection limits are not exceeded. FBW control systems incorporate redundancy on all levels of the control system. Increased number of systems allows safe continuation of flight in case of a system loss.

key_points: Slats Slats are aerodynamic surfaces on the leading edge of the wings of fixed-wing aircraft which, when deployed, allow the wing to operate at a higher angle of attack
A higher coefficient of lift is produced as a result of angle of attack and speed, so by deploying slats an aircraft can fly at slower speeds, or take off and land in shorter distances
They are usually used while landing or performing manoeuvres which take the aircraft close to the stall, but are usually retracted in normal flight to minimize drag
learning.explanation: Slats Slats are aerodynamic surfaces on the leading edge of the wings of fixed-wing aircraft which, when deployed, allow the wing to operate at a higher angle of attack. A higher coefficient of lift is produced as a result of angle of attack and speed, so by deploying slats an aircraft can fly at slower speeds, or take off and land in shorter distances. They are usually used while landing or performing manoeuvres which take the aircraft close to the stall, but are usually retracted in normal flight to minimize drag. They decrease stall speed. Usually this autoslat function has some conditions before it will function which can be airspeed, flaps and slats settings. When the stall condition ceases the autoslat system will retract the slats. With an autoslat system the aircraft has improved stall characteristics as with high angles of attack the stall speed is reduced.

options.D: To reduce the risk of entering a spiral divergence in cruise.

key_points: With a simple control system, full rudder pedal movement will provide full rudder deflection
With high speed aircraft, while it is necessary to have large rudder deflections available at low speed, when flying at high speed, full rudder deflection would cause excessive loads on the structure
To prevent this occurring, a gear change system can be incorporated into the rudder control system
learning.explanation: With a simple control system, full rudder pedal movement will provide full rudder deflection. With high speed aircraft, while it is necessary to have large rudder deflections available at low speed, when flying at high speed, full rudder deflection would cause excessive loads on the structure. To prevent this occurring, a gear change system can be incorporated into the rudder control system. This may be a single gear change which gives a smaller rudder deflection for full pedal movement above a certain speed, or a progressive gear change which gives a decreasing rudder deflection with full pedal movement as speed increases.

options.A: The elevators are positioned in response to the trim system to stabilise the aircraft in the pitch axis.
options.B: The entire horizontal tail assembly moves in response to control column or control stick movement to control the aircraft in the pitch axis.
options.C: The entire horizontal tail assembly moves in response to the trim system to stabilise the aircraft in the pitch axis.

key_points: As you can see at the bottom of this explanation, for the aileron and rudder the “zero force point” will be adjusted when trimming
This is not the case for elevator trim
When using the elevator (pitch) trim, the entire horizontal tail moves and therefore the zero force point will stay the same
learning.explanation: As you can see at the bottom of this explanation, for the aileron and rudder the “zero force point” will be adjusted when trimming. This is not the case for elevator trim. When using the elevator (pitch) trim, the entire horizontal tail moves and therefore the zero force point will stay the same. Primary flight controls Are controls which movement causes a rotation about one of the three axes of the aircraft, causing a change in the aircraft’s flightpath or attitude. The elevator, rudder and ailerons are considered to be the primary flight controls. The primary flight controls in a manually controlled system are reversible. This means that a force applied to the controls is a force which moves the control surface, and also a force which moves the control surface will move the pilot’s controls. This means that the air pressure on the control surface can be felt in the pilot’s controls. When the flight controls are fully power operated this is not the case and is called irreversible. This means that if there is a force moving the control surface this will not move the control columns, and there will be no natural feel on the controls. Because of this there will need to be an artificial feel unit installed in a fully powered or irreversible control system. This artificial feel unit should apply force to the cockpit controls in proportion to the control deflection and in proportion to the aircraft’s speed. The artificial feel system is placed in parallel with the hydraulic actuator, so the movement of the flight controls in the cockpit will cause the hydraulic actuator to operate. During this same movement the artificial feel system will apply pressure on the controls appropriate to the airspeed of the aircraft. This artificial feel system will also work with a trim system, but this works different than a normal trim surface does. A movement of the trimwheel will result in a movement of the electric trim actuator, and so the control surface, but not in the movement of the control column (this is for elevator control). It is different for aileron and rudder trim. Elevator trim: zero force position of the control column does not change (control column/horn/stick does not move) Aileron trim: zero force position changes (control wheel turns in the direction of the trim) Rudder trim: zero force position changes (pedals move in the direction of the trim)

content.question: The Airbus A320 has Fly By Wire flight controls. Imagine manually flying an Airbus A320 at low altitude and low airspeed, at the critical angle of attack. How can the pilots make the aircraft climb?

options.A: By trimming for a nose-up attitude.
options.B: By engaging AP in vertical speed mode.
options.C: Simply by pulling back on the sidestick.
options.D: By moving the thrust levers forward to increase speed.

key_points: Note: We think that the different authorities have different versions of this question
Some mention that it is a Fly By Wire aircraft, some saying Airbus, and some saying specifically A320
It is the same answer for all these, and EASA are usually talking about A320s when they mention Fly By Wire anyway
learning.explanation: Note: We think that the different authorities have different versions of this question. Some mention that it is a Fly By Wire aircraft, some saying Airbus, and some saying specifically A320. It is the same answer for all these, and EASA are usually talking about A320s when they mention Fly By Wire anyway. We think the questions are similar enough to warrant only this one in the bank, but if further feedback says otherwise, we will add separate questions. Fly By Wire systems A fly by wire control system is a powered system (irreversible) that uses electronic inputs to a solenoid servo valve instead of mechanical inputs from conventional powered controls. The pilot operates the controls, these can be a sidestick and rudder pedals or a conventional yoke with rudder pedals. These controls are fitted with transducers which convert the mechanical movement into an electrical output which is then amplified and processed by several computers. These computers provide the input for the servo valves which controls the movement of the hydraulic actuators attached to the flight control surfaces. One of the largest benefits of Fly By Wire is the flight envelope protection system. It has many abilities, including preventing excessive bank angles, preventing the stall, overspeed protection, overload protection, etc. This question used to be very ambiguous, but over the past year it has changed a few times, and now we know it is an Airbus (we believe it says A320 in some exam authorities) and it is flying at the critical angle of attack. As it is at its critical angle of attack, pulling back on the sidestick would make it initially attempt to climb, but as this would further increase the angle of attack and slow the aircraft, the flight envelope protections would step in and stop this pitching backwards. Therefore the only thing that can save us from this scenario is actually adding thrust. This will allow us to increase our speed, decreasing our AoA, and subsequently, the flight controls will allow us to begin a climb. This is the only way to induce any sort of climb from the very low energy state of the question. In fact, the Airbus A320 actually has a set of limiting angles of attack, where different measures will be taken one by one to stop an impending stall. One of those measures is automatically applying TO/GA (Take off/Go around) thrust. You are not expected to know this for the question, so do not assume that the aircraft will automatically do this if you keep pulling back. Video Explanation:

content.question: Rudder trim adjustment in an aeroplane with irreversible flight controls is…

options.A: unnecessary because this aeroplane does not need rudder trim.
options.B: an adjustment of the rudder ratio changer.
options.C: an adjustment of the zero force rudder position.
options.D: an adjustment of the rudder trim tab.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.05.01.03.05: Explain the operating principle of rudder and aileron trim in a fully powered control system. There are two basic types of flight controls, reversible and irreversible. Reversible flight controls are those that have a two way force mechanism naturally as part of the system. This includes manual flight controls, which use levers and pulleys to transfer pilot force to the controls, and partially powered controls, which are aided by hydraulic force, but there is still a mechanical connection between the pilot and controls (think powered steering in a car). The connecting factor is that if you went to the aileron and pushed it, the controls in the cockpit would move accordingly. The opposite are irreversible controls, which have no "backwards force", or "feel". These are only 1 way, so the pilot can move the control surfaces, but the control surfaces cannot move the pilot's controls. Fully powered hydraulic controls and fly-by-wire controls are irreversible. irreversible controls have no natural feedback, so require artificial "feel", so the pilot has something to push against, the controls naturally centre, etc. If you pushed the aileron, the controls would not move. There are pros and cons to both, but one benefit of irreversible controls such as fly by wire, is that trimming can be made easier. All a simple trim system needs to do is adjust where the system considers the "zero" point to be. Therefore the rudder (in this case) will sit naturally at the new "zero" point, which will produce a constant trim in a particular direction. Pitch trim can differ from this method though, and some manufacturers take their own stance on trimming, such as if the rudder pedals are supposed to move with the trim or not, etc.

key_points: FLY-BY-WIRE SYSTEMS Fly-By-Wire Systems remove the direct linkage from the control wheel to the Power Control Unit (PCU)
A FBW control system is a powered system (irreversible) that uses electronic inputs to a solenoid servo valve instead of mechanical inputs from conventional powered controls
The pilot operates the controls, these can be a sidestick and rudder pedals or a conventional yoke with rudder pedals
learning.explanation: FLY-BY-WIRE SYSTEMS Fly-By-Wire Systems remove the direct linkage from the control wheel to the Power Control Unit (PCU). A FBW control system is a powered system (irreversible) that uses electronic inputs to a solenoid servo valve instead of mechanical inputs from conventional powered controls. The pilot operates the controls, these can be a sidestick and rudder pedals or a conventional yoke with rudder pedals. These control inputs are sent to the Primary Flight Computer (PFC), which converts the mechanical movements of the control surfaces into a comum electrical output. The Actuator Control Electronics (ACE) takes these electrical signals and converts them into analogue signal which are sent to the Power Control Unit (PCU), the hydraulic actuators attached to the flight control surfaces.

content.question: An aircraft has a fully powered flight control system, linked to a single hydraulic actuator. If this actuator fails, which of the following will happen?

options.A: The control column will become jammed.
options.B: The back-up hydraulic system will be activated.
options.C: The pilot will need to use greater force to manoeuvre the aircraft.
options.D: The control surface will not respond to pilot inputs.

key_points: Fully powered flight controls means that there is no mechanical linkage between the pilot's controls and the control surfaces, but instead, the pilot's control movements command a servo valve which allows hydraulic pressure into the control surface actuators to provide a much larger force to the control surfaces than any pilot would ever be able to produce
There are, however, still some problems with that concept, such as in this question, where redundancy needs to be implemented in case of jammed or broken controls
This is usually done by duplication of actuators, of control runs, hydraulic system backups, multiple control surfaces, etc
learning.explanation: Fully powered flight controls means that there is no mechanical linkage between the pilot's controls and the control surfaces, but instead, the pilot's control movements command a servo valve which allows hydraulic pressure into the control surface actuators to provide a much larger force to the control surfaces than any pilot would ever be able to produce. There are, however, still some problems with that concept, such as in this question, where redundancy needs to be implemented in case of jammed or broken controls. This is usually done by duplication of actuators, of control runs, hydraulic system backups, multiple control surfaces, etc. A hydraulic actuator is a piston in a tube, which is moved by the hydraulic pressure, and mechanically moves the control surface. In this case, the single actuator has failed. If there is no redundancy for this part (which there is not in this scenario), then the control surface will not respond to any of the pilot's movements on the control column. It will be unusable.

One of the largest benefits of fly by wire is the flight envelope protection system. It has many abilities, including preventing excessive bank angles, preventing the stall, overspeed protection, overload protection, etc. In the event of severe windshear, the recommended way to gain altitude and escape the windshear is to apply maximum thrust and pitch up to a high attitude until reaching near the stall speed, then maintain that speed. In theory, a Fly-By-Wire aircraft can actually perform some of that for the pilot. Because of the stall protection of a Fly-By-Wire flight control system, in theory, the pilot can just apply full thrust and pull back on the sidestick all the way, and just hold it there. content.question: Which of the following is an advantage of Fly-By-Wire systems and their redundancy?

options.A: Better precision.
options.B: Increased stability.
options.C: Increased damage tolerance.
options.D: Better control feel.

key_points: Fly-By-Wire A Fly-By-Wire (FBW) control system is a fully powered flight control system (irreversible) that uses computers to translate pilot control inputs into movement of the hydraulically powered flight control surfaces
The answer to this question does seem a little counter-intuitive initially, but remember that the question is really asking about the advantages of fly-by-wire aircraft's redundancy elements

learning.explanation: Fly-By-Wire A Fly-By-Wire (FBW) control system is a fully powered flight control system (irreversible) that uses computers to translate pilot control inputs into movement of the hydraulically powered flight control surfaces. The answer to this question does seem a little counter-intuitive initially, but remember that the question is really asking about the advantages of fly-by-wire aircraft's redundancy elements. As Fly-By-Wire control systems have no manual back-up systems, and flight controls can be lost due to loss of power, loss of computers, loss of hydraulics, etc., they have multiple redundant systems to prevent this. In reality, they end up having more redundancy than some simpler systems, in the amount of separate systems that can be used as backups. For this question then, the correct answer is actually that FBW aircraft benefit from increased damage tolerance. Now we strongly believe that it very much depends on the type of damage and its location, but when you consider that FBW aircraft usually have 3 hydraulic systems and 3-4 flight control computers, you can see where the examiner is coming from. That is more redundant systems than simpler aircraft would usually have.

content.question: You are on an approach when extending flaps, due to a malfunction the right flap does not extend. What will happen to the aircraft?

options.A: Plane will bank right and left wing may stall.
options.B: Plane will bank left and right wing may stall.
options.C: Plane will bank right and right wing may stall.
options.D: Plane will go into a spin.

key_points: The extension of the left wing flaps generates an uneven increase in lift compared to the lack of flaps on the right wing
Consequently, the left wing raises, inducing a right bank in the aircraft
Furthermore, any aircraft maneuver that involves a turn leads to an elevation in the load factor
learning.explanation: The extension of the left wing flaps generates an uneven increase in lift compared to the lack of flaps on the right wing. Consequently, the left wing raises, inducing a right bank in the aircraft. Furthermore, any aircraft maneuver that involves a turn leads to an elevation in the load factor. Keep in mind that the stall speed grows proportionally to the square root of the load factor. Thus, in this situation, there is a heightened risk of stalling (and entering a spin) if prompt action is not taken, given the diminishing margin to the stall speed. In all cases of asymmetric flap, the wing with the greater amount of flap extended is producing a substantially higher amount of lift. At the same time, increased drag on the flaps-down side creates a pronounced adverse yaw situation, with the nose swinging toward the wing with most flaps deflected.

learning.explanation: At the rear of the fuselage of most aircraft one finds a horizontal stabilizer and an elevator. The trimmable stabilizer does not move in response to control column or control stick movement, instead it can be operated by moving the elevator trim switch. Trimmable horizontal stabilisers are normally moved by hydraulic actuators under either manual or electrical control. The most common type being moved by a hydraulically actuated jack.

content.question: How do auto-slat systems function and what is their main purpose?

options.A: Electrically operated auto-slats are linked to the angle of attack probe and retract only during cruise. Otherwise, they remain extended to prevent icing from forming on the leading edge.
options.B: Spring-powered auto-slats are extended by aerodynamic suction to delay the stalling angle of attack and are retracted by spring force to minimize drag.
options.C: Hydraulically powered auto-slats are extended if the aircraft's angle of attack approaches the stall, in order to delay the stalling angle of attack. They retract when the condition no longer exists to minimise drag.
options.D: Pneumatically operated auto-slats are heated by bleed air to prevent icing on the leading edge. They are operated by the landing gear lever, extending when the gear is selected down and retracting when up is selected.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.05.02.01.08: Describe the function of an auto-slat system. Slats Slats are aerodynamic surfaces on the leading edge of the wings of fixed-wing aircraft which, when deployed, allow the wing to operate at a higher angle of attack. At high angles of attack they allow the air over the wing to have much greater energy, allowing the aircraft to fly at much higher angles of attack without stalling. This allows the wing to produce a higher maximum coefficient of lift, and can therefore fly slower whilst still balancing the weight force with lift. Slats, like flaps, are therefore used for take-off, landing and slow flight, thereby reducing take-off and landing distances. Slats are still retracted for normal flight as they increase drag, similar to flaps. They are hydraulically powered, just like the flaps and other flight controls on large aircraft. Some aircrafts are equipped with an Auto-Slat System. This system enhances the airplane stalling characteristics. Upon receiving a signal from the stall warning system that the aircraft is close to the stall (high AoA), the auto-slat system automatically operates the slats, extending them from the midrange position to the fully extended landing position. The slats retract a few seconds after the signal is removed. This is a bit like a "get out of jail free" card, and allows a few extra degrees angle of attack before the wing completely stalls.

content.question: During level cruising flight, an aeroplane experiences a malfunction of the pressure controller. If the cabin vertical speed indicator reads 200 ft/min rate of descent…

options.A: the aircraft has to climb to a higher flight level in order to reduce the cabin altitude to its initial value.
options.B: the differential pressure will rise to its maximum value, thus causing the safety relief valves to open.
options.C: the crew has to intermittently cut off the incoming air flow in order to maintain a zero cabin altitude.
options.D: a descent must be initiated to prevent the oxygen masks dropping when the cabin altitude reaches 14 000 ft.

key_points: As the cabin vertical speed indicator reads a 200ft/min descent, this means that the pressure in the cabin is increasing
As the pressure is increasing while it shouldn’t, the maximum pressure differential will be exceeded causing the safety relief valves to open
Pressurization System control methods The way the pressure in the aircraft is controlled is by having a constant mass of air entering the cabin through the airconditioning system
learning.explanation: As the cabin vertical speed indicator reads a 200ft/min descent, this means that the pressure in the cabin is increasing. As the pressure is increasing while it shouldn’t, the maximum pressure differential will be exceeded causing the safety relief valves to open. Pressurization System control methods The way the pressure in the aircraft is controlled is by having a constant mass of air entering the cabin through the airconditioning system. This mass of air is kept constant by the mass flow controller. The pressure is regulated by the amount of air which is discharged back to the atmosphere by the outflow valves. So the more open these valves are, the lower the pressure will be in the aircraft. There must be two safety measures in place with these kind of systems to avoid a too high pressure or too low when the outside pressure is higher than that of the cabin. Safety valve This is a mechanical pressure relief valve which should open when the cabin exceeds the maximum pressure differential to which the aircraft is designed. Inward relief valve This valve works the other way around than the safety valve and will open once the pressure outside of the aircraft is higher so there will be no negative pressure differential. These two valves may be combined in the same unit or may be two separate units, but there must be at least two of each installed. Instrumentation The indications needed for a pressurized cabin are: Cabin altimeter, this reads a cabin pressure but it is calibrated in a way that it reads the equivalent in altitude of the cabin Cabin vertical speed Indicator, this indicates the rate at which the cabin altitude is climbing or descending. Cabin Differential Pressure Gauge, indicates the difference in absolute pressure between the inside of the cabin and the pressure outside of the aircraft. In additional to these parameters there should be a visual and aural warning when the cabin exceeds an altitude of 10 000 ft.

content.question: When does the pressurization start during the flight?

options.A: When the pressure controller senses that the aircraft is airborne.
options.B: When the altitude of 8000 ft is reached.
options.C: During start-up/taxi.
options.D: During climbout.

key_points: PRE-PRESSURIZATION In general, you want the cabin to be pressurized in flight; and not pressurized on the ground If the system followed only and exactly that logic, at the moment of lift-off, it would start pressurizing immediately, with the goal of overcoming the sudden change in pressure due to the aircraft's rapid climb away from the ground
In practice, that ends up being a pressure "bump" right at (or slightly after) rotation, which is undesirable since it is at least noticeable and potentially uncomfortable

To prevent this pressure "bump", the pressure controller is programmed to slowly pressurize the cabin slightly while the aircraft is still on the ground, so that at lift-off it is essentially maintaining the differential it has, rather than starting pressurization all at once

To prevent this pressure "bump", the pressure controller is programmed to slowly pressurize the cabin slightly while the aircraft is still on the ground, so that at lift-off it is essentially maintaining the differential it has, rather than starting pressurization all at once.
