content.question: In an air cycle machine (bootstrap system), bleed air downstream of the first heat exchanger is...

options.A: passed across an expansion turbine, compressed and then passed through the second heat exchanger.
options.B: passed across an expansion turbine, then directly passed to the second heat exchanger.
options.C: compressed, then passed across an expansion turbine and finally passed across the second heat exchanger.
options.D: compressed, passed through the second heat exchanger and then passed across an expansion turbine.

key_points: AIR CYCLE MACHINE Air Cycle Machines are ideally suited for turbine aircraft due to the supply of already compressed bleed air
Often referred to as "air conditioning packs"
In Air Cycle Machines, high-pressure bleed air from the engines is first pre-cooled in the primary heat exchanger
learning.explanation: AIR CYCLE MACHINE Air Cycle Machines are ideally suited for turbine aircraft due to the supply of already compressed bleed air. Often referred to as "air conditioning packs". In Air Cycle Machines, high-pressure bleed air from the engines is first pre-cooled in the primary heat exchanger. The bleed air is then compressed in the compressor section and is then fed through to the secondary heat exchanger to remove as much heat as possible before being expanded and introduced to the turbine section which is used to drive the compressor. After passing through the turbine section, the air is then ducted through a water separator to remove excess moisture from the conditioned air before it enters the cabin and cockpit via a one way check valve. Finally, the air passes through a humidifier to increase the moisture content of the conditioning air.

options.B: temperature drop across the turbine is the main contributor to the cooling effect of the air cycle machine.

key_points: What the answer to this question is looking for is that because the pressure and temperature rises across the compressor, there will be a higher difference in temperature between the compressed air and the charge air flowing around the secondary heat exchanger making it more efficient
A bootstrap system is based on a compressor driven by a turbine which is in turn driven by the charge air
In a bootstrap air cycle machine air is tapped from the low pressure compressor of the engine
learning.explanation: What the answer to this question is looking for is that because the pressure and temperature rises across the compressor, there will be a higher difference in temperature between the compressed air and the charge air flowing around the secondary heat exchanger making it more efficient. A bootstrap system is based on a compressor driven by a turbine which is in turn driven by the charge air. In a bootstrap air cycle machine air is tapped from the low pressure compressor of the engine. This air is then precooled by the primary heat exchanger after which it will pass through the compressor. This will increase pressure and temperature, increasing the pressure will make the energy conversion later in the turbine more efficient. After the compressor the air passes through the secondary heat exchanger to remove the excess heat caused by the compressor. The main temperature reduction is achieved in the heat exchangers. The goal of this system is to be able to use air from only the low pressure compressor. With the compressor in place there will be a sufficiently high pressure drop through the turbine.

key_points: PRESSURIZATION SYSTEMS Cabin pressurization is achieved by feeding air into the cabin (through air conditioning packs) and restricting its flow out - by using electric motor-operated outflow valves
The valves are automatically controlled by the aircraft’s pressurization system when in automatic control

If a higher pressure is needed inside the cabin, the outflow is reduced by closing the outflow valves (which increases the pressure); To reduce cabin pressure, the outflow valve slowly opens, allowing more air to escape
learning.explanation: PRESSURIZATION SYSTEMS Cabin pressurization is achieved by feeding air into the cabin (through air conditioning packs) and restricting its flow out - by using electric motor-operated outflow valves. The valves are automatically controlled by the aircraft’s pressurization system when in automatic control. If a higher pressure is needed inside the cabin, the outflow is reduced by closing the outflow valves (which increases the pressure); To reduce cabin pressure, the outflow valve slowly opens, allowing more air to escape. The aim is to maintain a proportional relationship between ambient and cabin pressure and a constant pressure differential in cruise. The outflow valves are positioned to regulate the release of air from the cabin at the pre-selected rate to achieve the required differential pressure and eventual stabilization at the selected cabin altitude. When the outflow valves stabilize (generally remain slightly open in cruise), providing that flight altitude (and ambient pressure) and air conditioning system settings remain unchanged => a constant air mass flow through the cabin is achieved.

In this case, during descent, a malfunction of the pressure controller will result in the OUTFLOW VALVE to be in the open position at high altitude - The pressure controller is what controls the cabin pressure

learning.explanation: When the aircraft is cruising at high altitude (FL310), the cabin altitude will be between 5000 and 8000 ft, in a pressurised comercial aircraft. In this case, during descent, a malfunction of the pressure controller will result in the OUTFLOW VALVE to be in the open position at high altitude - The pressure controller is what controls the cabin pressure. The effects of that malfunction will result in the following in regard to cabin pressure: Cabin rate of climb: Initially increases. The pressure in the cabin is as if it is climbing to higher altitude. Cabin pressure altitude: Increases. The valve being open is as if you have a broken window, and losing your cabin pressurisation (basically decompression is taking place). Eventually, the cabin pressure will end up equalising the ambient pressure. At this point, the cabin rate of descent will equal the rate of descent of the aircraft. Differential pressure: Decreases The difference between the cabin pressure and the outside pressure at high altitude is getting closer towards equalising, if it is not to be stoped. Eventually, the differential pressure will be 0. Cabin Pressure - Ambient Outside Pressure = Differential Pressure

key_points: AIR CYCLE MACHINE Air Cycle Machines are ideally suited for turbine aircraft due to the supply of already compressed bleed air

learning.explanation: AIR CYCLE MACHINE Air Cycle Machines are ideally suited for turbine aircraft due to the supply of already compressed bleed air. Often referred to as "air conditioning packs". In Air Cycle Machines, high-pressure bleed air from the engines is first pre-cooled in the primary heat exchanger. The bleed air is then compressed in the compressor section and is then fed through to the secondary heat exchanger to remove as much heat as possible before being expanded and introduced to the turbine section which is used to drive the compressor. After passing through the turbine section, the air is then ducted through a water separator to remove excess moisture from the conditioned air before it enters the cabin and cockpit via a one way check valve. Finally, the air passes through a humidifier to increase the moisture content of the conditioning air. As discussed above, the temperature reduction of the air inside the system is accomplished by air passing through heat exchangers. Heat exchangers normally use ram air as the cooling medium. In flight, ram air doors are modulated to increase or decrease ram air flow to the exchanger. During slow flight or when on the ground, a "ground cooling fan" is responsible to draw air through the ram air duct so that the heat exchange is possible when the aircraft is stationary.

key_points: Most jet aircraft have pneumatic systems with 2 separate air conditioning packs

These usually use bleed air that has been taken from that side engine's compressor, thereby having a left pack which runs from left engine bleed air, and a right pack which runs off air from the right hand engine(s)

learning.explanation: Most jet aircraft have pneumatic systems with 2 separate air conditioning packs. These usually use bleed air that has been taken from that side engine's compressor, thereby having a left pack which runs from left engine bleed air, and a right pack which runs off air from the right hand engine(s). The APU also feeds bleed air into the pneumatic system (usually to the left side). In the air, the system should operate normally with no interaction between the left and right side. There is an isolation valve between the two systems to either make them interconnected or completely separate. This is usually open on the ground when the engines are off to provide APU bleed air to both packs for cooling and to both engines for starting. It is closed in the air for split operation, unless an abnormal situation occurs, such as a loss of engine bleed air, pack failure, etc., when the isolation valve will either automatically be opened or the flight crew will open it to balance the load within the system. A significant pressure difference between the two sides of an isolation valve in the air is likely to mean that one of the sides has an issue that the other does not have. In the case of the Boeing 737 specifically (image shown above), the isolation valve opens automatically if any of the pack or engine bleed switches are NOT in their normal locations (bleeds on, packs auto) as the system knows that the pneumatics will become unbalanced in that case (bleed off, pack off, or pack set to high flow, etc.). It can be manually forced open or closed though by positioning the switch each side of the "AUTO" position. It is not good to feed bleed air into a leaky duct, though, so that is something to be careful of with pressure differentials. As for the other options: "They close when the system pressure equals the environmental pressure." This is talking roughly about the pressurisation outflow valve. That is what controls the pressure in the cabin. "They open when there is a leak in one of the systems." This is a bad thing, as we do not want to feed hot bleed air into a leaky air duct, due to overheating and potential loss of pressurisation. "They close when the engines are at maximum thrust." Engines at high thrust produce more bleed air, but they will produce it to both sides of the pneumatic manifold, so isolation valve open or closed, it shouldn't make too much difference.

content.question:
Refer to figure.
An aircraft cruising level is FL380. What altitude should the aircraft's cabin be to maintain a differential pressure of 8.17 psi?

key_points: "Cabin pressure differential" is the actual pressure difference between the inside and the outside of the pressurized cabin of the aircraft

99 PSI
learning.explanation: "Cabin pressure differential" is the actual pressure difference between the inside and the outside of the pressurized cabin of the aircraft. Locate the value of 38 000 ft in the first column on the left => continue horizontally to the right and read the corresponding pressure 2.99 PSI. The maximum allowed pressure differential is 8.17 PSI - that means that the cabin pressure is "outside air pressure (2.99) + differential pressure (8.17)= 11.16 PSI" Cabin altitude corresponding to 11.16 psi is found by interpolating 7000-8000 ft and 11.34-10.92 PSI. For the 0.42 PSI change between 11.34 PSI (7000 ft) and 10.92 (8000 ft) PSI, the change in altitude is 1000 ft in total. So each 0.01 PSI change causes a change in altitude of 23.81 ft. We can calculate 11.16 PSI cabin pressure based on 11.34 PSI or 10.92 PSI. Let's base it on 11.34 PSI. The difference between this and the cabin pressure we calculated is 0.18 (11.34 - 11.16) PSI. Since every 0.01 PSI change causes a change in altitude of 23.81 ft, a change of 0.18 PSI causes an altitude change of 429 ft (23.81 x 18). If we add this value to our base altitude (7000 ft), the result is 7429 ft. (We added it because the altitude increases as the PSI decreases) The closest answer is 7430 ft.

key_points: AIR CYCLE MACHINE Air Cycle Machines are ideally suited for turbine aircraft due to the supply of already compressed bleed air

learning.explanation: AIR CYCLE MACHINE Air Cycle Machines are ideally suited for turbine aircraft due to the supply of already compressed bleed air. Often referred to as "air conditioning packs". In Air Cycle Machines, high-pressure bleed air from the engines is first pre-cooled in the primary heat exchanger. The bleed air is then compressed in the compressor section and is then fed through to the secondary heat exchanger to remove as much heat as possible before being expanded and introduced to the turbine section which is used to drive the compressor. After passing through the turbine section, the air is then ducted through a water separator to remove excess moisture from the conditioned air before it enters the cabin and cockpit via a one way check valve. Finally, the air passes through a humidifier to increase the moisture content of the conditioning air. Note: Both temperature and pressure decrease when passing through the Air Cycle Machine. However, the main function of an air cycle machine is to cool the bleed air.

learning.explanation: This is sneaky, they are asking about the indication in the cabin of a bleed air duct leak. Therefore, the usual (and very easy) answer of the bleed air duct leak indicator light is no longer correct, because there is no such light in the cabin, only in the flight deck. The bleed air in the pneumatic system is usually fed from a "bleed air source" in a gas turbine engine, which is effectively just air that has already gone through some of the compressor stages and is siphoned off to pressurise the system (not burnt). It is then distributed through pipes to the various parts of the aircraft where it is needed, such as the air conditioning packs or the leading edges of the wings and tailplane for de/anti-icing. The bleed air is very hot (a temperature of 400°C is sometimes quoted, for context) and so any leaks of these pipes could be harmful to the passengers or the other aircraft equipment. Thankfully, it is usually kept far away from passengers, for just this reason, so the first sign of a duct leak in the cabin would likely be reduction in airflow coming through the vents. This is because less air is fed into the air conditioning packs (as some of it has leaked out), so less air is able to be cooled and sent to the cabin vents. The cabin pressure will not drop rapidly as the loss of pressurisation is small, depending on the location of the duct leak, and the outflow valve will close naturally to keep the remaining pressure inside. It could be argued that the cabin temperature could rise above normal limits, but this is highly dependent on the location of the leak. The majority of the bleed air lines exist in the wings and underbelly of the aircraft (mostly unpressurised areas) so the chance of the passenger cabin being heated by this is quite slim, but some aircraft equipment could certainly be damaged.

Aircraft components that must be protected from ice accumulations include the leading edges of wing and tail surfaces, pitot and static source openings, fuel tank vents, stall warning sensors, windshields, and propeller blades. Additionally, engines can require alternate sources of intake air or ice protected inlets. WINDSHIELD ICE CONTROL. Most aircraft are equipped with a defroster consisting of vents that direct heated air across the windshield on the inside of the cabin. To prevent ice formation, most windshields are electrically heated: small wires or electrically conductive materials are embedded in the windshield or in a panel of glass installed over the exterior of the windshield. By passing electric current through the windshield or panel, sufficient heat is produced to prevent ice formation. OTHER ICE CONTROL SYSTEMS. The pitot tube and static port openings, fuel vents and stall warning sensors, typically contain electrical elements to prevent ice formation. The different parts of the aircraft that require ice protection are the wing leading edges, the tail leading edges, any probes or vanes, the windscreen, the engine inlets and the propellers (if fitted). All these components can be de-iced when ice is detected, except for the engines, which have to be anti-iced, as any ice build up could fall into the engine when dislodged and potentially cause a flame out or even damage. On some airframes it is better to anti-ice the wing leading edges aswell, especially if using a weeping wing design like on many light aircraft. Anti-ice systems in turbine-type engines often use engine bleed air to prevent ice formation by heating or otherwise managing the temperature of critical components to ensure safe and efficient engine operation.

Piezoelectric sensors are very interesting. They create a linkage between movement and electric signals via the stress of a particular "piezoelectric" crystal. In this case, they are used to measure vibrations of an ice detection sensor. This is usually a small rod that sticks out from the aircraft fuselage and vibrates at the natural frequency of the rod, but any ice buildup will cause that natural frequency to change, and this change will be sensed by the piezoelectric crystal, triggering a warning for the pilots that ice buildup has been detected.

learning.explanation: Thermal anti-ice systems Thermal anti-ice systems heat the surfaces on aeroplanes to prevent or remove ice formation. Hot air anti-ice systems are installed on most turbojet and some turboprop aeroplanes. This is because a turbine engine has a ready source of hot air that can be used to heat aerofoil leading edges or engine cowlings. This is "bleed" air, which is taken from the high pressure, hot air in the engine compressors. Engine cowlings: On a turbojet/turbofan engine, the leading edges of the cowlings are usually heated with hot bleed air as an "anti-icing" system, which prevents ice from forming in the first place. Wing leading edges: These can be fed by hot bleed air, but require much greater volumes of bleed air than the engine cowlings, so are more commonly used as a "de-icing" system, where ice that has already formed can be removed.

key_points: SMITHS ICE DETECTOR The Smiths ice detector (also known as differential pressure ice accretion detector) consists of a hollow tube which contains a series of small holes and one large hole positioned in its leading edge and a separate series in its trailing edge
The detector monitors pressure differential between the two edges
In flight under normal conditions, the holes remain open and, consequently, the pressure differential is zero
learning.explanation: SMITHS ICE DETECTOR The Smiths ice detector (also known as differential pressure ice accretion detector) consists of a hollow tube which contains a series of small holes and one large hole positioned in its leading edge and a separate series in its trailing edge. The detector monitors pressure differential between the two edges. In flight under normal conditions, the holes remain open and, consequently, the pressure differential is zero. In icing conditions, holes in the leading edge rapidly become blocked by ice. This causes a change in the pressure differential - a decrease in dynamic pressure is sensed, causing the relay unit to give a warning. A heater element is fitted around the tube to dissipate accumulated ice, which heats up the small holes first causing the indications to turn off.

key_points: Compressed air is taken from the HP compressor stage of a gas turbine engine and is used for various purposes: de/anti-icing, air conditioning, engine start
This compressed air driven from the compressor is known as bleed air
When selecting the bleed air ‘ON’ some of the air will be sucked out of the normal flow inside the engine and will induce some inconveniences and risks
learning.explanation: Compressed air is taken from the HP compressor stage of a gas turbine engine and is used for various purposes: de/anti-icing, air conditioning, engine start. This compressed air driven from the compressor is known as bleed air. When selecting the bleed air ‘ON’ some of the air will be sucked out of the normal flow inside the engine and will induce some inconveniences and risks. In fact, the mass flow of air will be reduced, which will increase the engine’s overall temperature, especially the turbine temperature since less air is available for cooling. It also increases specific fuel consumption and the EGT and the power output (or thrust) will be decreased, in other words, aircraft, and more precisely engine performance will greatly be decreased. Because of all this, it is normal to see PACKS OFF take-off, since all the available power is needed during this critical stage of the flight. Conducting a PACKS OFF take-off also has the advantage of reducing the required thrust and the noise footprint.

learning.explanation: SMITHS ICE DETECTOR The Smiths ice detector (also known as a differential pressure ice accretion detector) consists of a hollow tube which contains a series of small holes and one large hole positioned in its leading edge and a separate series in its trailing edge. In icing conditions, holes in the leading edge rapidly become blocked by ice. This causes a change in the pressure differential - a decrease in dynamic pressure is sensed, causing the relay unit to give a warning. A heater element is fitted around the tube to dissipate accumulated ice, which heats up the small holes first causing the indications to turn off.

content.question: Regarding the load factor, an aircraft's maximum allowable load factor is determined by the manufacturer. For a particular aircraft, the maximum load limit with flaps extended is half of the load factor in the clean configuration. Which of the following options completes the statement correctly? In level and unaccelerated flight...

options.A: the difference between maximum load limit for flaps extended and clean wing is necessary as structural strength of the wing is lower with flaps extended.
options.B: the load factor with flaps extended will be higher than the load factor in the clean configuration.
options.C: the margin between actual load factor and maximum load factor decreases with increased bank angle.
options.D: the load factor at which structural damage occurs can never be more than +2.0G when flaps are extended.

key_points: Let's go through each answer: "In level and unaccelerated flight
the difference between maximum load limit for flaps extended and clean wing is necessary as structural strength of the wing is lower with flaps extended
" This is saying that the wing is weaker when flaps are extended
learning.explanation: Let's go through each answer: "In level and unaccelerated flight. the difference between maximum load limit for flaps extended and clean wing is necessary as structural strength of the wing is lower with flaps extended." This is saying that the wing is weaker when flaps are extended. This is not correct, as the wing structure does not rely of the flaps. What actually causes the lower maximum load factor with flaps extended is the flap mechanism. With flaps extended, the higher the load factor, the more force is travelling through the mechanism which locks the flaps down, which are moving parts, so not as strong as the wing itself. "In level and unaccelerated flight. the load factor with flaps extended will be higher than the load factor in the clean configuration." The load factor is simply lift/weight, and in straight and level flight, the lift will always equal the weight, therefore the load factor is 1, whether the flaps are up and down. It has not specified straight flight, but the same would be true in a turn of a particular bank angle; load factor is the same, with or without flaps. "In level and unaccelerated flight. the margin between current load factor and maximum load factor decreases with increased bank angle." Correct. In a level turn, the aircraft's wings have to produce a higher lift force, as the lift force is no longer straight upwards, but is instead pointing into the direction of turn somewhat. The steeper the bank angle, the greater the lift force has to be (to remain level), which means that the actual load factor has to increase. As the maximum load factor is a fixed value, the margin between actual and maximum decreases with increased bank angle. "In level and unaccelerated flight. the load factor at which structural damage occurs can never be more than +2.0G when flaps are extended." We had no feedback for this option, so made this up to fill in the gap. It is incorrect because flaps can be made as strong as you like. They could manage up to +15G if the manufacturer wants to. There are minimum values to their strength though, defined in the certification specifications.

Remark: Stress is the internal force per unit area inside a structural part as a result of external loads. Strain is the deformation caused by the action of stress on a material. An aircraft is constantly subject to various forces; tension, compression, torsion and shearing forces are all occurring in an aircraft in varying amounts. For instance, when stationary on the ground, the wing is heavy, and is being pulled down due to gravity, wanting to droop downwards away from the fixed wing root. This means that the top surface of the wing will be under tension, as it is trying to be stretched, but the bottom surface would be under compression, as it is being squashed. Also, The weight of the whole aircraft is being opposed by reaction forces that travel through the landing gear and all the structurally load bearing components of the structure. These are amongst the many forces acting on a stationary aeroplane. The forces are very different when flying in straight and level (1 G) flight, where, for instance, the wings are suspending the heavy fuselage due to their ability to create lift. In this case the wings are flexing upwards away from the wing root, as can be seen very clearly on newer aircraft such as the B787 and A350. In this scenario, the upper surface of the wing is being squashed, so is under compression, where the bottom surface of the wing is under tension. The rest of the aircraft also sustains new forces, such as that of pressurisation on the pressure hull. The forces change again during manoeuvres, taxi, take-off and landing. Any of these forces can be described in terms of stress and strain. Stress is the measure of force applied (per unit of cross-sectional area) whereas strain is the measure of deformation, usually as a proportion of the original size of the component. After this interval has been reached the structure should be replaced, inspected or overhauled per manufacturers recommendations. “Multiple load path” and “Damage-tolerant structure” both refers to a fail-safe system: Fail-safe: When a structure fails there is alternative load-path provided by an adjacent part which is able to take over the loads for a limited amount of time. This normally should be enough time until the next periodic inspection where the damage should be identified and the damaged part replaced. Redundancy means that there are more than one systems which can do the same task in case one or more fail. That’s why modern aircraft usually have 2 or even 3 hydraulic systems which can take over the functions of the other in case it fails.

content.question: The principle of “on condition” maintenance is based on the…

options.A: capability to withstand a certain amount of weakening of the structure without catastrophic failure.
options.B: redundancy of the structure or equipment.
options.C: replacement of parts after a given number of cycles or hours of use.
options.D: monitoring of critical parameters of a component or a piece of equipment and its replacement if a limit value is exceeded.

key_points: On condition maintenance is fairly straight forward, it will need maintenance once it has a condition which needs repair
This can be when a part gives a failure by itself or when some parameters are out of limits
Therefore “monitoring of critical parameters of a component or piece of equipment and its replacement if a limit value is exceeded” is correct

content.question:
Which of the following statements are correct or incorrect in reference to loads on an aircraft's structure?
1. Dynamic loads only occur during fligh
2. Static loads only occur when parked on the apron

options.A: Both statements are correct.
options.B: 1 is incorrect, 2 is correct.
options.C: 1 is correct, 2 is incorrect.
options.D: Both statements are incorrect.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.01.02.01.02: Describe the following types of loads that an aircraft may be subjected to, when they occur, and how a pilot may affect their magnitude: static loads; dynamic loads; cyclic loads. As stated in the Learning Objective above, there are three types of load, but they are not completely mutually exclusive. Static loads are loads that do not change in size, position or direction. These could be loads such as the weight of the aircraft through the wheels when parked, or the tension on the upper skin of the wing when on the ground. They are quite easy to account for. Dynamic loads are loads that do change in size, position or direction. They must be accounted for more heavily by engineers, as a constantly changing load can cause more fatigue or early failure if not expected. There are countless dynamic loads on an aircraft, taxiing loads, the engine pylons, the bending of the wing spar in turbulent flight, the control surfaces during manoeuvring, etc. Cyclic loads are a special type of the aforementioned loads. They are loads which have expected cycles, the main one being the pressurisation cycle of the aircraft. It is a static load when non-pressurised and when fully pressurised, but dynamic as it changes. The cyclical nature does mean that engineers can build it to last, and monitor it's progress also, giving an aircraft a number of available pressurisation cycles, which can dictate its lifespan. This question simply wants you to know that there are constantly loads of all types occuring on an aircraft at all times. static loads also occur whilst in flight, and dynamic loads occur on the ground, even when parked (wind, boarding, etc.), so the two statements are both incorrect.

This indicates that the wings have been forced to bend upwards

options.A: Growth of fungus on the lower fuselage.
options.B: White spots on bare aluminium surfaces.
options.C: Discolouration of paint.
options.D: Cracks at attachment joints.

key_points: Indications of corrosive attack can take several forms depending on the type of metal and the length of time the corrosion has developed
Corrosion deposits on aluminium and magnesium are generally a white/grey powder, while ferrous metals vary from red to dark reddish-brown stains
The white spots could be indicative of small regions of "pitting", which can be very structurally damaging to an airframe

content.question: An aircraft has been parked up for a significant amount of time. The last entry in the aircraft tech log by the maintenance organisation was made before the aircraft's last flight. Amongst other elements, this statement mentions that the aircraft is considered airworthy up to a certain amount of flight hours, which have not yet been reached by the aircraft. No technical malfunctions or deferred defects have been entered in the tech log. Which of the following statements is correct?

options.A: The aircraft can be considered airworthy provided a visual inspection of the aircraft does NOT reveal technical malfunctions. This is referred to as condition monitoring.
options.B: The airworthiness maintenance statement could also contain a due date for hard-time maintenance after a certain number of cycles, which needs to be verified.
options.C: After each parking period, irrespective of the duration, the airworthiness maintenance statement will need to be revised. This is an example of a hard-time maintenance method.
options.D: The maintenance statement remains always valid up to the flight time limits provided.

key_points: Note: This is quite a complex question and we do not believe it has any truly correct answers, but so far we know of 2 answers that are reported as incorrect (in Polish ULC at least)
We have therefore chosen the answer we believe to be most correct out of the other 2 options
Unfortunately, the wording makes this question rather difficult to answer at all, and the answer we evaluated as "most correct" is not correct in the exams
learning.explanation: Note: This is quite a complex question and we do not believe it has any truly correct answers, but so far we know of 2 answers that are reported as incorrect (in Polish ULC at least). We have therefore chosen the answer we believe to be most correct out of the other 2 options. Unfortunately, the wording makes this question rather difficult to answer at all, and the answer we evaluated as "most correct" is not correct in the exams. Please send any exam feedback you can remember to us in the comments or by email to info@atplquestions.com, thank you! Large aircraft are built to be flown almost continuously. After an aircraft has been parked for any significant length of time (it is unclear how long this is classed to be - anecdotal reports indicate as little as a week of being parked), the aircraft must be checked over by an engineer, subject to engine runs, fully powered-up, etc., to inspect for airworthiness. It is very difficult to find authoritative documents for this, as it will vary from operator to operator, and from aircraft to aircraft, manufacturer to manufacturer, etc. The two types of maintenance are "on-condition maintenance", where each part is checked to see if maintenance is required on a regular basis; and "hard time maintenance", where every component is overhauled or replaced after a certain amount of time/number of cycles. We would consider this scenario to be "on-condition maintenance", but the examiner may well disagree with that. See the individual explanations of each option below. We can look at each option individually: "The aircraft can be considered airworthy provided a visual inspection of the aircraft does NOT reveal technical malfunctions. This is referred to as condition monitoring." Reported as incorrect. What this option describes is effectively a pre-flight check, as the person undertaking the inspection is not identified, and the pilot must do this before every flight anyway, and therefore does not include the fact that the aircraft has been parked for a while. "The airworthiness maintenance statement could also contain a due date for hard-time maintenance after a certain number of cycles." This option is phrased very badly, but at the moment it is our best guess at the correct answer. It is all quite true, and some items are not expected to wear whilst the aircraft is parked, etc., but the words "due date" are misleading as how can it be known when an aircraft will complete that many cycles in the future? We think that maybe the examiner has not considered this phrasing, and means due date as a fixed number of cycles, not an actual date. "After each parking period, irrespective of the duration, the airworthiness maintenance statement will need to be revised. This is an example of a hard-time maintenance method." Reported as incorrect. This answer has flaws. The engineers will revise the airworthiness maintenance statement by performing an inspection and testing when the aircraft is coming back to service after being parked. We would, however, argue that this is not an example of hard time maintenance, which is the flaw in this option. "The maintenance statement remains always valid up to the flight time limits provided." No, the aircraft must certainly be checked over after a period of being parked, as per the main explanation above.

content.question: The flight crew has reported a rusty landing gear in the aircraft tech-log. The aircraft remained in service after a maintenance check. What kind of maintenance check did the aircraft undergo?

options.A: Post-condition maintenance.
options.B: On-condition maintenance.
options.C: Soft-time maintenance.
options.D: Hard-time maintenance.

key_points: There are two main types of maintenance process: Hard-time maintenance: refers to planned maintenance of a component, which is overhauled or replaced upon a set number of flight hours or cycles of operation
It is strictly forbidden to allow components to remain in service after the conclusion of their hard-time period
On-condition maintenance: refers to predictive maintenance that involves replacement or overhaul of components before a failure happens
learning.explanation: There are two main types of maintenance process: Hard-time maintenance: refers to planned maintenance of a component, which is overhauled or replaced upon a set number of flight hours or cycles of operation. It is strictly forbidden to allow components to remain in service after the conclusion of their hard-time period. On-condition maintenance: refers to predictive maintenance that involves replacement or overhaul of components before a failure happens. Regular inspection of components gives maintenance teams records about the condition of each monitored part on an aircraft. This type of maintenance is based on monitoring of critical parameters of a component or piece of equipment and its replacement if a limit value is exceeded

content.question: The property of a material to return to its original shape after the stress has been removed is called…

options.A: strength.
options.B: plastic deformation.
options.C: strain.
options.D: elastic deformation.

key_points: Elastic/Plastic Deformation When a sufficient load is applied to a metal or other structural material, it will cause the material to change shape
This change is called deformation
Elastic Deformation: A temporary shape change that is self-reversing after the force is removed, so that the object returns to its original shape
learning.explanation: Elastic/Plastic Deformation When a sufficient load is applied to a metal or other structural material, it will cause the material to change shape. This change is called deformation. Elastic Deformation: A temporary shape change that is self-reversing after the force is removed, so that the object returns to its original shape. Plastic Deformation: The object is permanently deformed, and therefore, will not return to its original shape. Strain: This is an external force which acts on a structure of sufficient magnitude that the structural dimensions change.

content.question: In theory, the fatigue life limit is reached sooner when an aircraft makes, on a daily basis…

options.A: six flights of 30 minutes each.
options.B: three flights of one hour each.
options.C: two flights of 90 minutes each.
options.D: one flight of three hours.

key_points: Fatigue is a term which is used for materials which have to endure cyclic loads
This is where a structure experiences reversal of loading and will fail at a load of less force than it would for a steadily applied load
So this means that an aircraft which makes more cycles has to endure more cyclic loads and therefore reaches the life limit sooner
learning.explanation: Fatigue is a term which is used for materials which have to endure cyclic loads. This is where a structure experiences reversal of loading and will fail at a load of less force than it would for a steadily applied load. So this means that an aircraft which makes more cycles has to endure more cyclic loads and therefore reaches the life limit sooner. The answer with the most amount of cycles per day is the correct answer, in this case six flights of 30 minutes each.

options.C: A properly maintained aircraft won't see any change in stress or strain during the turn.
options.D: Strain will increase due to the increased load factor, but stress will be unchanged.

If you have any further exam feedback against this question, please put it in the comments or email it to info@atplquestions.com An aircraft is constantly subject to various forces; tension, compression, torsion and shearing forces are all occurring in an aircraft in varying amounts. Any of these forces can be described in terms of stress and strain. Stress is the measure of force applied (per unit of cross-sectional area) whereas strain is the measure of deformation, usually as a proportion of the original size of the component. They are present on almost every item in some way, and are present in a multitude of different ways on an aircraft at all times. When an aircraft enters a turn, the load factor on the wings increases, as the wings are now required to produce more lift than before. This leads to a change in the stress (and therefore strain) on the aircraft, in particular, an increased load (stress) on the wing spars and roots, which cause a flex in the wing, demonstrating the extra strain.
